column55: Purpose: The City of Bismarck applies FFY2022 5307 Small Urban Formula funds for the full allocation of $1711465. The funds will be used for the following:Activities to be Performed:Project #1) Operating Assistance - Fixed Route and ParatransitProject #2) Capital Cost of Contracting - The City of Bismarck falls under #1 on the chart for Capital Cost of Contracting from FTA Circular 9030.1E page IV-12: 1. Service Contract (contractor provides maintenance and transit service; recipient provides vehicles. The City of Bismarck contracts out the operations of its Transit System to Bis-Man Transit; this contract is attached in application documents.Project #3) Preventive Maintenance - Fund and support bus and facility maintenance activities as defined in the national Transit Database Reporting Manual.Project #4) 1% Security - Security enhancements for buses and bus facilities.Expected Outcomes: Daily public transportation services will continue to be provided to the public in a safe convenient and efficient manner. Facilities and buses will be maintained in a state of good repair providing the public and transit employees safe comfortable and secure buses and facilities from which to access and administer public transportation services.Intended Beneficiaries: Operating Assistance benefits the transit staff and funds daily operations thereby benefiting the public by providing a transit system for their use. The Capital Cost of Contracting which covers tasks associated with the physical operation of the buses and routes benefits the public directly at the point of service. Preventive Maintenance benefits the total system by keeping it in a state of good repair which also indirectly benefits the public who use the service. Security enhancements will increase the security of the transit facility and transit services to the public.Subrecipient Activities: N/AThe local match for all projects in this grant will be provided my mill levy of various jurisdictions.The FY2022 North Dakota Governors Apportionment Letter is attached to this application under application documents.The STIP project listing and approval letters are attached to this application under application documents.
column90: THE CITY OF BISMARCK CONTRACTS OUT THE OPERATIONS OF ITS TRANSIT SYSTEM TO BIS-MAN TRANSIT.  THE 5307 GRANT IS FOR OPERATING, CAPITAL COST CONTRACTING, PREVENTATIVE MAINTENANCE AND VEHICLE MAINTENANCE.

column55: The purpose of the Weatherization Assistance Program is to increase the energy efficiency of dwellings owned and occupied by low-income persons, reduce their total residential expenditures, and improve their health and safety. The priority population for the Weatherization Assistance Program is persons who are particularly vulnerable such as the elderly, persons with disabilities, families with children, high residential energy users, and households with high-energy burden.

column28: 0001: URBANIZED AREA PROGRAMS;0016: BUS AND BUS FACILITIES FORMULA GRANTS
column55: Texas Department of Transportation 5339 BBF formula apportionments FY 2021 and FY 2022. These funds were distributed to the 36 subrecipients that represent Texas rural transit districts.RURAL TOTAL $7500000 TDC 1279516 July 6 2022 TDC letter awarding 1400000 TDCs attached.FY21 $3500000FY22 $4000000 The funds will be used by 5339 eligible subrecipients to support capital projects such as the purchase of new and replacement fleet new and replacement support vehicles shop equipment computer hardware and software vehicle overhauls facility rehab/renovations and other miscellaneous equipment eligible under the 5339 BBF formula program. Purpose of Award: 5339 BBF funding will enable the Texas rural transit providers to keep their equipment facilities and fleet in a state of good repair for use in rural portions of Texas. Activities to be performed: Fleet replacement facility design MISC equipment purchases fleet expansions and other eligible 5339 program activities. Vehicles being replaced have or will meet useful life prior to disposition.Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to keep their capital items in a state of good repair by rehabilitating and replacing older equipment fleet and facilities.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit Texans living in rural areas rural communities transit riders and providers.Subrecipient Activities: The rural transit districts that receive these funds will use the funds to benefit the general public by ensuring the capital items they interact with are in a good state of repair and in condition to serve their purpose.STIP pages: Pages 1289 and 1292
column56: 20.526: BUSES AND BUS FACILITIES FORMULA, COMPETITIVE, AND LOW OR NO EMISSIONS PROGRAMS
column90: THE FUNDS SHALL BE USED FOR RURAL AREA TRANSIT CAPITAL PROJECTS IN THE SUBRECIPIENT'S SERVICE AREA THAT MAY REPLACE, REHABILITATE AND PURCHASE BUSES AND RELATED EQUIPMENT AND TO CONSTRUCT BUS-RELATED FACILITIES INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO TECHNOLOGICAL CHANGES OR INNOVATIONS TO MODIFY LOW OR NO EMISSION VEHICLES OR FACILITIES. TRANSIT PROVIDER SHALL COMPLY WITH ARTICLE 12: PROJECT RECORDS AND REPORTS AND ARTICLE 13 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT REQUIRING PROCUREMENT AND PROJECT MILESTONES / QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS. WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME PERIOD SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT OF FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.

column18: REGION 6 DOT FTA
column24: OFFICE OF BUDGET AND POLICY(TBP)
column55: This application is for 2022 formula funds to the Rural Areas of Texas: the Rural Transit Districts defined in the Texas Transportation Code Title 43 Chapter 458 and RTAP 5311(b) funds. The local match will be derived from local funds and TDCs.The Public Transportation Program managed by the Public Transportation Division (PTN) of Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT) was allocated 15000000 Transportation Development Credits (TDC) for distribution to eligible projects by the Texas Transportation Commission (commission) in Minute Order 116073 for state fiscal year 2022. The TDC letter dated 7/1/22 awards 800000 TDC to various agencies as match for capital projects funded with FY2022 federal Section 5311 Rural Area Grant Program funds. The funds will be used by transit agencies for general transportation services and capital purchases. Purpose of the Award: Funding for this 5311 Rural Areas grant will enable Texas transit districts to provide public transportation services in the rural areas of Texas. Funding will also allow transit providers to continue operating established transit routes and to add new services to aid communities.Activities to be performed: Operating assistance project administration vehicle preventive maintenance and repairs capital projects benefiting the rural area (e.g. vehicle procurement hardware and software solutions) state administration and training and technical assistance. Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to implement programs and services to create an environment of resilience for passengers employees and communities in rural areas of the state of Texas.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit and support mobility for rural areas communities transit riders and transit providers.Subrecipient Activities: Passenger transportation services to the general public using the most efficient combination of knowledge materials resources and technology. GENERAL FUNDS SUMMARYFY 2022 5311 Total Apportionment$60303948 Total 5311 funds:$50517853 Total 5311(b)(3) funds:$871180 Total 5311(f) funds:$8914915 State Administrative: $2100001 5311 funds applied for: $48417852 5311(b)(3) funds applied for: $871180 5311(f) funds applied for: $4872167Total funds applied for: $56261200Total 5311 amount to be applied for later: $0 Total 5311(b)(3) amount to be applied for later: $0 Total 5311(f) amount to be applied for later: $4042748 Total amount to be applied for later:$4042748
column56: 20.509: FORMULA GRANTS FOR RURAL AREAS AND TRIBAL TRANSIT PROGRAM
column90: AS PRESENTED IN GULF COAST TRANSIT DISTRICT'S(GCTD) FY22 GRANT APPLICATION, GCTD WILL PROVIDE PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION(FIXED ROUTE, ADA, AND DEMAND RESPONSE) FOR THE ENTIRE RURAL SERVICE AREA IN GALVESTON AND BRAZORIA COUNTIES (MINUS ANY POTENTIAL RURAL AREA IN THE CITY OF GALVESTON CITY LIMITS). TRANSIT PROVIDER SHALL COMPLY WITH ARTICLE 12: PROJECT RECORDS AND REPORTS AND ARTICLE 13 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT REQUIRING PROCUREMENT AND PROJECT MILESTONES / QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS. WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME PERIOD SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) SETS A FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL EVERY THREE YEARS FOR FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THE PROPOSED OVERALL GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.

column55: This application is to request Section 5311 funds apportioned to the State of Kansas (UZA: 200000) in the amount of $16803066. Purpose: This application is to request FFY2020-2022 Section 5311 funds apportioned to the State of Kansas in the amount of $16802066.Budget Funding:2020.25.18.81 $122951842021.25.18.81 $ 42569492022.2J.18.R7 $ 249933Total Federal Amount: $16802066 Local/State Funding: $13548754Total Grant Amount: $30350820The State will be providing 20 of the local match with State Highway Funds. The remaining 20% match will be provided by the agencies general funds mill levy or other local funds. No federal funding is being used as match. All agencies and CTDs are verified in SAM before any payments are made to them. Activities to be performed: Operating Intercity Bus - provide continued transportation for their passengers. Project Admin - Provide administrative support to the transit agencies in the state. RTAP - Provide training and technical assistance to transit agencies in the state. State Admin - Will be used to cover expenses incurred to administer FTA programs. Expected outcomes: The funding for all of these projects will provide a needed boost to the transit agencies and their passengers. The RTAP project will centralize information and streamline processes that can be used by all the agencies and their passengers. Intended beneficiaries: It is expected that all of the projects will benefit anyone that uses transportation services in Kansas. Subrecipient Activities: Operating Intercity - Continue day to day services and utilize the additional funding to assist with additional expenses. RTAP - The University of Kansas Center for Research will provide assistance to transit agencies to better serve their customers.*Pre-award authority was selected because KDOT will enter into agreements with the CTDS the Intercity Bus Providers and KU for the period starting 7-1-22 in the amount of $15843067. The first two months of expenses are anticipated prior to execution of the award.

column55: The purpose of the Weatherization Assistance Program is to increase the energy efficiency of dwellings owned and occupied by low-income persons, reduce their total residential expenditures, and improve their health and safety. The priority population for the Weatherization Assistance Program is persons who are particularly vulnerable such as the elderly, persons with disabilities, families with children, high residential energy users, and households with high-energy burden.

column31: RAIL AND PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION, VIRGINIA DEPARTMENT OF
column55: The Virginia Department of Rail and Public Transportation (VDRPT) is applying for FFY 2022 Section 5303 Metropolitan Planning Program (MPP) funds in the amount of $3408991 to support the funding of 14 Metropolitan Planning Organization (MPO) Unified Planning Work Programs (UPWPs) throughout the state.VDRPT is also applying for FFY 2022 Section 5304 funds in the amount of $765356 for statewide transportation planning. The Statewide Planning and Research (SPR) Work Program is attached in TrAMS and includes a description and funding amount for each of the plans and studies listed in the ALIs.The non-Federal share will be provided by the respective metropolitan areas across the Commonwealth and the Commonwealth of Virginia. The FTA has approved the Unified Planning Work Program (UPWP) for MWCOG on June 1 2022 the only large urbanized area and air quality non-attainment or maintenance area remaining in the Commonwealth of Virginia. Funding in this application reflects what has been approved in the MPOs UPWPs. Approval letters and UPWPs are attached in TrAMS under Application Documents.Purpose: The purpose of this award is to support the funding of 14 Metropolitan Planning Organizations (MPO) so that they can carry out the activities in their FY2023 Unified Planning Work Programs (UPWP). It is also to support the planning activities of the Commonwealth of Virginia.Activities to be performed: Funds will be used to cover the activities in the approved UPWPs of our 14 MPOs which include general planning and programming short and long-term planning TIP development transit studies human service transportation coordination and addressing safety and security issues. The Commonwealth will also help transit agencies develop Transit Development Programs (TDPs) and Transit Strategic Plans (TSPs). Studies and surveys to help improve transportation services in the Commonwealth will also be funded.Expected outcome: Funding ensures the MPOs and the Commonwealth are carrying out transportation planning activities to comply with Federal transportation planning regulations.Intended beneficiaries: All citizens of the Commonwealth of Virginia that rely on efficient safe and effective transportation services and facilities to get them where they need to go.Subrecipient activities: Funds will be given to the following MPOs to cover the activities in their approved UPWPs: Roanoke Valley MPO Hampton Roads TPO Richmond Regional TPO Tri-Cities MPO Washington D.C. MPO (Metropolitan Washington Council of Governments or MWCOG) Fredericksburg MPO Harrisonburg-Rockingham MPO Staunton-Augusta-Waynesboro MPO Charlottesville MPO Bristol MPO Kingsport MPO Winchester MPO Lynchburg MPO and New River Valley MPO. Funds will also be given to the Thomas Jefferson PDC to conduct a study their regional transit and the Roanoke Valley-Alleghany Regional Commission to conduct a survey to better understand the transportation usage in their region.

column55: This application is to request Section 5311 funds apportioned to the State of Kansas (UZA: 200000) in the amount of $16803066. Purpose: This application is to request FFY2020-2022 Section 5311 funds apportioned to the State of Kansas in the amount of $16802066.Budget Funding:2020.25.18.81 $122951842021.25.18.81 $ 42569492022.2J.18.R7 $ 249933Total Federal Amount: $16802066 Local/State Funding: $13548754Total Grant Amount: $30350820The State will be providing 20 of the local match with State Highway Funds. The remaining 20% match will be provided by the agencies general funds mill levy or other local funds. No federal funding is being used as match. All agencies and CTDs are verified in SAM before any payments are made to them. Activities to be performed: Operating Intercity Bus - provide continued transportation for their passengers. Project Admin - Provide administrative support to the transit agencies in the state. RTAP - Provide training and technical assistance to transit agencies in the state. State Admin - Will be used to cover expenses incurred to administer FTA programs. Expected outcomes: The funding for all of these projects will provide a needed boost to the transit agencies and their passengers. The RTAP project will centralize information and streamline processes that can be used by all the agencies and their passengers. Intended beneficiaries: It is expected that all of the projects will benefit anyone that uses transportation services in Kansas. Subrecipient Activities: Operating Intercity - Continue day to day services and utilize the additional funding to assist with additional expenses. RTAP - The University of Kansas Center for Research will provide assistance to transit agencies to better serve their customers.*Pre-award authority was selected because KDOT will enter into agreements with the CTDS the Intercity Bus Providers and KU for the period starting 7-1-22 in the amount of $15843067. The first two months of expenses are anticipated prior to execution of the award.

column55: Project Title: Wilkes University Pedestrian Safety Imp PH III :::: Project Description: Replacement of damaged sidewalks and curbs, construction of concrete crosswalks, and the installation of pedestrian lighting in the city of Wilkes-Barre, Luzerne County.  Wilkes University will construct new sidewalks, granite curbing, ADA ramps, pedestrian period lighting, street tree installation, tree lawn pavers on West South Street between East Main Street and South Franklin Street; South Franklin Street between West South Street and West Ross Street. there will also be a raised midblock concrete crosswalk on Formalin Street with overhead flashing signal and signage.   The lighting is in a period or historic style. The proposed lights utilize the existing Sternberg standards which are typical to downtown Wilkes Barre.   The new walks are made up of both concrete sidewalk and unit pavers. The walk and pavers are in same style as the recently completed PennDOT TAP improvements on West South Street and South Franklin Street. The pavers define the tree lawn along the curb. The new walks will be replacing the deteriorated paver walks that are there now.

column55: The West Virginia Department of Transportation Division of Public Transit (WVDOT) Section is applying for FFY 2022 Section 5310 Enhanced Mobility of Seniors and Individuals with Disabilities Program funds in the amount of $2830061 ($1307284 for Rural Apportionment and $1522777 for Small Urban Apportionment) to support the State DOTs FFY 2022 Program of Projects (POP). The WVDOT is applying for funding for both rural and small urban areas for the following projects:Rural projects include the following:Purchase of Eight (8) replacement vansPurchase of Four (4) expansion vans3rd party contracted servicesSmall Urban projects include the following:State Program Administration funds3rd party contracted servicesPurchase of One (1) replacement SUVPurchase of Eight (8) replacement vansPurchase of One (1) expansion vanAll projects in the current POP are in Category A status and are for traditional Section 5310 projects and thus meet the requirement to spend 55% of the apportionment toward traditional capital projects.The States FY 2022 Section 5310 POP is attached to this grant under Application Documents. The total number of recipients funded in the POP is twelve (12) private non-profits in the small urbans areas and twenty (20) private non-profits in the rural areas. The projects included in this application were derived from updated coordinated public transit - human services transportation plans developed by various West Virginia Planning and Development Councils located throughout the State. In addition each plan has been approved by the West Virginia Division of Public Transit.The State Management Plan for the State FY 2022 Section 5310 Program was approved by FTA on March 7 2019.Purpose: The purpose of this award is to provide funding to eligible recipients to meet the transportation needs of seniors and individuals with disabilities throughout West Virginia.Activities to be Performed: This application will fund the purchase of replacement and expansion vans as well as state program admin funds and funding for third party contracting.Expected Outcomes: Continued safe and effective operation of transit services for rural areas of West Virginia. Intended Beneficiaries: WVDOT transit agencies and citizens in the rural and non-urbanized areas of the state. Subrecipient Activities: The following twelve (12) private non-profits in the small urbans areas and twenty (20) private non-profits in the rural areas of West Virginia.Small UrbanEastern Panhandle TransitBerkeley Senior Services Hansford Senior ServicesHancock County Sr. ServicesKanawha Valley Senior Services Northwood Health SystemsPutnam Aging ProgramRaleigh County Community Action Association Family Service Upper Ohio ValleyGood Shepherd InterfaithMonongalia County UrbanWood County Senior Citizens AssociationRural Braxton County Senior Citizens CenterChristian Help Inc. of Mingo CountyCommunity Action of South Eastern West VirginiaCouncil of Senior Citizens of Gilmer CountyCouncil on Aging (Wyoming)Harrison County Senior Citizens Center Inc.Lewis County Senior Citizens CenterMcDowell County Commission on AgingPocahontas County Senior CitizensRitchie County Integrated Family ServicesSenior Life Services of Morgan CountySummers County Council on AgingWirt County Committee on AgingCentral WV Community Action Integrated Resources Inc. column24: REGION 6 (FUNDING OFFICE)
column55: Description:This agreement is to fund the State of Texas' Water Quality Management Planning program to improve impaired water and protect unimpaired waters across the state by conducting planning that informs and supports implementation of Clean Water Act programs. In accordance with Clean Water Act section 205(j)(3), unless a waiver request is approved by EPA, the recipient will jointly develop workplans with and provide at least 40% of this award to regional or interstate watershed management planning agencies.   This agreement is supported by funding provided under the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act (IIJA) (PL 117-58).  Activities:The activities to be performed by the Coastal Bend and Bays Estuary Program (CBBEP) include the following water quality management planning activities: continuation of the Nueces Delta environmental monitoring, Baffin Bay watershed modeling, nutrient sampling in Petronila Creek, installation of Mission River water quality station, seagrass monitoring in Corpus Christi and Upper Laguna Madre, and a Coastal Bend Regional Wastewater feasibility study.  The following is more detail for the above projects: Nueces Delta Environmental Monitoring - CBBEP The purpose of this project is for the contractor to continue maintaining one current real-time salinity monitoring station on the Rincon Bayou. The salinity sensor will be used to trace freshwater inflows from freshwater pumping events via the Rincon Bayou Pipeline from the Nueces River and will report water temperature, conductivity, and salinity every 30 minutes. Data from this salinity station is being used to aid in the development of a management strategies for the Rincon Bayou Pipeline. The Center for Coastal Studies, the Harte Research Institute (HRI) at Texas AandM University Corpus Christi (TAMUCC) use the salinity data provided from the salinity stations to support various projects involving sampling in the Nueces Delta. Data from these salinity stations are also utilized by the University of Texas (UT) at Austin and the UT Marine Science Institute in Port Aransas to support various modeling projects which are investigating the interactions between water in sediment and tidal creeks in the Nueces Delta. The Nueces Delta Hydrodynamic Model being conducted by UT also utilized the tide gauge data in the western Nueces Bay. Several TWDB funded projects have and currently are utilizing the available data. The Nueces Delta Environmental Monitoring Project supports the Program Elements 11 a., 11 b., 11 g., 11 h., and 11 i. of the March 31, 1994 106/604(b) Guidance Memo issued by EPA Headquarters. This established monitoring effort supports the 1995 Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (then Texas Natural Resources Conservation Commission) Agreed Order which established the protocols for the required freshwater releases to the Nueces Estuary. By supporting ongoing operation of fixed salinity gauge and meteorological monitoring stations in the Nueces Delta as well as a sea level monitoring station in Nueces Bay, this project monitors the effectiveness of freshwater inflows to the Nueces Estuary and provides data necessary for adaptive management recommendations made by the Nueces Estuary Advisory Council (NEAC). The water level monitoring station also supports National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's (NOAA) Corpus Christi PORTSreg; monitoring network, a decision support tool that improves the safety and efficiency of maritime commerce and coastal resource management through the integration of real-time environmental observations. Data generated by this project is near real-time and is made publicly available via the NOAA Tides and Currents and the Texas AandM University - Conrad Blucher Institute websites and annual reports are published on the CBBEP website.   Baffin Bay Watershed Model - CBBEP The purpose of this project is to design and fabricate a 3'x7' custom plastic relief mode

column90: THE PERFORMING PARTY'S WORK IN THE LOWER RIO GRANDE VALLEY REGION WILL FOCUS ON FOUR OBJECTIVES: 1) PROJECT ADMINISTRATION, 2) COORDINATION WITH CLEAN WATER STATE REVOLVING FUND (CWSRF) LOAN PROJECTS, 3) DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF WATER QUALITY EDUCATION AND OUTREACH PROGRAMS, AND 4) PROVIDING EDUCATIONAL OUTREACH MATERIALS TO THE PUBLIC TO INCREASE THEIR AWARENESS OF LOCAL WATER QUALITY ISSUES.

column18: REGION 6 DOT FTA
column24: OFFICE OF BUDGET AND POLICY(TBP)
column55: This application is for 2022 formula funds to the Rural Areas of Texas: the Rural Transit Districts defined in the Texas Transportation Code Title 43 Chapter 458 and RTAP 5311(b) funds. The local match will be derived from local funds and TDCs.The Public Transportation Program managed by the Public Transportation Division (PTN) of Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT) was allocated 15000000 Transportation Development Credits (TDC) for distribution to eligible projects by the Texas Transportation Commission (commission) in Minute Order 116073 for state fiscal year 2022. The TDC letter dated 7/1/22 awards 800000 TDC to various agencies as match for capital projects funded with FY2022 federal Section 5311 Rural Area Grant Program funds. The funds will be used by transit agencies for general transportation services and capital purchases. Purpose of the Award: Funding for this 5311 Rural Areas grant will enable Texas transit districts to provide public transportation services in the rural areas of Texas. Funding will also allow transit providers to continue operating established transit routes and to add new services to aid communities.Activities to be performed: Operating assistance project administration vehicle preventive maintenance and repairs capital projects benefiting the rural area (e.g. vehicle procurement hardware and software solutions) state administration and training and technical assistance. Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to implement programs and services to create an environment of resilience for passengers employees and communities in rural areas of the state of Texas.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit and support mobility for rural areas communities transit riders and transit providers.Subrecipient Activities: Passenger transportation services to the general public using the most efficient combination of knowledge materials resources and technology. GENERAL FUNDS SUMMARYFY 2022 5311 Total Apportionment$60303948 Total 5311 funds:$50517853 Total 5311(b)(3) funds:$871180 Total 5311(f) funds:$8914915 State Administrative: $2100001 5311 funds applied for: $48417852 5311(b)(3) funds applied for: $871180 5311(f) funds applied for: $4872167Total funds applied for: $56261200Total 5311 amount to be applied for later: $0 Total 5311(b)(3) amount to be applied for later: $0 Total 5311(f) amount to be applied for later: $4042748 Total amount to be applied for later:$4042748
column56: 20.509: FORMULA GRANTS FOR RURAL AREAS AND TRIBAL TRANSIT PROGRAM
column67: LOWER RIO GRANDE VALLEY DEVELOPMENT COUNCIL CORPORATION, INC.
column81: U.S. LOCAL GOVERNMENT,MUNICIPALITY,COUNTY,CITY,PLANNING COMMISSION,TRANSIT AUTHORITY,COUNCIL OF GOVERNMENTS,INTER-MUNICIPAL
column90: AS PRESENTED IN LOWER RIO GRANDE VALLEY DEVELOPMENT COUNCIL'S (LRGVDC) FY22 GRANT APPLICATION, LRGVDC WILL PROVIDE PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION THROUGHOUT THE RURAL TRANSIT DISTRICT SERVICE AREA. LRGVDC WILL PROVIDE DEMAND RESPONSE SERVICE IN THE RURAL AREAS OF CAMERON, HIDALGO, STARR, WILLACY, AND ZAPATA COUNTIES. LRGVDC WILL ALSO PROVIDE DEVIATED FIXED ROUTE SERVICE IN STAR AND ZAPATA COUNTIES AND BETWEEN THE RURAL SERVICE AREA AND THE URBANIZED AREAS OF MCALLEN, BROWNSVILLE, AND HARLINGEN. ONLY EXPENDITURES INCURRED TO RUN THE RURAL PORTION OF THE DEVIATED FIXED ROUTE SERVICE WILL BE ELIGIBLE FOR REIMBURSEMENT. TRANSIT PROVIDER SHALL COMPLY WITH ARTICLE 12: PROJECT RECORDS AND REPORTS AND ARTICLE 13 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT REQUIRING PROCUREMENT AND PROJECT MILESTONES / QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS. WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME PERIOD SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) SETS A FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL EVERY THREE YEARS FOR FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THE PROPOSED OVERALL GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.

column18: REGION 6 DOT FTA

column28: 0001: URBANIZED AREA PROGRAMS;0010: SENIORS AND PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES;0017: IIJA ACT, 2021
column55: This application is for 2022 formula funds for the 5310 demographics statewide: as defined in the Texas Transportation Code Title 43 Chapter 461. These funds will be recommended for award statewide to 39 small urban and rural transit districts private non-profit agencies governmental entities and local public agencies to the Texas Transportation Commission on July 12 2022. TDC letter dated 6/24/2022 attached.The funds will be used by 5310 providers for transportation services and capital purchases that serve Seniors and Individuals with disabilities to overcome transportation barriers.Purpose of the Award: Funding for section 5310 grant will enable Texas transit districts to provide public transportation services in both the rural and small urban areas of Texas. Funding will allow transit providers to continue operating established transit services and add new or expanded service to aid the growing 5310 population. Activities to be performed: Operating assistance project administration vehicle preventive maintenance and repairs capital projects benefiting the rural and small urban area (e.g. vehicle procurement hardware and software solutions state administration and mobility management 3rd Party contract services and technical assistance.) Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to implement 5310 programs and services to create an environment of resilience for passengers employees and communities in both rural and small urban areas of the state of Texas Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit seniors and individuals with disabilities by supporting mobility for rural and small urban areas communities transit riders and transit providers. Texas has the largest number of individuals with disabilities of all the states and 17% of the senior population lives in the 177 rural counties in Texas. Over half of seniors in Texas have one or more disabilities. Subrecipient Activities: 5310 Passenger transportation services to the public using the most efficient combination of knowledge materials resources and technology. The minimum of 55 percent of funding for traditional 5310 program type projects has been met. column56: 20.513: ENHANCED MOBILITY OF SENIORS AND INDIVIDUALS WITH DISABILITIES
column67: LOWER RIO GRANDE VALLEY DEVELOPMENT COUNCIL CORPORATION, INC.
column81: U.S. LOCAL GOVERNMENT,MUNICIPALITY,COUNTY,CITY,PLANNING COMMISSION,TRANSIT AUTHORITY,COUNCIL OF GOVERNMENTS,INTER-MUNICIPAL
column90: LOWER RIO GRANDE VALLEY DEVELOPMENT COUNCIL WILL PROVIDE EXISTING 5310 SERVICE AND UTILIZING THE PROCUREMENT OF TWO TYPE 2 VEHICLES (TO INCLUDE PRE-WIRE FOR FAREBOX, TWO-WAY RADIO AND MOBILE ROUTERS, ON BOARD CAMERA SYSTEM, DESTINATION SIGNS, FAREBOX, BIKE RACK AND VEHICLE WRAP) FOR EXPANSION MICROTRANSIT SERVICE IN RURAL AND SMALL URBAN AREAS. MOBILITY MANAGEMENT WILL PROVIDE TRANSIT MOBILITY OPTIONS AND SERVICES FOR SENIORS AND PEOPLE WITH DISABILITIES. WORKING CLOSELY WITH VALLEY METRO, AS WELL AS A NETWORK OF OTHER AGENCIES AND NONPROFITS, THIS POSITION WILL CONNECT TRANSIT OPERATIONS WITH CUSTOMER RESOURCES IN A WAY THAT WILL IMPROVE RELATIONS BETWEEN TARGETED GROUPS AND PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION. THE MOBILITY MANAGER WILL BE KNOWLEDGEABLE ABOUT ALL TRANSIT SYSTEMS IN THE AREA AND WILL SPEND 100% OF HIS/HER TIME MEETING WITH CLIENTS, PLANNING TRIPS, COMMUNICATING INFORMATION, MEETING WITH AGENCY STAFF, ATTENDING COMMUNITY MEETINGS, CONDUCTING OUTREACH AND COMMUNITY EDUCATION, AND PERFORMING ALL THE OTHER TASKS NECESSARY TO IMPROVE MOBILITY IN SMALL URBAN AND RURAL AREAS. TRANSIT PROVIDER SHALL COMPLY WITH ARTICLE 12: PROJECT RECORDS AND REPORTS AND ARTICLE 13 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT REQUIRING PROCUREMENT AND PROJECT MILESTONES / QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS. WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. Â  PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). Â  TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) SETS A FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL EVERY THREE YEARS FOR FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THE OVERALL GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT

column55: Texas Department of Transportation 5339 BBF formula apportionments FY 2021 and FY 2022. These funds were distributed to the 36 subrecipients that represent Texas rural transit districts.RURAL TOTAL $7500000 TDC 1279516 July 6 2022 TDC letter awarding 1400000 TDCs attached.FY21 $3500000FY22 $4000000 The funds will be used by 5339 eligible subrecipients to support capital projects such as the purchase of new and replacement fleet new and replacement support vehicles shop equipment computer hardware and software vehicle overhauls facility rehab/renovations and other miscellaneous equipment eligible under the 5339 BBF formula program. Purpose of Award: 5339 BBF funding will enable the Texas rural transit providers to keep their equipment facilities and fleet in a state of good repair for use in rural portions of Texas. Activities to be performed: Fleet replacement facility design MISC equipment purchases fleet expansions and other eligible 5339 program activities. Vehicles being replaced have or will meet useful life prior to disposition.Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to keep their capital items in a state of good repair by rehabilitating and replacing older equipment fleet and facilities.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit Texans living in rural areas rural communities transit riders and providers.Subrecipient Activities: The rural transit districts that receive these funds will use the funds to benefit the general public by ensuring the capital items they interact with are in a good state of repair and in condition to serve their purpose.STIP pages: Pages 1289 and 1292

column55: The West Virginia Department of Transportation Division of Public Transit (WVDOT) Section is applying for FFY 2022 Section 5310 Enhanced Mobility of Seniors and Individuals with Disabilities Program funds in the amount of $2830061 ($1307284 for Rural Apportionment and $1522777 for Small Urban Apportionment) to support the State DOTs FFY 2022 Program of Projects (POP). The WVDOT is applying for funding for both rural and small urban areas for the following projects:Rural projects include the following:Purchase of Eight (8) replacement vansPurchase of Four (4) expansion vans3rd party contracted servicesSmall Urban projects include the following:State Program Administration funds3rd party contracted servicesPurchase of One (1) replacement SUVPurchase of Eight (8) replacement vansPurchase of One (1) expansion vanAll projects in the current POP are in Category A status and are for traditional Section 5310 projects and thus meet the requirement to spend 55% of the apportionment toward traditional capital projects.The States FY 2022 Section 5310 POP is attached to this grant under Application Documents. The total number of recipients funded in the POP is twelve (12) private non-profits in the small urbans areas and twenty (20) private non-profits in the rural areas. The projects included in this application were derived from updated coordinated public transit - human services transportation plans developed by various West Virginia Planning and Development Councils located throughout the State. In addition each plan has been approved by the West Virginia Division of Public Transit.The State Management Plan for the State FY 2022 Section 5310 Program was approved by FTA on March 7 2019.Purpose: The purpose of this award is to provide funding to eligible recipients to meet the transportation needs of seniors and individuals with disabilities throughout West Virginia.Activities to be Performed: This application will fund the purchase of replacement and expansion vans as well as state program admin funds and funding for third party contracting.Expected Outcomes: Continued safe and effective operation of transit services for rural areas of West Virginia. Intended Beneficiaries: WVDOT transit agencies and citizens in the rural and non-urbanized areas of the state. Subrecipient Activities: The following twelve (12) private non-profits in the small urbans areas and twenty (20) private non-profits in the rural areas of West Virginia.Small UrbanEastern Panhandle TransitBerkeley Senior Services Hansford Senior ServicesHancock County Sr. ServicesKanawha Valley Senior Services Northwood Health SystemsPutnam Aging ProgramRaleigh County Community Action Association Family Service Upper Ohio ValleyGood Shepherd InterfaithMonongalia County UrbanWood County Senior Citizens AssociationRural Braxton County Senior Citizens CenterChristian Help Inc. of Mingo CountyCommunity Action of South Eastern West VirginiaCouncil of Senior Citizens of Gilmer CountyCouncil on Aging (Wyoming)Harrison County Senior Citizens Center Inc.Lewis County Senior Citizens CenterMcDowell County Commission on AgingPocahontas County Senior CitizensRitchie County Integrated Family ServicesSenior Life Services of Morgan CountySummers County Council on AgingWirt County Committee on AgingCentral WV Community Action Integrated Resources Inc. Logan-Mingo Area Mental HealthMarion CountyTaylor County Senior Citizens IncWebster County Senior CitizensYouth Health Services

column55: Texas Department of Transportation 5339 BBF formula apportionments FY 2021 and FY 2022. These funds were distributed to the 36 subrecipients that represent Texas rural transit districts.RURAL TOTAL $7500000 TDC 1279516 July 6 2022 TDC letter awarding 1400000 TDCs attached.FY21 $3500000FY22 $4000000 The funds will be used by 5339 eligible subrecipients to support capital projects such as the purchase of new and replacement fleet new and replacement support vehicles shop equipment computer hardware and software vehicle overhauls facility rehab/renovations and other miscellaneous equipment eligible under the 5339 BBF formula program. Purpose of Award: 5339 BBF funding will enable the Texas rural transit providers to keep their equipment facilities and fleet in a state of good repair for use in rural portions of Texas. Activities to be performed: Fleet replacement facility design MISC equipment purchases fleet expansions and other eligible 5339 program activities. Vehicles being replaced have or will meet useful life prior to disposition.Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to keep their capital items in a state of good repair by rehabilitating and replacing older equipment fleet and facilities.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit Texans living in rural areas rural communities transit riders and providers.Subrecipient Activities: The rural transit districts that receive these funds will use the funds to benefit the general public by ensuring the capital items they interact with are in a good state of repair and in condition to serve their purpose.STIP pages: Pages 1289 and 1292

column90: THE FUNDS SHALL BE USED FOR RURAL AREA TRANSIT CAPITAL PROJECTS IN THE SUBRECIPIENT'S SERVICE AREA THAT MAY REPLACE, REHABILITATE AND PURCHASE BUSES AND RELATED EQUIPMENT AND TO CONSTRUCT BUS-RELATED FACILITIES INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO TECHNOLOGICAL CHANGES OR INNOVATIONS TO MODIFY LOW OR NO EMISSION VEHICLES OR FACILITIES. TRANSIT PROVIDER SHALL COMPLY WITH ARTICLE 12: PROJECT RECORDS AND REPORTS AND ARTICLE 13 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT REQUIRING PROCUREMENT AND PROJECT MILESTONES / QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS. WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME PERIOD SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT OF FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.

column55: This application is for 2022 formula funds to the Rural Areas of Texas: the Rural Transit Districts defined in the Texas Transportation Code Title 43 Chapter 458 and RTAP 5311(b) funds. The local match will be derived from local funds and TDCs.The Public Transportation Program managed by the Public Transportation Division (PTN) of Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT) was allocated 15000000 Transportation Development Credits (TDC) for distribution to eligible projects by the Texas Transportation Commission (commission) in Minute Order 116073 for state fiscal year 2022. The TDC letter dated 7/1/22 awards 800000 TDC to various agencies as match for capital projects funded with FY2022 federal Section 5311 Rural Area Grant Program funds. The funds will be used by transit agencies for general transportation services and capital purchases. Purpose of the Award: Funding for this 5311 Rural Areas grant will enable Texas transit districts to provide public transportation services in the rural areas of Texas. Funding will also allow transit providers to continue operating established transit routes and to add new services to aid communities.Activities to be performed: Operating assistance project administration vehicle preventive maintenance and repairs capital projects benefiting the rural area (e.g. vehicle procurement hardware and software solutions) state administration and training and technical assistance. Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to implement programs and services to create an environment of resilience for passengers employees and communities in rural areas of the state of Texas.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit and support mobility for rural areas communities transit riders and transit providers.Subrecipient Activities: Passenger transportation services to the general public using the most efficient combination of knowledge materials resources and technology. GENERAL FUNDS SUMMARYFY 2022 5311 Total Apportionment$60303948 Total 5311 funds:$50517853 Total 5311(b)(3) funds:$871180 Total 5311(f) funds:$8914915 State Administrative: $2100001 5311 funds applied for: $48417852 5311(b)(3) funds applied for: $871180 5311(f) funds applied for: $4872167Total funds applied for: $56261200Total 5311 amount to be applied for later: $0 Total 5311(b)(3) amount to be applied for later: $0 Total 5311(f) amount to be applied for later: $4042748 Total amount to be applied for later:$4042748

column90: AS PRESENTED IN CONCHO VALLEY TRANSIT DISTRICT'S (CVTD) FY22 GRANT APPLICATION, CVTD WILL PROVIDE PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION THROUGHOUT THE RURAL TRANSIT DISTRICT SERVICE AREA. CVTD WILL PROVIDE DEMAND RESPONSE SERVICE IN THE RURAL AREAS OF COKE, CONCHO, CROCKETT, IRION, KIMBLE, MCCULLOCH, MENARD, REAGAN, SCHLEICHER, SUTTON, STERLING AND TOM GREEN COUNTIES; OUT OF COUNTY SERVICE WILL BE PROVIDED ON A FIXED SCHEDULE. TRANSIT PROVIDER SHALL COMPLY WITH ARTICLE 12: PROJECT RECORDS AND REPORTS AND ARTICLE 13 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT REQUIRING PROCUREMENT AND PROJECT MILESTONES / QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS. WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME PERIOD SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) SETS A FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL EVERY THREE YEARS FOR FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THE PROPOSED OVERALL GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.

column55: This application is to request Section 5311 funds apportioned to the State of Kansas (UZA: 200000) in the amount of $16803066. Purpose: This application is to request FFY2020-2022 Section 5311 funds apportioned to the State of Kansas in the amount of $16802066.Budget Funding:2020.25.18.81 $122951842021.25.18.81 $ 42569492022.2J.18.R7 $ 249933Total Federal Amount: $16802066 Local/State Funding: $13548754Total Grant Amount: $30350820The State will be providing 20 of the local match with State Highway Funds. The remaining 20% match will be provided by the agencies general funds mill levy or other local funds. No federal funding is being used as match. All agencies and CTDs are verified in SAM before any payments are made to them. Activities to be performed: Operating Intercity Bus - provide continued transportation for their passengers. Project Admin - Provide administrative support to the transit agencies in the state. RTAP - Provide training and technical assistance to transit agencies in the state. State Admin - Will be used to cover expenses incurred to administer FTA programs. Expected outcomes: The funding for all of these projects will provide a needed boost to the transit agencies and their passengers. The RTAP project will centralize information and streamline processes that can be used by all the agencies and their passengers. Intended beneficiaries: It is expected that all of the projects will benefit anyone that uses transportation services in Kansas. Subrecipient Activities: Operating Intercity - Continue day to day services and utilize the additional funding to assist with additional expenses. RTAP - The University of Kansas Center for Research will provide assistance to transit agencies to better serve their customers.*Pre-award authority was selected because KDOT will enter into agreements with the CTDS the Intercity Bus Providers and KU for the period starting 7-1-22 in the amount of $15843067. The first two months of expenses are anticipated prior to execution of the award.

column55: Funding for all projects included in this grant application is provided by the following apportionment years and Urbanized areas (UZAs).Section 5307 FFY 2022 Thousand Oaks (UZA #61440): $1459217Section 5307 FFY 2022 Oxnard (UZA #60860): $3626823Section 5307 FFY 2021 Camarillo (UZA #063680): $701522Section 5307 FFY 2022 Camarillo (UZA #063680): $759185Section 5307 FFY 2022 Simi Valley (#062710): $272551Overall grant fundingTotal Federal Funds: $6819298Total Local Match: $3834747 (Transportation Development Act [state sales tax for transportation] city general funds)Total Project Cost: $10654045A portion of the local share is provided by Transportation Development Credits. Because Transportation Development Credits do not allocate actual money toward project expenses an increased federal share is reflected where the credits are applied.VCTC is hereby submitting this grant application in support of the following projects for capital planning and operations:1) Capital Projects for VCTC and Subrecipients FY 2022 FundsThe grant applies $1940325 in FY 22 Section 5307 funds for preventive maintenance ADA service capital contracting cost capital infrastructure mobility management and Jobs Access and Reverse Commute with further details provided in the Project Description.2) Planning Projects for VCTC and CamarilloThe grant applies $1199000 in FY 22 Section 5307 funds for planning with further details provided in the Project Description.3) Operating Assistance for VCTC and Subrecipients FY 2022 FundsThe grant applies $2858451 in FY 22 Section 5307 funds for operating assistance with further details provided in the Project Description.4) Camarillo Preventive Maintenance FY 2021 FundsThe grant applies $604800 in FY 21 Section 5307 funds for preventive maintenance with further details provided in the Project Description.5) Camarillo Operating Assistance FY 2021 FundsThe grant applies $96722 in FY 21 Section 5307 funds for operating assistance with further details provided in the Project Description.Purpose: The purpose of this award is to provide $2545125 to VCTC and subrecipients for for preventive maintenance ADA service capital contracting cost mobility management capital infrastructure and Jobs Access Reverse Commute (JARC); $1199000 to VCTC and Camarillo for planning; and $2955173 to VCTC and Subrecipients for operating assistance.Activities to be performed: Funds will be used to cover eligible operating expenses such as driver salaries fuel maintenance on-demand rideshare transit vehicle leases etc. to continue transit operations.Expected outcomes: Funding will permit VCTC to continue to provide operations that would otherwise have to be cut due to lack of funding.Intended beneficiaries: VCTC and the riders that rely on its services will benefit from continued service permitting workers to get to work and riders to get to essential services.Subrecipients: The following are providers of transit service operators: MV Transportation First Transit and RATP-DEV.Suballocation Letter:Recipient organization is the Designated Recipient and can apply for and receive these apportioned funds. This Application is consistent with the suballocation identified in the Split Letter dated April 11 2022 and attached to this application. In keeping with the IIJA set aside for safety for areas over 200000 this grant will spend a minimum of $38145.30 representing 0.0075% of the Oxnard and Thousand Oaks funds for keeping vehicles safe and safety maintenance as part of ALI 11.7A.00 VCTC Intercity Preventive Maintenance.

column18: REGION 3 DOT FTA
column24: OFFICE OF BUDGET AND POLICY(TBP)
column31: RAIL AND PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION, VIRGINIA DEPARTMENT OF
column55: The Virginia Department of Rail and Public Transportation (VDRPT) is applying for FFY 2022 Section 5303 Metropolitan Planning Program (MPP) funds in the amount of $3408991 to support the funding of 14 Metropolitan Planning Organization (MPO) Unified Planning Work Programs (UPWPs) throughout the state.VDRPT is also applying for FFY 2022 Section 5304 funds in the amount of $765356 for statewide transportation planning. The Statewide Planning and Research (SPR) Work Program is attached in TrAMS and includes a description and funding amount for each of the plans and studies listed in the ALIs.The non-Federal share will be provided by the respective metropolitan areas across the Commonwealth and the Commonwealth of Virginia. The FTA has approved the Unified Planning Work Program (UPWP) for MWCOG on June 1 2022 the only large urbanized area and air quality non-attainment or maintenance area remaining in the Commonwealth of Virginia. Funding in this application reflects what has been approved in the MPOs UPWPs. Approval letters and UPWPs are attached in TrAMS under Application Documents.Purpose: The purpose of this award is to support the funding of 14 Metropolitan Planning Organizations (MPO) so that they can carry out the activities in their FY2023 Unified Planning Work Programs (UPWP). It is also to support the planning activities of the Commonwealth of Virginia.Activities to be performed: Funds will be used to cover the activities in the approved UPWPs of our 14 MPOs which include general planning and programming short and long-term planning TIP development transit studies human service transportation coordination and addressing safety and security issues. The Commonwealth will also help transit agencies develop Transit Development Programs (TDPs) and Transit Strategic Plans (TSPs). Studies and surveys to help improve transportation services in the Commonwealth will also be funded.Expected outcome: Funding ensures the MPOs and the Commonwealth are carrying out transportation planning activities to comply with Federal transportation planning regulations.Intended beneficiaries: All citizens of the Commonwealth of Virginia that rely on efficient safe and effective transportation services and facilities to get them where they need to go.Subrecipient activities: Funds will be given to the following MPOs to cover the activities in their approved UPWPs: Roanoke Valley MPO Hampton Roads TPO Richmond Regional TPO Tri-Cities MPO Washington D.C. MPO (Metropolitan Washington Council of Governments or MWCOG) Fredericksburg MPO Harrisonburg-Rockingham MPO Staunton-Augusta-Waynesboro MPO Charlottesville MPO Bristol MPO Kingsport MPO Winchester MPO Lynchburg MPO and New River Valley MPO. Funds will also be given to the Thomas Jefferson PDC to conduct a study their regional transit and the Roanoke Valley-Alleghany Regional Commission to conduct a survey to better understand the transportation usage in their region.
column56: 20.505: METROPOLITAN TRANSPORTATION PLANNING AND STATE AND NON-METROPOLITAN PLANNING AND RESEARCH
column90: METROPOLITAN TRANSPORTATION PLANNING AND STATE AND NON-METROPOLITAN PLANNING AND RESEARCH SUBAWARD FOR CENTRAL VIRGINIA PLANNING DISTRICT COMMISSION (CVPDC).

column55: Texas Department of Transportation 5339 BBF formula apportionments FY 2021 and FY 2022. These funds were distributed to the 36 subrecipients that represent Texas rural transit districts.RURAL TOTAL $7500000 TDC 1279516 July 6 2022 TDC letter awarding 1400000 TDCs attached.FY21 $3500000FY22 $4000000 The funds will be used by 5339 eligible subrecipients to support capital projects such as the purchase of new and replacement fleet new and replacement support vehicles shop equipment computer hardware and software vehicle overhauls facility rehab/renovations and other miscellaneous equipment eligible under the 5339 BBF formula program. Purpose of Award: 5339 BBF funding will enable the Texas rural transit providers to keep their equipment facilities and fleet in a state of good repair for use in rural portions of Texas. Activities to be performed: Fleet replacement facility design MISC equipment purchases fleet expansions and other eligible 5339 program activities. Vehicles being replaced have or will meet useful life prior to disposition.Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to keep their capital items in a state of good repair by rehabilitating and replacing older equipment fleet and facilities.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit Texans living in rural areas rural communities transit riders and providers.Subrecipient Activities: The rural transit districts that receive these funds will use the funds to benefit the general public by ensuring the capital items they interact with are in a good state of repair and in condition to serve their purpose.STIP pages: Pages 1289 and 1292
column56: 20.526: BUSES AND BUS FACILITIES FORMULA, COMPETITIVE, AND LOW OR NO EMISSIONS PROGRAMS
column90: THE FUNDS SHALL BE USED FOR RURAL AREA TRANSIT CAPITAL PROJECTS IN THE SUBRECIPIENT'S SERVICE AREA THAT MAY REPLACE, REHABILITATE AND PURCHASE BUSES AND RELATED EQUIPMENT AND TO CONSTRUCT BUS-RELATED FACILITIES INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO TECHNOLOGICAL CHANGES OR INNOVATIONS TO MODIFY LOW OR NO EMISSION VEHICLES OR FACILITIES. TRANSIT PROVIDER SHALL COMPLY WITH ARTICLE 12: PROJECT RECORDS AND REPORTS AND ARTICLE 13 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT REQUIRING PROCUREMENT AND PROJECT MILESTONES / QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS. WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME PERIOD SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT OF FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.

column55: This application is for 2022 formula funds to the Rural Areas of Texas: the Rural Transit Districts defined in the Texas Transportation Code Title 43 Chapter 458 and RTAP 5311(b) funds. The local match will be derived from local funds and TDCs.The Public Transportation Program managed by the Public Transportation Division (PTN) of Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT) was allocated 15000000 Transportation Development Credits (TDC) for distribution to eligible projects by the Texas Transportation Commission (commission) in Minute Order 116073 for state fiscal year 2022. The TDC letter dated 7/1/22 awards 800000 TDC to various agencies as match for capital projects funded with FY2022 federal Section 5311 Rural Area Grant Program funds. The funds will be used by transit agencies for general transportation services and capital purchases. Purpose of the Award: Funding for this 5311 Rural Areas grant will enable Texas transit districts to provide public transportation services in the rural areas of Texas. Funding will also allow transit providers to continue operating established transit routes and to add new services to aid communities.Activities to be performed: Operating assistance project administration vehicle preventive maintenance and repairs capital projects benefiting the rural area (e.g. vehicle procurement hardware and software solutions) state administration and training and technical assistance. Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to implement programs and services to create an environment of resilience for passengers employees and communities in rural areas of the state of Texas.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit and support mobility for rural areas communities transit riders and transit providers.Subrecipient Activities: Passenger transportation services to the general public using the most efficient combination of knowledge materials resources and technology. PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME PERIOD SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). column55: This application is for 2022 formula funds for the 5310 demographics statewide: as defined in the Texas Transportation Code Title 43 Chapter 461. These funds will be recommended for award statewide to 39 small urban and rural transit districts private non-profit agencies governmental entities and local public agencies to the Texas Transportation Commission on July 12 2022. TDC letter dated 6/24/2022 attached.The funds will be used by 5310 providers for transportation services and capital purchases that serve Seniors and Individuals with disabilities to overcome transportation barriers.Purpose of the Award: Funding for section 5310 grant will enable Texas transit districts to provide public transportation services in both the rural and small urban areas of Texas. Funding will allow transit providers to continue operating established transit services and add new or expanded service to aid the growing 5310 population. Activities to be performed: Operating assistance project administration vehicle preventive maintenance and repairs capital projects benefiting the rural and small urban area (e.g. vehicle procurement hardware and software solutions state administration and mobility management 3rd Party contract services and technical assistance.) Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to implement 5310 programs and services to create an environment of resilience for passengers employees and communities in both rural and small urban areas of the state of Texas Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit seniors and individuals with disabilities by supporting mobility for rural and small urban areas communities transit riders and transit providers. Texas has the largest number of individuals with disabilities of all the states and 17% of the senior population lives in the 177 rural counties in Texas. Over half of seniors in Texas have one or more disabilities. Subrecipient Activities: 5310 Passenger transportation services to the public using the most efficient combination of knowledge materials resources and technology. FY2022 Full Apportionment: $11507861Funds Available: $11507861Non-Traditional State Administrative: $1150786 The amount of FY2022 non-traditional funds awarded does not exceed the 45% maximum. Total available for projects: $10357075 FY22 Total Small Urban apportionment: $5828383 Total State Admin applied for: $69412Traditional Small Urban projects applied for: $624707 Total Small Urban funds applied for: $694119 (SU projects +10% admin) Total obligated Small Urban traditional funds are 82% vs non traditional representing 18%Total Small Urban remaining funds to apply for later: $5134264 FY22 Total Rural apportionment: $5679478State Administrative Rural: $341988 Total Rural projects applied for: $3419883 Total rural funds applied for: $3761871 (Rural projects + 10% admin) Total obligated Rural traditional funds are 88% vs non traditional representing 12%FY22 Total Remaining Funds to be Applied for Later: $1917607 Total FY22 Rural/Small Urban funds to apply for later: $7051871 The Texas Department of Transportation is a Designated Recipient. The minimum of 55 percent of funding for traditional 5310 program type projects has been met. TxDOT certifies that the funds were awarded to subrecipients were awarded on a fair and equitable basis and the projects have been derived from a regionally coordinated public transit-human services transportation plan. To the extent feasible services are coordinated with transportation services provided by other federal agencies.

Planning and Architectural/Engineering Services; Dynamic Air Purification Treatment; Transportation Service Feasibility Study Facility Feasibility Study; Drug Alcohol Consortium and Training; Midland County Connection/City of Midland Transit StudyExpected Outcomes: Projects will increase the support the economic vitality of the metropolitan area especially by enabling global competitiveness productivity and efficiency safety and security of the transportation system for motorized and nonmotorized users accessibility and mobility protect and enhance the environment enhance integration and connectivity of systems promote efficient and effective system management emphasize the preservation of the existing transportation system improve the resiliency and reliability of the transportation system and provide assistance to the transit agencies in the state of Michigan.Intended Beneficiaries: Rural and Urban Transit Agencies cities and municipalities counties and the publicSubrecipient Activities: Transportation Needs Study and Service Plan Facility Construction Feasibility Study; column56: 20.505: METROPOLITAN TRANSPORTATION PLANNING AND STATE AND NON-METROPOLITAN PLANNING AND RESEARCH
column90: DYNAMIC AIR PURIFICATION TREATMENT:  FOR THE DYNAMIC AIR PURIFICATION TREATMENT PROJECT, BENZIE TRANSPORTATION AUTHORITY (BTA) PROPOSES BEING A PILOT TEST BUS/LAB FOR RENEW OR AN EQUIVALENT SYSTEM, AN AIR-PURIFICATION SYSTEM WHICH KILLS 98% OF SARS-COV-2 PARTICLES SIMILAR TO THE COMMERCIAL AIRLINE INDUSTRY; BUT IS MORE COST EFFECTIVE. IF SUCCESSFUL, IT WILL IMPROVE SAFETY OF THE TRANSPORTATION SYSTEM BY REDUCING THE TRANSMITTING OF ILLNESS AND THE RESULTS WILL BE TRANSFERRED TO TRANSIT SYSTEMS STATEWIDE THROUGH TECH TALKS AND MDOT CONFERENCES. THIS INNOVATIVE APPROACH TO CONVENTIONAL OEM AIR HANDLING SYSTEMS AND IS ESSENTIAL TO COMBAT AIRBORNE IMPURITIES. THIS PROJECT IS DEEMED CRITICAL AND WILL BE ADMINISTERED BY THE BTA EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR AND BTA STAFF WILL ASSIST IN COLLECTING AIR QUALITY DATA, WRITING REPORTS, AND ASSISTING IN PRESENTATIONS. ONE VENDOR CALLED LUMINATOR, HAS A SYSTEM CALLED RENEWÂ ¢ AIR TREATMENT SYSTEM THAT DISPENSES GRIGNARD PURE, AN ANTIMICROBIAL AIR TREATMENT THROUGH A CONNECTED, TECHNOLOGICALLY ADVANCED SYSTEM THAT MEASURES AND AUTOMATICALLY ADJUSTS THE AMOUNT THAT IS DISPENSED IN THE AIR. AS CONDITIONS CHANGE, SUCH AS FLUCTUATIONS OF FRESH AIR INTAKE THROUGHOUT THE ROUTE, THE SYSTEM MAINTAINS AN EFFECTIVE LEVEL TO CONTINUOUSLY KILL VIRUS PARTICLES IN THE AIR. GRIGNARD PURE KILLS 98% OF SARS-COV-2 PARTICLES IN THE AIR, WHERE TRANSMISSION IS MOST LIKELY. THE ADAPTIVE SYSTEM UTILIZES ON-BOARD SENSORS TO AUTOMATICALLY ADJUST THE SYSTEM BASED UPON THE FRESH AIR INTAKE AND OTHER CONDITIONS IN THE VEHICLE, MAINTAINING PROPER CONCENTRATION FOR EFFICACY, EVEN WITH DOORS OPENING AND CLOSING AS PASSENGERS EMBARK AND DISEMBARK THE VEHICLE. THIS SYSTEM IS EASY TO USE Â   NO DILUTION, MIXING OR PROTECTIVE GEAR IS REQUIRED AND IS SAFE FOR ALL ON-BOARD SURFACES INCLUDING UPHOLSTERY AND ELECTRONICS. OTHER ULTRAVIOLET SYSTEMS ARE AVAILABLE AND BTA WILL CONDUCT ITS DUE DILIGENCE PRIOR TO PUBLISHING SPECS FOR ITS RFP. BTA WOULD IDEALLY DOCUMENT AIR QUALITY IN BUSES BEFORE AND AFTER SHOWING IMPROVED RESULTS THAT CAN BE SHARED THROUGHOUT THE INDUSTRY. GENERALLY, SHARING INFORMATION IS BEST BY THE STATE ASSOCIATION, MICHIGAN PUBLIC TRANSIT ASSOCIATION (MPTA) AT MONTHLY MEETINGS AND MDOT CONFERENCES HAVE TOPICAL SESSIONS ON BEST PRACTICES OR MONTHLY ZOOM TECH TALKS THAT APPEAR TO BE WELL ATTENDED AND POPULAR.

column55: This application is for 2022 formula funds for the 5310 demographics statewide: as defined in the Texas Transportation Code Title 43 Chapter 461. These funds will be recommended for award statewide to 39 small urban and rural transit districts private non-profit agencies governmental entities and local public agencies to the Texas Transportation Commission on July 12 2022. TDC letter dated 6/24/2022 attached.The funds will be used by 5310 providers for transportation services and capital purchases that serve Seniors and Individuals with disabilities to overcome transportation barriers.Purpose of the Award: Funding for section 5310 grant will enable Texas transit districts to provide public transportation services in both the rural and small urban areas of Texas. Funding will allow transit providers to continue operating established transit services and add new or expanded service to aid the growing 5310 population. Activities to be performed: Operating assistance project administration vehicle preventive maintenance and repairs capital projects benefiting the rural and small urban area (e.g. vehicle procurement hardware and software solutions state administration and mobility management 3rd Party contract services and technical assistance.) Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to implement 5310 programs and services to create an environment of resilience for passengers employees and communities in both rural and small urban areas of the state of Texas Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit seniors and individuals with disabilities by supporting mobility for rural and small urban areas communities transit riders and transit providers. Texas has the largest number of individuals with disabilities of all the states and 17% of the senior population lives in the 177 rural counties in Texas. Over half of seniors in Texas have one or more disabilities. Subrecipient Activities: 5310 Passenger transportation services to the public using the most efficient combination of knowledge materials resources and technology. FY2022 Full Apportionment: $11507861Funds Available: $11507861Non-Traditional State Administrative: $1150786 The amount of FY2022 non-traditional funds awarded does not exceed the 45% maximum. Total available for projects: $10357075 FY22 Total Small Urban apportionment: $5828383 Total State Admin applied for: $69412Traditional Small Urban projects applied for: $624707 Total Small Urban funds applied for: $694119 (SU projects +10% admin) Total obligated Small Urban traditional funds are 82% vs non traditional representing 18%Total Small Urban remaining funds to apply for later: $5134264 FY22 Total Rural apportionment: $5679478State Administrative Rural: $341988 Total Rural projects applied for: $3419883 Total rural funds applied for: $3761871 (Rural projects + 10% admin) Total obligated Rural traditional funds are 88% vs non traditional representing 12%FY22 Total Remaining Funds to be Applied for Later: $1917607 Total FY22 Rural/Small Urban funds to apply for later: $7051871 The Texas Department of Transportation is a Designated Recipient. The minimum of 55 percent of funding for traditional 5310 program type projects has been met. TxDOT certifies that the funds were awarded to subrecipients were awarded on a fair and equitable basis and the projects have been derived from a regionally coordinated public transit-human services transportation plan. To the extent feasible services are coordinated with transportation services provided by other federal agencies.
column56: 20.513: ENHANCED MOBILITY OF SENIORS AND INDIVIDUALS WITH DISABILITIES
column90: THE TRANSIT SYSTEM WILL PROVIDE PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE OF EXISTING 5310 FLEET OF VEHICLES. THE LOCATION OF THE PROJECT WILL BE SOMERVELL AND HOOD COUNTIES. TRANSIT PROVIDER SHALL COMPLY WITH ARTICLE 12: PROJECT RECORDS AND REPORTS AND ARTICLE 13 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT REQUIRING PROCUREMENT AND PROJECT MILESTONES / QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS. WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. Â  PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). Â  TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) SETS A FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL EVERY THREE YEARS FOR FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THE OVERALL GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.

column55: Texas Department of Transportation 5339 BBF formula apportionments FY 2021 and FY 2022. These funds were distributed to the 36 subrecipients that represent Texas rural transit districts.RURAL TOTAL $7500000 TDC 1279516 July 6 2022 TDC letter awarding 1400000 TDCs attached.FY21 $3500000FY22 $4000000 The funds will be used by 5339 eligible subrecipients to support capital projects such as the purchase of new and replacement fleet new and replacement support vehicles shop equipment computer hardware and software vehicle overhauls facility rehab/renovations and other miscellaneous equipment eligible under the 5339 BBF formula program. Purpose of Award: 5339 BBF funding will enable the Texas rural transit providers to keep their equipment facilities and fleet in a state of good repair for use in rural portions of Texas. Activities to be performed: Fleet replacement facility design MISC equipment purchases fleet expansions and other eligible 5339 program activities. Vehicles being replaced have or will meet useful life prior to disposition.Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to keep their capital items in a state of good repair by rehabilitating and replacing older equipment fleet and facilities.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit Texans living in rural areas rural communities transit riders and providers.Subrecipient Activities: The rural transit districts that receive these funds will use the funds to benefit the general public by ensuring the capital items they interact with are in a good state of repair and in condition to serve their purpose.STIP pages: Pages 1289 and 1292
