column55: This application is for 2022 formula funds to the Rural Areas of Texas: the Rural Transit Districts defined in the Texas Transportation Code Title 43 Chapter 458 and RTAP 5311(b) funds. The local match will be derived from local funds and TDCs.The Public Transportation Program managed by the Public Transportation Division (PTN) of Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT) was allocated 15000000 Transportation Development Credits (TDC) for distribution to eligible projects by the Texas Transportation Commission (commission) in Minute Order 116073 for state fiscal year 2022. The TDC letter dated 7/1/22 awards 800000 TDC to various agencies as match for capital projects funded with FY2022 federal Section 5311 Rural Area Grant Program funds. The funds will be used by transit agencies for general transportation services and capital purchases. Purpose of the Award: Funding for this 5311 Rural Areas grant will enable Texas transit districts to provide public transportation services in the rural areas of Texas. Funding will also allow transit providers to continue operating established transit routes and to add new services to aid communities.Activities to be performed: Operating assistance project administration vehicle preventive maintenance and repairs capital projects benefiting the rural area (e.g. vehicle procurement hardware and software solutions) state administration and training and technical assistance. Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to implement programs and services to create an environment of resilience for passengers employees and communities in rural areas of the state of Texas.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit and support mobility for rural areas communities transit riders and transit providers.Subrecipient Activities: Passenger transportation services to the general public using the most efficient combination of knowledge materials resources and technology. GENERAL FUNDS SUMMARYFY 2022 5311 Total Apportionment$60303948 Total 5311 funds:$50517853 Total 5311(b)(3) funds:$871180 Total 5311(f) funds:$8914915 State Administrative: $2100001 5311 funds applied for: $48417852 5311(b)(3) funds applied for: $871180 5311(f) funds applied for: $4872167Total funds applied for: $56261200Total 5311 amount to be applied for later: $0 Total 5311(b)(3) amount to be applied for later: $0 Total 5311(f) amount to be applied for later: $4042748 Total amount to be applied for later:$4042748

column55: Purpose of the Award: This application requests a total of $9779002 in Section 5311 funds to cover various transit operational activities throughout the state. The total of $9318868 in FFY2022 funds includes the full FFY2022 5311 statewide apportionment of $9179646 and the full RTAP amount of $139222. In addition this application re-obligates $460134 in FFY2020 LAPSING statewide funds being de-obligated from prior award #SD-2020-007-01.Activities to be performed: $4424171 Operating Assistance for rural providers$3567793 Project Administration for rural providers$1247812 Intercity Bus (91% of the 15% ICB requirement d $1376946 to fund feeder services across the State)$139222 RTAP (training)$ 400004 State/Program Administration for SDDOT (51% of maximum allowable as calculated by SDDOT)$9779002 Total FTA funds (Note: The FY 2020 funds have been separated into different Projects from the FY 2022 funds due to accounting requirements. Projects #1-#4 are funded with FY 2022 funds; Projects #5 and #6 are those funded with FY 2020 funds.)Expected outcomes: This grant will assist transit agencies statewide in funding administrative and operating costs during FY2023. SDDOT will award to 5311 eligible subrecipients for projects throughout the state. Intended beneficiaries: The transit patrons and employees of various transit agencies throughout the state of South Dakota.Subrecipient Activities: This grant will fund administrative and operating costs as well as provide training and fund ICB admin and operating for the following subrecipients:Aberdeen Ride Line Brookings Area Transit Authority City of Brandon Community Transit of Watertown/Sisseton East Dakota Transit Palace Transit Peoples Transit River Cities Public Transit Rural Office of Community Service Standing Rock Public Transit Vermillion Public Transit West River (Prairie Hills Transit) and Yankton Transit. Other Information:- Local funds sources for each subrecipient is documented in the POP.- Required documentation including the Program of Projects (POP) STIP documentation and Governors ICB letter are attached. The Governors letter stating that the intercity bus service needs in the state are being met without using 15% minimum of the 5311 funds. SDDOT will meet their ICB needs utilizing ARP and 5311 funds for FFY2022. In addition SDDOT is awarding ICB funds to subrecipients for feeder services. - SDDOT uses the sliding scale percentages for Project Administration at 82.82% federal match and Operating at 51.76% federal match as approved by FHWA in accordance with Circular 9040.1G . RTAP and State Administration are funded at 100% Federal.

column55: This application is to request Section 5307 formula funds apportioned to Maine in the amount of $691558. The allocation programmed from FFY2021 is $194359 and the allocation from FFY2022 is $497199. These funds were apportioned to the following urbanized areas in Maine:$442853 Portland UZA (see split letter executed 6/29/22)$248705 Dover-Rochester and Portsmouth UZAsPURPOSE: The purpose of this award is to provide operating and capital assistance in the two southern Maine MPO regions: PACTS and KACTS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: PACTS Region: Funds will be used to cover all operating costs to continue a JARC operating project within the Portland UZA and to fund accessible vehicle purchases. KACTS Region: Funds will be used to continue to fund operating costs for demand-response transportation within the MPO area which consists of the Maine portions of the Dover-Rochester and Portsmouth urbanized areas.EXPECTED OUTCOMES: PACTS Region: Continued demand-response transportation for service eligible under the JARC program under Section 5307. Continued and improved demand-response transportation by adding newer accessible vehicles to the region.KACTS Region: Continuation of demand-response transportation in the region.INTENDED BENEFECIARIES: Residents and visitors to the region who will have continued transit options.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: The Regional Transportation Program will recieve capital assistance to procure two expansion vehicles to their fleet. York County Community Action Corporation will recieve funding to support a JARC operating project. The southern Maine Planning and Development Commission will recieve funding to support demand-response service in Southern Maine.

column55: The purpose of the Weatherization Assistance Program is to increase the energy efficiency of dwellings owned and occupied by low-income persons, reduce their total residential expenditures, and improve their health and safety. The priority population for the Weatherization Assistance Program is persons who are particularly vulnerable such as the elderly, persons with disabilities, families with children, high residential energy users, and households with high-energy burden.

column28: 0001: URBANIZED AREA PROGRAMS;0010: SENIORS AND PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES;0017: IIJA ACT, 2021
column55: This application is for 2022 formula funds for the 5310 demographics statewide: as defined in the Texas Transportation Code Title 43 Chapter 461. These funds will be recommended for award statewide to 39 small urban and rural transit districts private non-profit agencies governmental entities and local public agencies to the Texas Transportation Commission on July 12 2022. TDC letter dated 6/24/2022 attached.The funds will be used by 5310 providers for transportation services and capital purchases that serve Seniors and Individuals with disabilities to overcome transportation barriers.Purpose of the Award: Funding for section 5310 grant will enable Texas transit districts to provide public transportation services in both the rural and small urban areas of Texas. Funding will allow transit providers to continue operating established transit services and add new or expanded service to aid the growing 5310 population. Activities to be performed: Operating assistance project administration vehicle preventive maintenance and repairs capital projects benefiting the rural and small urban area (e.g. vehicle procurement hardware and software solutions state administration and mobility management 3rd Party contract services and technical assistance.) Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to implement 5310 programs and services to create an environment of resilience for passengers employees and communities in both rural and small urban areas of the state of Texas Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit seniors and individuals with disabilities by supporting mobility for rural and small urban areas communities transit riders and transit providers. Texas has the largest number of individuals with disabilities of all the states and 17% of the senior population lives in the 177 rural counties in Texas. Over half of seniors in Texas have one or more disabilities. Subrecipient Activities: 5310 Passenger transportation services to the public using the most efficient combination of knowledge materials resources and technology. FY2022 Full Apportionment: $11507861Funds Available: $11507861Non-Traditional State Administrative: $1150786 The amount of FY2022 non-traditional funds awarded does not exceed the 45% maximum. Total available for projects: $10357075 FY22 Total Small Urban apportionment: $5828383 Total State Admin applied for: $69412Traditional Small Urban projects applied for: $624707 Total Small Urban funds applied for: $694119 (SU projects +10% admin) Total obligated Small Urban traditional funds are 82% vs non traditional representing 18%Total Small Urban remaining funds to apply for later: $5134264 FY22 Total Rural apportionment: $5679478State Administrative Rural: $341988 Total Rural projects applied for: $3419883 Total rural funds applied for: $3761871 (Rural projects + 10% admin) Total obligated Rural traditional funds are 88% vs non traditional representing 12%FY22 Total Remaining Funds to be Applied for Later: $1917607 Total FY22 Rural/Small Urban funds to apply for later: $7051871 The Texas Department of Transportation is a Designated Recipient. The minimum of 55 percent of funding for traditional 5310 program type projects has been met. TxDOT certifies that the funds were awarded to subrecipients were awarded on a fair and equitable basis and the projects have been derived from a regionally coordinated public transit-human services transportation plan. To the extent feasible services are coordinated with transportation services provided by other federal agencies.
column56: 20.513: ENHANCED MOBILITY OF SENIORS AND INDIVIDUALS WITH DISABILITIES
column81: U.S. LOCAL GOVERNMENT,LOCAL GOVERNMENT OWNED,TRANSIT AUTHORITY
column90: CTRTD WILL PROVIDE 5310 CONTINUITY OF SERVICES WITHIN THE ABILENE , BROWNWOOD, AND FORT WORTH TXDOT DISTRICTS, UTILIZING 4 TYPE 3 VEHICLES, MOBILITY MANAGEMENT, PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE, AND OPERATING FUNDING ASSISTANCE IN CONJUNCTION WITH SERVICES PROVIDED WITH ITS TRADITIONAL PARTNERS , IN CONJUNCTION WITH AGREEMENTS WITH THE CENTER FOR LIFE RESOURCES MHMR, THE AREA AGENCY ON AGING (WEST CENTRAL TEXAS COUNCIL OF GOVERNMENTS), DISABILITY IN ACTION, AND ERATH COUNTY SENIOR CITIZENS CENTER. TRANSIT PROVIDER SHALL COMPLY WITH ARTICLE 12: PROJECT RECORDS AND REPORTS AND ARTICLE 13 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT REQUIRING PROCUREMENT AND PROJECT MILESTONES / QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS. WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. Â  PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). Â  TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) SETS A FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL EVERY THREE YEARS FOR FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THE OVERALL GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.

column55: Texas Department of Transportation 5339 BBF formula apportionments FY 2021 and FY 2022. These funds were distributed to the 36 subrecipients that represent Texas rural transit districts.RURAL TOTAL $7500000 TDC 1279516 July 6 2022 TDC letter awarding 1400000 TDCs attached.FY21 $3500000FY22 $4000000 The funds will be used by 5339 eligible subrecipients to support capital projects such as the purchase of new and replacement fleet new and replacement support vehicles shop equipment computer hardware and software vehicle overhauls facility rehab/renovations and other miscellaneous equipment eligible under the 5339 BBF formula program. Purpose of Award: 5339 BBF funding will enable the Texas rural transit providers to keep their equipment facilities and fleet in a state of good repair for use in rural portions of Texas. Activities to be performed: Fleet replacement facility design MISC equipment purchases fleet expansions and other eligible 5339 program activities. Vehicles being replaced have or will meet useful life prior to disposition.Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to keep their capital items in a state of good repair by rehabilitating and replacing older equipment fleet and facilities.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit Texans living in rural areas rural communities transit riders and providers.Subrecipient Activities: The rural transit districts that receive these funds will use the funds to benefit the general public by ensuring the capital items they interact with are in a good state of repair and in condition to serve their purpose.STIP pages: Pages 1289 and 1292

column55: This application is for 2022 formula funds to the Rural Areas of Texas: the Rural Transit Districts defined in the Texas Transportation Code Title 43 Chapter 458 and RTAP 5311(b) funds. The local match will be derived from local funds and TDCs.The Public Transportation Program managed by the Public Transportation Division (PTN) of Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT) was allocated 15000000 Transportation Development Credits (TDC) for distribution to eligible projects by the Texas Transportation Commission (commission) in Minute Order 116073 for state fiscal year 2022. The TDC letter dated 7/1/22 awards 800000 TDC to various agencies as match for capital projects funded with FY2022 federal Section 5311 Rural Area Grant Program funds. The funds will be used by transit agencies for general transportation services and capital purchases. Purpose of the Award: Funding for this 5311 Rural Areas grant will enable Texas transit districts to provide public transportation services in the rural areas of Texas. Funding will also allow transit providers to continue operating established transit routes and to add new services to aid communities.Activities to be performed: Operating assistance project administration vehicle preventive maintenance and repairs capital projects benefiting the rural area (e.g. vehicle procurement hardware and software solutions) state administration and training and technical assistance. Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to implement programs and services to create an environment of resilience for passengers employees and communities in rural areas of the state of Texas.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit and support mobility for rural areas communities transit riders and transit providers.Subrecipient Activities: Passenger transportation services to the general public using the most efficient combination of knowledge materials resources and technology. GENERAL FUNDS SUMMARYFY 2022 5311 Total Apportionment$60303948 Total 5311 funds:$50517853 Total 5311(b)(3) funds:$871180 Total 5311(f) funds:$8914915 State Administrative: $2100001 5311 funds applied for: $48417852 5311(b)(3) funds applied for: $871180 5311(f) funds applied for: $4872167Total funds applied for: $56261200Total 5311 amount to be applied for later: $0 Total 5311(b)(3) amount to be applied for later: $0 Total 5311(f) amount to be applied for later: $4042748 Total amount to be applied for later:$4042748

column55: The Virginia Department of Rail and Public Transportation (VDRPT) is applying for FFY 2022 Section 5303 Metropolitan Planning Program (MPP) funds in the amount of $3408991 to support the funding of 14 Metropolitan Planning Organization (MPO) Unified Planning Work Programs (UPWPs) throughout the state.VDRPT is also applying for FFY 2022 Section 5304 funds in the amount of $765356 for statewide transportation planning. The Statewide Planning and Research (SPR) Work Program is attached in TrAMS and includes a description and funding amount for each of the plans and studies listed in the ALIs.The non-Federal share will be provided by the respective metropolitan areas across the Commonwealth and the Commonwealth of Virginia. The FTA has approved the Unified Planning Work Program (UPWP) for MWCOG on June 1 2022 the only large urbanized area and air quality non-attainment or maintenance area remaining in the Commonwealth of Virginia. Funding in this application reflects what has been approved in the MPOs UPWPs. Approval letters and UPWPs are attached in TrAMS under Application Documents.Purpose: The purpose of this award is to support the funding of 14 Metropolitan Planning Organizations (MPO) so that they can carry out the activities in their FY2023 Unified Planning Work Programs (UPWP). It is also to support the planning activities of the Commonwealth of Virginia.Activities to be performed: Funds will be used to cover the activities in the approved UPWPs of our 14 MPOs which include general planning and programming short and long-term planning TIP development transit studies human service transportation coordination and addressing safety and security issues. The Commonwealth will also help transit agencies develop Transit Development Programs (TDPs) and Transit Strategic Plans (TSPs). Studies and surveys to help improve transportation services in the Commonwealth will also be funded.Expected outcome: Funding ensures the MPOs and the Commonwealth are carrying out transportation planning activities to comply with Federal transportation planning regulations.Intended beneficiaries: All citizens of the Commonwealth of Virginia that rely on efficient safe and effective transportation services and facilities to get them where they need to go.Subrecipient activities: Funds will be given to the following MPOs to cover the activities in their approved UPWPs: Roanoke Valley MPO Hampton Roads TPO Richmond Regional TPO Tri-Cities MPO Washington D.C. MPO (Metropolitan Washington Council of Governments or MWCOG) Fredericksburg MPO Harrisonburg-Rockingham MPO Staunton-Augusta-Waynesboro MPO Charlottesville MPO Bristol MPO Kingsport MPO Winchester MPO Lynchburg MPO and New River Valley MPO. Funds will also be given to the Thomas Jefferson PDC to conduct a study their regional transit and the Roanoke Valley-Alleghany Regional Commission to conduct a survey to better understand the transportation usage in their region.

column90: TRANSPORTATION NEEDS STUDY AND SERVICE PLAN & FACILITY CONSTRUCTION FEASIBILITY STUDY:  AS A FIRST EVER ASSESSMENT, ARENAC PUBLIC TRANSIT AUTHORITY (APTA) ANTICIPATES THE RESULTS OF THE TRANSPORTATION NEEDS STUDY AND SERVICE PLAN MAY INDICATE CHANGES TO HOURS OF OPERATION, EXPANDING EXISTING SERVICE, IDENTIFYING NEW STATE OR LOCAL CONTRACTS, AND/OR CREATING ADDITIONAL PROGRAMS TO MEET SPECIFIC POPULATIONS. THIS PROJECT WILL BE SPEARHEADED BY APTA EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR. APTA INTENDS TO WORK CLOSELY WITH THE CONSULTANT TO ASSIST WHERE NEEDED TO GATHER NECESSARY INFORMATION REQUIRED BY THE CONSULTANT. THE TRANSPORTATION NEEDS STUDY AND SERVICE PLAN WOULD PROVIDE THE AGENCY WITH TOOLS/RESOURCES TO ASSIST WITH EDUCATING THE COMMUNITY YET ALSO EDUCATE EXISTING STAFF ON SERVICE POSSIBILITIES NOT PREVIOUSLY CONSIDERED. ANALYZING STUDY INFORMATION WILL ALLOW APTA TO CREATE NEW APPROACHES TO INTRODUCE TRANSPORTATION TO THE PUBLIC; REDUCING BARRIERS, MINIMIZE UNMET NEEDS, IDENTIFY, AND REDUCE STIGMA REGARDING MISCONCEPTIONS OF PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION. APTA WOULD EVALUATE OPERATIONS INCLUDING TECHNOLOGY, FLEET SIZE, FLEET GROWTH POTENTIAL, SUPPORT EQUIPMENT, ADEQUATE STAFFING, AND ORGANIZATIONAL STRUCTURE. AS PUBLIC KNOWLEDGE INCREASES, BUSINESSES AND COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS WILL IDENTIFY WAYS PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION WILL SUPPORT THEIR INDUSTRY. APTA EXPECTS A THOROUGH FACILITY CONSTRUCTION FEASIBILITY STUDY WILL IDENTIFY THE AMOUNT OF SPACE NEEDED TO ACCOMMODATE CURRENT FLEET, ALLOW FOR EXPANSION, TRANSITION TO LOW NO EMISSION VEHICLES, AND COMPARE COST SAVINGS OF IN-HOUSE MAINTENANCE VS OUTSOURCING AS CURRENT PRACTICE. THE STUDY WOULD ALSO INCLUDE A PROJECTION OF FINANCIAL SUSTAINABILITY. RESEARCHING BUILDING DESIGNS, INVESTIGATING BEST REAL ESTATE OPTIONS SUITABLE FOR BUILDING OR MODIFICATION, AND ENGAGING GUIDANCE FROM MDOT WILL BE PART OF THE PROCESS SPEARHEADED BY APTA EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR. CONDUCTING TRANSPORTATION SURVEY, TOWN HALL STYLE MEETINGS, PRESENTATIONS WITH COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS, AND BUSINESSES WILL PROVIDE FEEDBACK TO GAGE PUBLIC FINANCIAL SUPPORT AND EDUCATE ON PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION SERVICES AND VALUE. THE FACILITY CONSTRUCTION FEASIBILITY STUDY WILL IDENTIFY THE APPROPRIATE FACILITY; SIZE, LOCATION, AMENITIES TO MEET TRANSPORTATION NEEDS FOR ARENAC COUNTY; IDENTIFY ADEQUATE STAFFING SIZE TO MAINTAIN; PROJECTION OF FINANCIAL SUSTAINABILITY; IDENTIFY FUNDING SOURCES; LOCAL, STATE, FEDERAL, AND OTHER GRANT OPPORTUNITIES; NEXT STEPS AND CREATE A TIMELINE TO ADVANCE THE PROCESS; AND PROVIDE DATA TO ADEQUATELY ANSWER QUESTIONS FROM STATE, FEDERAL, AND COMMUNITY STAKEHOLDERS.

column55: This application is to request Section 5311 funds apportioned to the State of Kansas (UZA: 200000) in the amount of $16803066. Purpose: This application is to request FFY2020-2022 Section 5311 funds apportioned to the State of Kansas in the amount of $16802066.Budget Funding:2020.25.18.81 $122951842021.25.18.81 $ 42569492022.2J.18.R7 $ 249933Total Federal Amount: $16802066 Local/State Funding: $13548754Total Grant Amount: $30350820The State will be providing 20 of the local match with State Highway Funds. The remaining 20% match will be provided by the agencies general funds mill levy or other local funds. No federal funding is being used as match. All agencies and CTDs are verified in SAM before any payments are made to them. Activities to be performed: Operating Intercity Bus - provide continued transportation for their passengers. Project Admin - Provide administrative support to the transit agencies in the state. RTAP - Provide training and technical assistance to transit agencies in the state. State Admin - Will be used to cover expenses incurred to administer FTA programs. Expected outcomes: The funding for all of these projects will provide a needed boost to the transit agencies and their passengers. The RTAP project will centralize information and streamline processes that can be used by all the agencies and their passengers. Intended beneficiaries: It is expected that all of the projects will benefit anyone that uses transportation services in Kansas. Subrecipient Activities: Operating Intercity - Continue day to day services and utilize the additional funding to assist with additional expenses. RTAP - The University of Kansas Center for Research will provide assistance to transit agencies to better serve their customers.*Pre-award authority was selected because KDOT will enter into agreements with the CTDS the Intercity Bus Providers and KU for the period starting 7-1-22 in the amount of $15843067. The first two months of expenses are anticipated prior to execution of the award.

column55: Texas Department of Transportation 5339 BBF formula apportionments FY 2021 and FY 2022. These funds were distributed to the 36 subrecipients that represent Texas rural transit districts.RURAL TOTAL $7500000 TDC 1279516 July 6 2022 TDC letter awarding 1400000 TDCs attached.FY21 $3500000FY22 $4000000 The funds will be used by 5339 eligible subrecipients to support capital projects such as the purchase of new and replacement fleet new and replacement support vehicles shop equipment computer hardware and software vehicle overhauls facility rehab/renovations and other miscellaneous equipment eligible under the 5339 BBF formula program. Purpose of Award: 5339 BBF funding will enable the Texas rural transit providers to keep their equipment facilities and fleet in a state of good repair for use in rural portions of Texas. Activities to be performed: Fleet replacement facility design MISC equipment purchases fleet expansions and other eligible 5339 program activities. Vehicles being replaced have or will meet useful life prior to disposition.Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to keep their capital items in a state of good repair by rehabilitating and replacing older equipment fleet and facilities.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit Texans living in rural areas rural communities transit riders and providers.Subrecipient Activities: The rural transit districts that receive these funds will use the funds to benefit the general public by ensuring the capital items they interact with are in a good state of repair and in condition to serve their purpose.STIP pages: Pages 1289 and 1292
column56: 20.526: BUSES AND BUS FACILITIES FORMULA, COMPETITIVE, AND LOW OR NO EMISSIONS PROGRAMS
column90: THE FUNDS SHALL BE USED FOR RURAL AREA TRANSIT CAPITAL PROJECTS IN THE SUBRECIPIENT'S SERVICE AREA THAT MAY REPLACE, REHABILITATE AND PURCHASE BUSES AND RELATED EQUIPMENT AND TO CONSTRUCT BUS-RELATED FACILITIES INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO TECHNOLOGICAL CHANGES OR INNOVATIONS TO MODIFY LOW OR NO EMISSION VEHICLES OR FACILITIES. TRANSIT PROVIDER SHALL COMPLY WITH ARTICLE 12: PROJECT RECORDS AND REPORTS AND ARTICLE 13 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT REQUIRING PROCUREMENT AND PROJECT MILESTONES / QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS. WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME PERIOD SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT OF FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.

column55: This application is for 2022 formula funds to the Rural Areas of Texas: the Rural Transit Districts defined in the Texas Transportation Code Title 43 Chapter 458 and RTAP 5311(b) funds. The local match will be derived from local funds and TDCs.The Public Transportation Program managed by the Public Transportation Division (PTN) of Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT) was allocated 15000000 Transportation Development Credits (TDC) for distribution to eligible projects by the Texas Transportation Commission (commission) in Minute Order 116073 for state fiscal year 2022. The TDC letter dated 7/1/22 awards 800000 TDC to various agencies as match for capital projects funded with FY2022 federal Section 5311 Rural Area Grant Program funds. The funds will be used by transit agencies for general transportation services and capital purchases. Purpose of the Award: Funding for this 5311 Rural Areas grant will enable Texas transit districts to provide public transportation services in the rural areas of Texas. Funding will also allow transit providers to continue operating established transit routes and to add new services to aid communities.Activities to be performed: Operating assistance project administration vehicle preventive maintenance and repairs capital projects benefiting the rural area (e.g. vehicle procurement hardware and software solutions) state administration and training and technical assistance. Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to implement programs and services to create an environment of resilience for passengers employees and communities in rural areas of the state of Texas.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit and support mobility for rural areas communities transit riders and transit providers.Subrecipient Activities: Passenger transportation services to the general public using the most efficient combination of knowledge materials resources and technology. GENERAL FUNDS SUMMARYFY 2022 5311 Total Apportionment$60303948 Total 5311 funds:$50517853 Total 5311(b)(3) funds:$871180 Total 5311(f) funds:$8914915 State Administrative: $2100001 5311 funds applied for: $48417852 5311(b)(3) funds applied for: $871180 5311(f) funds applied for: $4872167Total funds applied for: $56261200Total 5311 amount to be applied for later: $0 Total 5311(b)(3) amount to be applied for later: $0 Total 5311(f) amount to be applied for later: $4042748 Total amount to be applied for later:$4042748

column90: AS PRESENTED IN THE CITY OF CLEBURNE - CITY/COUNTY TRANSPORTATION'S (CCT) FY22 GRANT APPLICATION, CCT WILL PROVIDE PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION IN THE RURAL TRANSIT DISTRICT SERVICE AREA. SERVICE AREA INCLUDES THE CITIES OF ALVARADO, BURLESON, CLEBURNE, GODLEY, GRANDVIEW, JOSHUA, AND RIO VISTA, AND ALL OF THE UNINCORPORATED AREA OF JOHNSON COUNTY. CCT WILL PROVIDE DEMAND RESPONSE SERVICE THROUGHOUT JOHNSON COUNTY AND COMMUTER SERVICE FROM THE CITY OF CLEBURNE TO FORT WORTH. TRANSIT PROVIDER SHALL COMPLY WITH ARTICLE 12: PROJECT RECORDS AND REPORTS AND ARTICLE 13 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT REQUIRING PROCUREMENT AND PROJECT MILESTONES / QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS. WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME PERIOD SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) SETS A FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL EVERY THREE YEARS FOR FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THE PROPOSED OVERALL GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.

column55: The purpose of the Weatherization Assistance Program is to increase the energy efficiency of dwellings owned and occupied by low-income persons, reduce their total residential expenditures, and improve their health and safety. The priority population for the Weatherization Assistance Program is persons who are particularly vulnerable such as the elderly, persons with disabilities, families with children, high residential energy users, and households with high-energy burden.

column55: The Virginia Department of Rail and Public Transportation (VDRPT) is applying for FFY 2022 Section 5303 Metropolitan Planning Program (MPP) funds in the amount of $3408991 to support the funding of 14 Metropolitan Planning Organization (MPO) Unified Planning Work Programs (UPWPs) throughout the state.VDRPT is also applying for FFY 2022 Section 5304 funds in the amount of $765356 for statewide transportation planning. The Statewide Planning and Research (SPR) Work Program is attached in TrAMS and includes a description and funding amount for each of the plans and studies listed in the ALIs.The non-Federal share will be provided by the respective metropolitan areas across the Commonwealth and the Commonwealth of Virginia. The FTA has approved the Unified Planning Work Program (UPWP) for MWCOG on June 1 2022 the only large urbanized area and air quality non-attainment or maintenance area remaining in the Commonwealth of Virginia. Funding in this application reflects what has been approved in the MPOs UPWPs. Approval letters and UPWPs are attached in TrAMS under Application Documents.Purpose: The purpose of this award is to support the funding of 14 Metropolitan Planning Organizations (MPO) so that they can carry out the activities in their FY2023 Unified Planning Work Programs (UPWP). It is also to support the planning activities of the Commonwealth of Virginia.Activities to be performed: Funds will be used to cover the activities in the approved UPWPs of our 14 MPOs which include general planning and programming short and long-term planning TIP development transit studies human service transportation coordination and addressing safety and security issues. The Commonwealth will also help transit agencies develop Transit Development Programs (TDPs) and Transit Strategic Plans (TSPs). Studies and surveys to help improve transportation services in the Commonwealth will also be funded.Expected outcome: Funding ensures the MPOs and the Commonwealth are carrying out transportation planning activities to comply with Federal transportation planning regulations.Intended beneficiaries: All citizens of the Commonwealth of Virginia that rely on efficient safe and effective transportation services and facilities to get them where they need to go.Subrecipient activities: Funds will be given to the following MPOs to cover the activities in their approved UPWPs: Roanoke Valley MPO Hampton Roads TPO Richmond Regional TPO Tri-Cities MPO Washington D.C. MPO (Metropolitan Washington Council of Governments or MWCOG) Fredericksburg MPO Harrisonburg-Rockingham MPO Staunton-Augusta-Waynesboro MPO Charlottesville MPO Bristol MPO Kingsport MPO Winchester MPO Lynchburg MPO and New River Valley MPO. Funds will also be given to the Thomas Jefferson PDC to conduct a study their regional transit and the Roanoke Valley-Alleghany Regional Commission to conduct a survey to better understand the transportation usage in their region.

column55: The West Virginia Department of Transportation Division of Public Transit (WVDOT) Section is applying for FFY 2022 Section 5310 Enhanced Mobility of Seniors and Individuals with Disabilities Program funds in the amount of $2830061 ($1307284 for Rural Apportionment and $1522777 for Small Urban Apportionment) to support the State DOTs FFY 2022 Program of Projects (POP). The WVDOT is applying for funding for both rural and small urban areas for the following projects:Rural projects include the following:Purchase of Eight (8) replacement vansPurchase of Four (4) expansion vans3rd party contracted servicesSmall Urban projects include the following:State Program Administration funds3rd party contracted servicesPurchase of One (1) replacement SUVPurchase of Eight (8) replacement vansPurchase of One (1) expansion vanAll projects in the current POP are in Category A status and are for traditional Section 5310 projects and thus meet the requirement to spend 55% of the apportionment toward traditional capital projects.The States FY 2022 Section 5310 POP is attached to this grant under Application Documents. The total number of recipients funded in the POP is twelve (12) private non-profits in the small urbans areas and twenty (20) private non-profits in the rural areas. The projects included in this application were derived from updated coordinated public transit - human services transportation plans developed by various West Virginia Planning and Development Councils located throughout the State. In addition each plan has been approved by the West Virginia Division of Public Transit.The State Management Plan for the State FY 2022 Section 5310 Program was approved by FTA on March 7 2019.Purpose: The purpose of this award is to provide funding to eligible recipients to meet the transportation needs of seniors and individuals with disabilities throughout West Virginia.Activities to be Performed: This application will fund the purchase of replacement and expansion vans as well as state program admin funds and funding for third party contracting.Expected Outcomes: Continued safe and effective operation of transit services for rural areas of West Virginia. Intended Beneficiaries: WVDOT transit agencies and citizens in the rural and non-urbanized areas of the state. Subrecipient Activities: The following twelve (12) private non-profits in the small urbans areas and twenty (20) private non-profits in the rural areas of West Virginia.Small UrbanEastern Panhandle TransitBerkeley Senior Services Hansford Senior ServicesHancock County Sr. ServicesKanawha Valley Senior Services Northwood Health SystemsPutnam Aging ProgramRaleigh County Community Action Association Family Service Upper Ohio ValleyGood Shepherd InterfaithMonongalia County UrbanWood County Senior Citizens AssociationRural Braxton County Senior Citizens CenterChristian Help Inc. of Mingo CountyCommunity Action of South Eastern West VirginiaCouncil of Senior Citizens of Gilmer CountyCouncil on Aging (Wyoming)Harrison County Senior Citizens Center Inc.Lewis County Senior Citizens CenterMcDowell County Commission on AgingPocahontas County Senior CitizensRitchie County Integrated Family ServicesSenior Life Services of Morgan CountySummers County Council on AgingWirt County Committee on AgingCentral WV Community Action Integrated Resources Inc. Logan-Mingo Area Mental HealthMarion CountyTaylor County Senior Citizens IncWebster County Senior CitizensYouth Health Services

column55: 06/06/22 (Original Grant):This application is to request Section 5304 funds apportioned to Michigan in the amount $671025 for eight new planning projects. The total FY22 grant is $838783. The funding breakdown is as follows:FY21 Section 5304 Federal funding of $443349 FY22 Section 5304 Federal funding of $227676State CTF match of $124454Local match (MPTA membership fee dues and/or registration fees) of $43304Purpose: Provide Section 5304 funds to assist rural and urban transit agencies cities municipalities and counties for research training/education planning and coordination and operational and technical projects that preserve or enhance public transportation.Activities to be performed: Transportation Needs Study and Service Plan Facility Construction Feasibility Study; Planning and Architectural/Engineering Services; Dynamic Air Purification Treatment; Transportation Service Feasibility Study Facility Feasibility Study; Drug Alcohol Consortium and Training; Midland County Connection/City of Midland Transit StudyExpected Outcomes: Projects will increase the support the economic vitality of the metropolitan area especially by enabling global competitiveness productivity and efficiency safety and security of the transportation system for motorized and nonmotorized users accessibility and mobility protect and enhance the environment enhance integration and connectivity of systems promote efficient and effective system management emphasize the preservation of the existing transportation system improve the resiliency and reliability of the transportation system and provide assistance to the transit agencies in the state of Michigan.Intended Beneficiaries: Rural and Urban Transit Agencies cities and municipalities counties and the publicSubrecipient Activities: Transportation Needs Study and Service Plan Facility Construction Feasibility Study; Planning and Architectural/Engineering Services; Dynamic Air Purification Treatment; Transportation Service Feasibility Study Facility Feasibility Study; Drug Alcohol Consortium and Training; Midland County Connection/City of Midland Transit StudyPOP Statewide UWP FTA Approval Letter BCATS UWP and MATS UWP are attached.
column56: 20.505: METROPOLITAN TRANSPORTATION PLANNING AND STATE AND NON-METROPOLITAN PLANNING AND RESEARCH
column81: U.S. LOCAL GOVERNMENT,LOCAL GOVERNMENT OWNED,TRANSIT AUTHORITY
column90: PROPULSION SYSTEMS FEASIBILITY STUDY:  THE PROPULSION SYSTEMS FEASIBILITY STUDY OBJECTIVE IS TO DETERMINE IF AND WHAT TYPE OF ALTERNATIVE PROPULSION SYSTEM COULD BE IMPLEMENTED ON THE M/V EMERALD ISLE AND THE FERRY VESSEL THAT WAS DESIGNED IN 2012, BUT NOT YET CONSTRUCTED, TO BETTER MEET OR EXCEED THE EPAÂ  S CLEAN AIR ACT. THE M/V EMERALD ISLE IS POWERED BY TWIN CATERPILLAR 3512BS DIESEL ENGINES AND TWO (2) 3304 DIESEL GENERATORS, AND A 3116 DIESEL POWERED BOW THRUSTER. THESE ENGINES ARE ORIGINAL (VESSEL LAUNCHED 1997) AND HAVE BEEN REBUILT SEVERAL TIMES. THE STUDY WILL EXAMINE IF AN ALTERNATIVE PROPULSION SYSTEM SHOULD BE CONSIDERED, WHAT WOULD NEED TO BE REPLACED/MODIFIED ON THE VESSEL TO MAKE IT FUNCTIONAL WITH THE PROPOSED ALTERNATE TECHNOLOGY PROPULSION SYSTEMS, WOULD IT BE FINANCIALLY BENEFICIAL AND WHAT WOULD BE THE PROJECTED COSTS FOR THE PROPOSED OPTIONS. A PROPOSED NEW VESSEL WAS DESIGNED IN 2012 AND HAS NOT YET BEEN FUNDED. THIS VESSEL WAS DESIGNED UTILIZING DIESEL ENGINES. THIS STUDY WOULD ALSO EXAMINE IF THE VESSEL PLANS COULD BE ALTERED TO ACCOMMODATE A DIFFERENT TYPE OF PROPULSION SYSTEM AND THE ESTIMATED COST FOR A VESSEL REDESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION COSTS WITH ALTERNATE PROPULSION SYSTEMS. THE STUDY WOULD ALSO INCLUDE WHAT TYPE OF ENERGY SOURCE IS CONSIDERED A VIABLE ALTERNATIVE TO DIESEL AND WHAT THE INFRASTRUCTURE NEEDS AND PROJECTED COSTS REQUIRED ON THE DOCKS, IF THE ISLAND HAVE THESE CAPABILITIES, ARE THEY AVAILABLE AT THE MAINLAND DOCK, AND THE ESTIMATED INFRASTRUCTURE COSTS AND COST OF CHARGING/STORING FUEL. THE ANTICIPATED WORK PRODUCT OF THE PROPULSION SYSTEMS FEASIBILITY STUDY WOULD BE TO PROVIDE A FINAL REPORT FROM A NAVAL ARCHITECTURAL FIRM WITH THEIR RECOMMENDATIONS, AND A TENTATIVE SCHEDULE TO ACCOMPLISH THE TASKS REQUIRED TO MEET A POSSIBLE REPOWER AND INFRASTRUCTURE SUPPORT AT DOCK LOCATIONS.

column55: 06/06/22 (Original Grant):This application is to request Section 5304 funds apportioned to Michigan in the amount $671025 for eight new planning projects. The total FY22 grant is $838783. The funding breakdown is as follows:FY21 Section 5304 Federal funding of $443349 FY22 Section 5304 Federal funding of $227676State CTF match of $124454Local match (MPTA membership fee dues and/or registration fees) of $43304Purpose: Provide Section 5304 funds to assist rural and urban transit agencies cities municipalities and counties for research training/education planning and coordination and operational and technical projects that preserve or enhance public transportation.Activities to be performed: Transportation Needs Study and Service Plan Facility Construction Feasibility Study; Planning and Architectural/Engineering Services; Dynamic Air Purification Treatment; Transportation Service Feasibility Study Facility Feasibility Study; Drug Alcohol Consortium and Training; Midland County Connection/City of Midland Transit StudyExpected Outcomes: Projects will increase the support the economic vitality of the metropolitan area especially by enabling global competitiveness productivity and efficiency safety and security of the transportation system for motorized and nonmotorized users accessibility and mobility protect and enhance the environment enhance integration and connectivity of systems promote efficient and effective system management emphasize the preservation of the existing transportation system improve the resiliency and reliability of the transportation system and provide assistance to the transit agencies in the state of Michigan.Intended Beneficiaries: Rural and Urban Transit Agencies cities and municipalities counties and the publicSubrecipient Activities: Transportation Needs Study and Service Plan Facility Construction Feasibility Study; Planning and Architectural/Engineering Services; Dynamic Air Purification Treatment; Transportation Service Feasibility Study Facility Feasibility Study; Drug Alcohol Consortium and Training; Midland County Connection/City of Midland Transit StudyPOP Statewide UWP FTA Approval Letter BCATS UWP and MATS UWP are attached.
column56: 20.505: METROPOLITAN TRANSPORTATION PLANNING AND STATE AND NON-METROPOLITAN PLANNING AND RESEARCH
column90:
TRANSPORTATION SERVICE FEASIBILITY STUDY & FACILITY FEASIBILITY STUDY:  THE TRANSPORTATION SERVICE FEASIBILITY STUDY WOULD EVALUATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THE CURRENT SERVICES, IDENTIFY ADDITIONAL TRANSPORTATION METHODS, DELIVERY SERVICES PROCESS, AND BUSINESS CONSORTIUM TO MEET CONSUMER TRANSPORTATION NEEDS. AS A FIRST EVER ASSESSMENT, MECOSTA OSCEOLA TRANSIT AUTHORITY (MOTA) ANTICIPATES THE RESULTS WILL INDICATE CHANGES TO HOURS OF SERVICE, EXPANDING SERVICE, IDENTIFYING NEW STATE AND/OR LOCAL CONTRACTS, AND/OR CRESTING NEW PROGRAMS TO MEET THE NEEDS OF THE PEOPLE. ALTHOUGH MOTA AREA RESIDENTS ARE SUPPORTIVE OF PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION, ONLY APPROXIMATELY 15,000 RIDES PER YEAR COME FROM THE COMBINED POPULATION BASE OVER 63,000 RESIDENTS IN BOTH COUNTIES. WHILE THE MAJORITY OF THE RIDES OCCUR IN MECOSTA (MOST POPULATED), OSCEOLA COUNTY REMAINS UNDER-SERVED DUE IN LARGE PART TO THE LARGE STATE FOREST IN THE CENTER OF THE COUNTY WHICH HAS NO PUBLIC ROADS IN IT. MOTA DESIRES TO INCREASE THE USAGE OF ITS SERVICES IN OSCEOLA COUNTY AND IN OUTLYING UNDER-SERVED AREAS OF MECOSTA COUNTY AS WELL. WHILE MECOSTA COUNTY HAS A POVERTY RATE OF 13.6%, OSCEOLA COUNTYÂ  S RATE IS 14.2% ACCORDING TO THE LATEST U.S. CENSUS. THIS PROJECT WILL BE OVERSEEN BY THE EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR WHO WILL COORDINATE WITH THE CONSULTANTS AND WORK CLOSELY WITH THE TOWNSHIPS, VILLAGES, AND CITIES IN MOTAÂ  S SERVICE AREA. THE FACILITY CONSTRUCTION FEASIBILITY STUDY WILL IDENTIFY THE NEED FOR AN APPROPRIATE LOCATION OF AN APPROPRIATE FACILITY CONSIDERING MOTAÂ  S PRESENT FLEET SIZE AND PROJECT NEEDS. MOTA EXPECTS TO RECEIVE CLEAR DIRECTION AND GUIDANCE TO EITHER UPGRADING THE PRESENT FACILITY OR MOVING TO AN APPROPRIATE MORE CENTRALLY LOCATED FACILITY IN THEIR SERVICE AREA, AND ADJUSTING THE SERVICE PROVIDED FOR INCREASED EFFECTIVENESS AND GREATER UTILIZATION. MOTA EXPECTS A THOROUGH STUDY WILL IDENTIFY THE AMOUNT OF SPACE NEEDED TO ACCOMMODATE CURRENT FLEET, ALLOW FOR EXPANSION, TRANSITION TO LOW/NO EMISSION VEHICLES. THE STUDY WOULD ALSO INCLUDE A PROJECTION OF FINANCIAL SUSTAINABILITY. RESEARCHING BUILDING DESIGNS, INVESTIGATING BEST REAL ESTATE OPTIONS SUITABLE FOR BUILDING OR MODIFICATION, AND ENGAGING GUIDANCE FROM MDOT WILL BE PART OF THE PROCESS SPEARHEADED BY THE MOTA EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR. 
 
 09/19/22:  MECOSTA OSCEOLA TRANSIT AUTHORITY (MOTA) REQUESTED THEIR NAME BE UPDATED ON THEIR UEI NUMBER FROM MECOSTAOSCEOLA CO AREA TRANSIT TO MATCH THEIR LEGAL NAME (MOTA).  TO DATE, THIS UPDATE HAS NOT BEEN MADE.  THE REFERENCE INFORMATION IS AS FOLLOWS: INC-GSAFSD6946463 - ADDRESS MISMATCH REFERENCE NUMBER: CF350B4D-AF4F-4525-B18E-64141C03C2BA.

column56: 20.505: METROPOLITAN TRANSPORTATION PLANNING AND STATE AND NON-METROPOLITAN PLANNING AND RESEARCH
column90: DRUG AND ALCOHOL CONSORTIUM AND TRAINING:  MDOT Â   OPT, WOULD CONTRACT WITH A THIRD-PARTY IN THE ADMINISTRATION OF ALL NECESSARY REQUIREMENTS (EXCEPT POLICY FORMULATION INCLUDING DRUG AND ALCOHOL POLICY TEMPLATES PROVIDED TO NEW TRANSIT AGENCIES AS WELL AS POLICY REVIEW AND APPROVAL OF NEW POLICIES AS WELL AS EXISTING TRANSIT POLICIES) TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH THE USDOT (FTA AND FMSCA) TO COMPLY WITH THE FEDERAL REGULATIONS FOR DRUG AND ALCOHOL TESTING. THIS CONTRACT IS AVAILABLE TO ANY GOVERNMENTAL AGENCY OR APPROVED CONTRACTOR WITHIN THE STATE OF MICHIGAN. USER AGENCIES THAT ARE REGULATED BY FTA AND MAY INCLUDE TRANSIT AGENCIES SUCH AS INDEPENDENT AND COUNTY OPERATED TRANSIT SYSTEMS, COVERED CONTRACTORS, MAINTENANCE CONTRACTORS WHOSE EMPLOYEES PERFORM SAFETY-SENSITIVE FUNCTIONS AS DEFINED BY 49 CFR PART 655 AND USER AGENCIES THAT ARE REGULATED BY FMCSA MAY INCLUDE TRANSIT AGENCIES SUCH AS PRIVATE NONPROFIT, COVERED CONTRACTORS, MAINTENANCE CONTRACTORS, WHOSE EMPLOYEES PERFORM SAFETY-SENSITIVE FUNCTIONS AS DEFINED BY 49 CFR PART 382. SERVICES PROVIDED UNDER THIS CONTRACT INCLUDE COMPLETE DRUG AND ALCOHOL TESTING SERVICES INCLUDING THE COLLECTION OF THE SPECIMEN AT A LOCAL FACILITY, ANALYSIS OF THE SPECIMEN, INITIAL AND CONFIRMATION TESTING, MEDICAL REVIEW OFFICER SERVICES, RANDOM SELECTION, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, AND SUBSTANCE ABUSE PROFESSIONAL REFERRAL SERVICES. THE CONSULTANT WILL ENSURE POLICIES FOR ALL RURAL AGENCIES ARE FOLLOWING CURRENT REGULATIONS AND PROVIDE TRAINING TO ALL RURAL AGENCIES ON THE DRUG AND ALCOHOL PROGRAM, INCLUDING REASONABLE SUSPICION. THESE ACTIONS WILL RESULT IN THE FOLLOWING: MINIMIZED COMPLIANCE COSTS, SIMPLIFIED COMPLIANCE PROCEDURES, IDENTIFIED AND COORDINATED COMPLIANCE RESOURCES, EDUCATION/TRAINING, CLARIFICATION, ADVICE, AND REDUCED STATE ADMINISTRATION AND INVOLVEMENT WITH PROGRAM.

column55: Funding for all projects included in this grant application is provided by the following apportionment years and Urbanized areas (UZAs).Section 5307 FFY 2022 Thousand Oaks (UZA #61440): $1459217Section 5307 FFY 2022 Oxnard (UZA #60860): $3626823Section 5307 FFY 2021 Camarillo (UZA #063680): $701522Section 5307 FFY 2022 Camarillo (UZA #063680): $759185Section 5307 FFY 2022 Simi Valley (#062710): $272551Overall grant fundingTotal Federal Funds: $6819298Total Local Match: $3834747 (Transportation Development Act [state sales tax for transportation] city general funds)Total Project Cost: $10654045A portion of the local share is provided by Transportation Development Credits. Because Transportation Development Credits do not allocate actual money toward project expenses an increased federal share is reflected where the credits are applied.VCTC is hereby submitting this grant application in support of the following projects for capital planning and operations:1) Capital Projects for VCTC and Subrecipients FY 2022 FundsThe grant applies $1940325 in FY 22 Section 5307 funds for preventive maintenance ADA service capital contracting cost capital infrastructure mobility management and Jobs Access and Reverse Commute with further details provided in the Project Description.2) Planning Projects for VCTC and CamarilloThe grant applies $1199000 in FY 22 Section 5307 funds for planning with further details provided in the Project Description.3) Operating Assistance for VCTC and Subrecipients FY 2022 FundsThe grant applies $2858451 in FY 22 Section 5307 funds for operating assistance with further details provided in the Project Description.4) Camarillo Preventive Maintenance FY 2021 FundsThe grant applies $604800 in FY 21 Section 5307 funds for preventive maintenance with further details provided in the Project Description.5) Camarillo Operating Assistance FY 2021 FundsThe grant applies $96722 in FY 21 Section 5307 funds for operating assistance with further details provided in the Project Description.Purpose: The purpose of this award is to provide $2545125 to VCTC and subrecipients for for preventive maintenance ADA service capital contracting cost mobility management capital infrastructure and Jobs Access Reverse Commute (JARC); $1199000 to VCTC and Camarillo for planning; and $2955173 to VCTC and Subrecipients for operating assistance.Activities to be performed: Funds will be used to cover eligible operating expenses such as driver salaries fuel maintenance on-demand rideshare transit vehicle leases etc. to continue transit operations.Expected outcomes: Funding will permit VCTC to continue to provide operations that would otherwise have to be cut due to lack of funding.Intended beneficiaries: VCTC and the riders that rely on its services will benefit from continued service permitting workers to get to work and riders to get to essential services.Subrecipients: The following are providers of transit service operators: MV Transportation First Transit and RATP-DEV.Suballocation Letter:Recipient organization is the Designated Recipient and can apply for and receive these apportioned funds. This Application is consistent with the suballocation identified in the Split Letter dated April 11 2022 and attached to this application. In keeping with the IIJA set aside for safety for areas over 200000 this grant will spend a minimum of $38145.30 representing 0.0075% of the Oxnard and Thousand Oaks funds for keeping vehicles safe and safety maintenance as part of ALI 11.7A.00 VCTC Intercity Preventive Maintenance.

column28: 0001: URBANIZED AREA PROGRAMS;0010: SENIORS AND PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES;0017: IIJA ACT, 2021
column55: This application is for 2022 formula funds for the 5310 demographics statewide: as defined in the Texas Transportation Code Title 43 Chapter 461. These funds will be recommended for award statewide to 39 small urban and rural transit districts private non-profit agencies governmental entities and local public agencies to the Texas Transportation Commission on July 12 2022. TDC letter dated 6/24/2022 attached.The funds will be used by 5310 providers for transportation services and capital purchases that serve Seniors and Individuals with disabilities to overcome transportation barriers.Purpose of the Award: Funding for section 5310 grant will enable Texas transit districts to provide public transportation services in both the rural and small urban areas of Texas. Funding will allow transit providers to continue operating established transit services and add new or expanded service to aid the growing 5310 population. Activities to be performed: Operating assistance project administration vehicle preventive maintenance and repairs capital projects benefiting the rural and small urban area (e.g. vehicle procurement hardware and software solutions state administration and mobility management 3rd Party contract services and technical assistance.) Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to implement 5310 programs and services to create an environment of resilience for passengers employees and communities in both rural and small urban areas of the state of Texas Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit seniors and individuals with disabilities by supporting mobility for rural and small urban areas communities transit riders and transit providers. Texas has the largest number of individuals with disabilities of all the states and 17% of the senior population lives in the 177 rural counties in Texas. Over half of seniors in Texas have one or more disabilities. Subrecipient Activities: 5310 Passenger transportation services to the public using the most efficient combination of knowledge materials resources and technology. FY2022 Full Apportionment: $11507861Funds Available: $11507861Non-Traditional State Administrative: $1150786 The amount of FY2022 non-traditional funds awarded does not exceed the 45% maximum. Total available for projects: $10357075 FY22 Total Small Urban apportionment: $5828383 Total State Admin applied for: $69412Traditional Small Urban projects applied for: $624707 Total Small Urban funds applied for: $694119 (SU projects +10% admin) Total obligated Small Urban traditional funds are 82% vs non traditional representing 18%Total Small Urban remaining funds to apply for later: $5134264 FY22 Total Rural apportionment: $5679478State Administrative Rural: $341988 Total Rural projects applied for: $3419883 Total rural funds applied for: $3761871 (Rural projects + 10% admin) Total obligated Rural traditional funds are 88% vs non traditional representing 12%FY22 Total Remaining Funds to be Applied for Later: $1917607 Total FY22 Rural/Small Urban funds to apply for later: $7051871 The Texas Department of Transportation is a Designated Recipient. The minimum of 55 percent of funding for traditional 5310 program type projects has been met. TxDOT certifies that the funds were awarded to subrecipients were awarded on a fair and equitable basis and the projects have been derived from a regionally coordinated public transit-human services transportation plan. To the extent feasible services are coordinated with transportation services provided by other federal agencies.
column56: 20.513: ENHANCED MOBILITY OF SENIORS AND INDIVIDUALS WITH DISABILITIES

column90: SPARTAN WILL DELIVER SERVICE THROUGH PURCHASE OF SERVICE WITH PROJECT PARTNERS LIFERUN CENTER FOR INDEPENDENT LIVING, HOCKLEY COUNTY SENIOR CITIZENS CENTER, BROWNFIELD SENIOR CITIZENS, AND SCURRY COUNTY SENIOR CITIZENS. THIS FUNDING WILL ALLOW SPARTAN'S EXISTING PARTNERSHIPS TO CONTINUE TO FILL GAPS. TRANSIT PROVIDER SHALL COMPLY WITH ARTICLE 12: PROJECT RECORDS AND REPORTS AND ARTICLE 13 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT REQUIRING PROCUREMENT AND PROJECT MILESTONES / QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS. WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. Â  PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). Â  TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) SETS A FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL EVERY THREE YEARS FOR FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THE OVERALL GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.

column55: This application is for 2022 formula funds to the Rural Areas of Texas: the Rural Transit Districts defined in the Texas Transportation Code Title 43 Chapter 458 and RTAP 5311(b) funds. The local match will be derived from local funds and TDCs.The Public Transportation Program managed by the Public Transportation Division (PTN) of Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT) was allocated 15000000 Transportation Development Credits (TDC) for distribution to eligible projects by the Texas Transportation Commission (commission) in Minute Order 116073 for state fiscal year 2022. The TDC letter dated 7/1/22 awards 800000 TDC to various agencies as match for capital projects funded with FY2022 federal Section 5311 Rural Area Grant Program funds. The funds will be used by transit agencies for general transportation services and capital purchases. Purpose of the Award: Funding for this 5311 Rural Areas grant will enable Texas transit districts to provide public transportation services in the rural areas of Texas. Funding will also allow transit providers to continue operating established transit routes and to add new services to aid communities.Activities to be performed: Operating assistance project administration vehicle preventive maintenance and repairs capital projects benefiting the rural area (e.g. vehicle procurement hardware and software solutions) state administration and training and technical assistance. Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to implement programs and services to create an environment of resilience for passengers employees and communities in rural areas of the state of Texas.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit and support mobility for rural areas communities transit riders and transit providers.Subrecipient Activities: Passenger transportation services to the general public using the most efficient combination of knowledge materials resources and technology. column90: AS PRESENTED IN SOUTH PLAINS COMMUNITY ACTION ASSOCIATION, INC. - SPARTAN'S FY22 GRANT APPLICATION, SPARTAN WILL PROVIDE PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION THROUGHOUT THE RURAL TRANSIT DISTRICT SERVICE AREA. SPARTAN WILL PROVIDE DEMAND RESPONSE SERVICE IN THE RURAL AREAS OF BAILEY, COCHRAN, CROSBY, DICKENS, FLOYD, GARZA, HALE, HOCKLEY, KING, LAMB, LUBBOCK, LYNN, MITCHELL, MOTLEY, SCURRY, TERRY AND YOAKUM COUNTIES. TRANSIT PROVIDER SHALL COMPLY WITH ARTICLE 12: PROJECT RECORDS AND REPORTS AND ARTICLE 13 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT REQUIRING PROCUREMENT AND PROJECT MILESTONES / QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS. WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME PERIOD SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) SETS A FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL EVERY THREE YEARS FOR FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THE PROPOSED OVERALL GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.

column28: 0001: URBANIZED AREA PROGRAMS;0016: BUS AND BUS FACILITIES FORMULA GRANTS
column55: Texas Department of Transportation 5339 BBF formula apportionments FY 2021 and FY 2022. These funds were distributed to the 36 subrecipients that represent Texas rural transit districts.RURAL TOTAL $7500000 TDC 1279516 July 6 2022 TDC letter awarding 1400000 TDCs attached.FY21 $3500000FY22 $4000000 The funds will be used by 5339 eligible subrecipients to support capital projects such as the purchase of new and replacement fleet new and replacement support vehicles shop equipment computer hardware and software vehicle overhauls facility rehab/renovations and other miscellaneous equipment eligible under the 5339 BBF formula program. Purpose of Award: 5339 BBF funding will enable the Texas rural transit providers to keep their equipment facilities and fleet in a state of good repair for use in rural portions of Texas. Activities to be performed: Fleet replacement facility design MISC equipment purchases fleet expansions and other eligible 5339 program activities. Vehicles being replaced have or will meet useful life prior to disposition.Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to keep their capital items in a state of good repair by rehabilitating and replacing older equipment fleet and facilities.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit Texans living in rural areas rural communities transit riders and providers.Subrecipient Activities: The rural transit districts that receive these funds will use the funds to benefit the general public by ensuring the capital items they interact with are in a good state of repair and in condition to serve their purpose.STIP pages: Pages 1289 and 1292

column90: THE FUNDS SHALL BE USED FOR RURAL AREA TRANSIT CAPITAL PROJECTS IN THE SUBRECIPIENT'S SERVICE AREA THAT MAY REPLACE, REHABILITATE AND PURCHASE BUSES AND RELATED EQUIPMENT AND TO CONSTRUCT BUS-RELATED FACILITIES INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO TECHNOLOGICAL CHANGES OR INNOVATIONS TO MODIFY LOW OR NO EMISSION VEHICLES OR FACILITIES. TRANSIT PROVIDER SHALL COMPLY WITH ARTICLE 12: PROJECT RECORDS AND REPORTS AND ARTICLE 13 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT REQUIRING PROCUREMENT AND PROJECT MILESTONES / QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS. WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME PERIOD SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT OF FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.

column31: RAIL AND PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION, VIRGINIA DEPARTMENT OF
column55: The Virginia Department of Rail and Public Transportation (VDRPT) is applying for FFY 2022 Section 5303 Metropolitan Planning Program (MPP) funds in the amount of $3408991 to support the funding of 14 Metropolitan Planning Organization (MPO) Unified Planning Work Programs (UPWPs) throughout the state.VDRPT is also applying for FFY 2022 Section 5304 funds in the amount of $765356 for statewide transportation planning. The Statewide Planning and Research (SPR) Work Program is attached in TrAMS and includes a description and funding amount for each of the plans and studies listed in the ALIs.The non-Federal share will be provided by the respective metropolitan areas across the Commonwealth and the Commonwealth of Virginia. The FTA has approved the Unified Planning Work Program (UPWP) for MWCOG on June 1 2022 the only large urbanized area and air quality non-attainment or maintenance area remaining in the Commonwealth of Virginia. Funding in this application reflects what has been approved in the MPOs UPWPs. Approval letters and UPWPs are attached in TrAMS under Application Documents.Purpose: The purpose of this award is to support the funding of 14 Metropolitan Planning Organizations (MPO) so that they can carry out the activities in their FY2023 Unified Planning Work Programs (UPWP). It is also to support the planning activities of the Commonwealth of Virginia.Activities to be performed: Funds will be used to cover the activities in the approved UPWPs of our 14 MPOs which include general planning and programming short and long-term planning TIP development transit studies human service transportation coordination and addressing safety and security issues. The Commonwealth will also help transit agencies develop Transit Development Programs (TDPs) and Transit Strategic Plans (TSPs). Studies and surveys to help improve transportation services in the Commonwealth will also be funded.Expected outcome: Funding ensures the MPOs and the Commonwealth are carrying out transportation planning activities to comply with Federal transportation planning regulations.Intended beneficiaries: All citizens of the Commonwealth of Virginia that rely on efficient safe and effective transportation services and facilities to get them where they need to go.Subrecipient activities: Funds will be given to the following MPOs to cover the activities in their approved UPWPs: Roanoke Valley MPO Hampton Roads TPO Richmond Regional TPO Tri-Cities MPO Washington D.C. MPO (Metropolitan Washington Council of Governments or MWCOG) Fredericksburg MPO Harrisonburg-Rockingham MPO Staunton-Augusta-Waynesboro MPO Charlottesville MPO Bristol MPO Kingsport MPO Winchester MPO Lynchburg MPO and New River Valley MPO. Funds will also be given to the Thomas Jefferson PDC to conduct a study their regional transit and the Roanoke Valley-Alleghany Regional Commission to conduct a survey to better understand the transportation usage in their region.

column28: 0001: URBANIZED AREA PROGRAMS;0016: BUS AND BUS FACILITIES FORMULA GRANTS
column55: Texas Department of Transportation 5339 BBF formula apportionments FY 2021 and FY 2022. These funds were distributed to the 36 subrecipients that represent Texas rural transit districts.RURAL TOTAL $7500000 TDC 1279516 July 6 2022 TDC letter awarding 1400000 TDCs attached.FY21 $3500000FY22 $4000000 The funds will be used by 5339 eligible subrecipients to support capital projects such as the purchase of new and replacement fleet new and replacement support vehicles shop equipment computer hardware and software vehicle overhauls facility rehab/renovations and other miscellaneous equipment eligible under the 5339 BBF formula program. Purpose of Award: 5339 BBF funding will enable the Texas rural transit providers to keep their equipment facilities and fleet in a state of good repair for use in rural portions of Texas. Activities to be performed: Fleet replacement facility design MISC equipment purchases fleet expansions and other eligible 5339 program activities. Vehicles being replaced have or will meet useful life prior to disposition.Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to keep their capital items in a state of good repair by rehabilitating and replacing older equipment fleet and facilities.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit Texans living in rural areas rural communities transit riders and providers.Subrecipient Activities: The rural transit districts that receive these funds will use the funds to benefit the general public by ensuring the capital items they interact with are in a good state of repair and in condition to serve their purpose.STIP pages: Pages 1289 and 1292
column56: 20.526: BUSES AND BUS FACILITIES FORMULA, COMPETITIVE, AND LOW OR NO EMISSIONS PROGRAMS
column90: THE FUNDS SHALL BE USED FOR RURAL AREA TRANSIT CAPITAL PROJECTS IN THE SUBRECIPIENT'S SERVICE AREA THAT MAY REPLACE, REHABILITATE AND PURCHASE BUSES AND RELATED EQUIPMENT AND TO CONSTRUCT BUS-RELATED FACILITIES INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO TECHNOLOGICAL CHANGES OR INNOVATIONS TO MODIFY LOW OR NO EMISSION VEHICLES OR FACILITIES. TRANSIT PROVIDER SHALL COMPLY WITH ARTICLE 12: PROJECT RECORDS AND REPORTS AND ARTICLE 13 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT REQUIRING PROCUREMENT AND PROJECT MILESTONES / QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS. WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME PERIOD SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT OF FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.

column18: REGION 6 DOT FTA
column24: OFFICE OF BUDGET AND POLICY(TBP)
column55: This application is for 2022 formula funds to the Rural Areas of Texas: the Rural Transit Districts defined in the Texas Transportation Code Title 43 Chapter 458 and RTAP 5311(b) funds. The local match will be derived from local funds and TDCs.The Public Transportation Program managed by the Public Transportation Division (PTN) of Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT) was allocated 15000000 Transportation Development Credits (TDC) for distribution to eligible projects by the Texas Transportation Commission (commission) in Minute Order 116073 for state fiscal year 2022. The TDC letter dated 7/1/22 awards 800000 TDC to various agencies as match for capital projects funded with FY2022 federal Section 5311 Rural Area Grant Program funds. The funds will be used by transit agencies for general transportation services and capital purchases. Purpose of the Award: Funding for this 5311 Rural Areas grant will enable Texas transit districts to provide public transportation services in the rural areas of Texas. Funding will also allow transit providers to continue operating established transit routes and to add new services to aid communities.Activities to be performed: Operating assistance project administration vehicle preventive maintenance and repairs capital projects benefiting the rural area (e.g. vehicle procurement hardware and software solutions) state administration and training and technical assistance. Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to implement programs and services to create an environment of resilience for passengers employees and communities in rural areas of the state of Texas.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit and support mobility for rural areas communities transit riders and transit providers.Subrecipient Activities: Passenger transportation services to the general public using the most efficient combination of knowledge materials resources and technology. GENERAL FUNDS SUMMARYFY 2022 5311 Total Apportionment$60303948 Total 5311 funds:$50517853 Total 5311(b)(3) funds:$871180 Total 5311(f) funds:$8914915 State Administrative: $2100001 5311 funds applied for: $48417852 5311(b)(3) funds applied for: $871180 5311(f) funds applied for: $4872167Total funds applied for: $56261200Total 5311 amount to be applied for later: $0 Total 5311(b)(3) amount to be applied for later: $0 Total 5311(f) amount to be applied for later: $4042748 Total amount to be applied for later:$4042748
column56: 20.509: FORMULA GRANTS FOR RURAL AREAS AND TRIBAL TRANSIT PROGRAM
column90: AS PRESENTED IN CAPITAL AREA RURAL TRANSPORTATION SYSTEM'S (CARTS) FY22 GRANT APPLICATION, CARTS WILL PROVIDE PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION THROUGHOUT THE RURAL TRANSIT DISTRICT SERVICE AREA. CARTS WILL PROVIDE DEMAND RESPONSE SERVICE IN THE RURAL AREAS OF BASTROP, BLANCO, BURNET, CALDWELL, FAYETTE, HAYS, LEE, TRAVIS AND WILLIAMSON COUNTIES. CARTS WILL ALSO PROVIDE DEVIATED FIXED ROUTE LOCAL SERVICE IN THE CITY OF BASTROP, COMMUTER SERVICE FROM SMITHVILLE TO BASTROP TO AUSTIN AND FROM COMMUTER SERVICE FROM ELGIN TO MANOR. CARTS COORDINATES SERVICES WITH REGIONAL INTERCITY BUS SERVICES, MEDICAL TRANSPORTATION SERVICES, URBAN LOCAL TRANSIT SERVICES, AND COORDINATED METROPOLITAN ROUTES TO PROVIDE A COMPREHENSIVE MOBILITY RESOURCE IN THE CARTS DISTRICT. TRANSIT PROVIDER SHALL COMPLY WITH ARTICLE 12: PROJECT RECORDS AND REPORTS AND ARTICLE 13 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT REQUIRING PROCUREMENT AND PROJECT MILESTONES / QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS. WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME PERIOD SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) SETS A FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL EVERY THREE YEARS FOR FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THE PROPOSED OVERALL GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.
