column55: This application is to request Section 5307 formula funds apportioned to Maine in the amount of $691558. The allocation programmed from FFY2021 is $194359 and the allocation from FFY2022 is $497199. These funds were apportioned to the following urbanized areas in Maine:$442853 Portland UZA (see split letter executed 6/29/22)$248705 Dover-Rochester and Portsmouth UZAsPURPOSE: The purpose of this award is to provide operating and capital assistance in the two southern Maine MPO regions: PACTS and KACTS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: PACTS Region: Funds will be used to cover all operating costs to continue a JARC operating project within the Portland UZA and to fund accessible vehicle purchases. KACTS Region: Funds will be used to continue to fund operating costs for demand-response transportation within the MPO area which consists of the Maine portions of the Dover-Rochester and Portsmouth urbanized areas.EXPECTED OUTCOMES: PACTS Region: Continued demand-response transportation for service eligible under the JARC program under Section 5307. Continued and improved demand-response transportation by adding newer accessible vehicles to the region.KACTS Region: Continuation of demand-response transportation in the region.INTENDED BENEFECIARIES: Residents and visitors to the region who will have continued transit options.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: The Regional Transportation Program will recieve capital assistance to procure two expansion vehicles to their fleet. York County Community Action Corporation will recieve funding to support a JARC operating project. The southern Maine Planning and Development Commission will recieve funding to support demand-response service in Southern Maine.

Planning and Architectural/Engineering Services; Dynamic Air Purification Treatment; Transportation Service Feasibility Study Facility Feasibility Study; Drug Alcohol Consortium and Training; Midland County Connection/City of Midland Transit StudyExpected Outcomes: Projects will increase the support the economic vitality of the metropolitan area especially by enabling global competitiveness productivity and efficiency safety and security of the transportation system for motorized and nonmotorized users accessibility and mobility protect and enhance the environment enhance integration and connectivity of systems promote efficient and effective system management emphasize the preservation of the existing transportation system improve the resiliency and reliability of the transportation system and provide assistance to the transit agencies in the state of Michigan.Intended Beneficiaries: Rural and Urban Transit Agencies cities and municipalities counties and the publicSubrecipient Activities: Transportation Needs Study and Service Plan Facility Construction Feasibility Study; Planning and Architectural/Engineering Services; Dynamic Air Purification Treatment; Transportation Service Feasibility Study Facility Feasibility Study; Drug Alcohol Consortium and Training; Midland County Connection/City of Midland Transit StudyPOP Statewide UWP FTA Approval Letter BCATS UWP and MATS UWP are attached.

column55: Project Title: Shuster Way Heritage Trail :::: Project Description: Extending from Fort Bedford Park in downtown Bedford to Old Bedford Village and Friendship Village. Bedford Borough, Bedford County  This project is for the construction of Shuster Way Heritage Trail in Bedford Borough and Bedford Township in Bedford County. The Shuster Way Heritage Trail parallels the Raystown Branch of the Juniata River with the trail starting at the southern end of the project located in Bedford Borough at the intersection of North Davidson Street and SR 4010 (Lincoln Way) and the trail head at the northern end of the project located in Bedford Township where the Raystown Branch of the Juniata River crosses Sawblade Road at Old Bedford Village approximately 0.02 miles west of its intersection with US Business 220 (North Richard Street). Two (2) pedestrian structures will be constructed as a part of this trail crossing an Unnamed Tributary to the Raystown Branch of the Juniata River and the Raystown Branch of the Juniata River. Approximately 1.80 miles of trail will be constructed adjacent to the Raystown Branch of the Juniata River as indicated on the approved drawings included in the bid package for STATE ROUTE 0000, SECTION BHT, in BEDFORD COUNTY, BEDFORD TOWNSHIP, BEDFORD BOROUGH at the locations indicated on the plan.
column90: ENHANCEMENT - SHUSTER WAY HERITAGE TRAIL - BEDFORD CO

column55: Purpose of the Award: This application requests a total of $9779002 in Section 5311 funds to cover various transit operational activities throughout the state. The total of $9318868 in FFY2022 funds includes the full FFY2022 5311 statewide apportionment of $9179646 and the full RTAP amount of $139222. In addition this application re-obligates $460134 in FFY2020 LAPSING statewide funds being de-obligated from prior award #SD-2020-007-01.Activities to be performed: $4424171 Operating Assistance for rural providers$3567793 Project Administration for rural providers$1247812 Intercity Bus (91% of the 15% ICB requirement d $1376946 to fund feeder services across the State)$139222 RTAP (training)$ 400004 State/Program Administration for SDDOT (51% of maximum allowable as calculated by SDDOT)$9779002 Total FTA funds (Note: The FY 2020 funds have been separated into different Projects from the FY 2022 funds due to accounting requirements. Projects #1-#4 are funded with FY 2022 funds; Projects #5 and #6 are those funded with FY 2020 funds.)Expected outcomes: This grant will assist transit agencies statewide in funding administrative and operating costs during FY2023. SDDOT will award to 5311 eligible subrecipients for projects throughout the state. Intended beneficiaries: The transit patrons and employees of various transit agencies throughout the state of South Dakota.Subrecipient Activities: This grant will fund administrative and operating costs as well as provide training and fund ICB admin and operating for the following subrecipients:Aberdeen Ride Line Brookings Area Transit Authority City of Brandon Community Transit of Watertown/Sisseton East Dakota Transit Palace Transit Peoples Transit River Cities Public Transit Rural Office of Community Service Standing Rock Public Transit Vermillion Public Transit West River (Prairie Hills Transit) and Yankton Transit. Other Information:- Local funds sources for each subrecipient is documented in the POP.- Required documentation including the Program of Projects (POP) STIP documentation and Governors ICB letter are attached. The Governors letter stating that the intercity bus service needs in the state are being met without using 15% minimum of the 5311 funds. SDDOT will meet their ICB needs utilizing ARP and 5311 funds for FFY2022. In addition SDDOT is awarding ICB funds to subrecipients for feeder services. - SDDOT uses the sliding scale percentages for Project Administration at 82.82% federal match and Operating at 51.76% federal match as approved by FHWA in accordance with Circular 9040.1G . RTAP and State Administration are funded at 100% Federal.

column55: This application is for 2022 formula funds to the Rural Areas of Texas: the Rural Transit Districts defined in the Texas Transportation Code Title 43 Chapter 458 and RTAP 5311(b) funds. The local match will be derived from local funds and TDCs.The Public Transportation Program managed by the Public Transportation Division (PTN) of Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT) was allocated 15000000 Transportation Development Credits (TDC) for distribution to eligible projects by the Texas Transportation Commission (commission) in Minute Order 116073 for state fiscal year 2022. The TDC letter dated 7/1/22 awards 800000 TDC to various agencies as match for capital projects funded with FY2022 federal Section 5311 Rural Area Grant Program funds. The funds will be used by transit agencies for general transportation services and capital purchases. Purpose of the Award: Funding for this 5311 Rural Areas grant will enable Texas transit districts to provide public transportation services in the rural areas of Texas. Funding will also allow transit providers to continue operating established transit routes and to add new services to aid communities.Activities to be performed: Operating assistance project administration vehicle preventive maintenance and repairs capital projects benefiting the rural area (e.g. vehicle procurement hardware and software solutions) state administration and training and technical assistance. Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to implement programs and services to create an environment of resilience for passengers employees and communities in rural areas of the state of Texas.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit and support mobility for rural areas communities transit riders and transit providers.Subrecipient Activities: Passenger transportation services to the general public using the most efficient combination of knowledge materials resources and technology. GENERAL FUNDS SUMMARYFY 2022 5311 Total Apportionment$60303948 Total 5311 funds:$50517853 Total 5311(b)(3) funds:$871180 Total 5311(f) funds:$8914915 State Administrative: $2100001 5311 funds applied for: $48417852 5311(b)(3) funds applied for: $871180 5311(f) funds applied for: $4872167Total funds applied for: $56261200Total 5311 amount to be applied for later: $0 Total 5311(b)(3) amount to be applied for later: $0 Total 5311(f) amount to be applied for later: $4042748 Total amount to be applied for later:$4042748
column56: 20.509: FORMULA GRANTS FOR RURAL AREAS AND TRIBAL TRANSIT PROGRAM
column90: AS PRESENTED IN THE CITY OF DEL RIO'S FY22 GRANT APPLICATION, THE CITY OF DEL RIO WILL PROVIDE PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION THROUGHOUT THE RURAL TRANSIT DISTRICT SERVICE AREA. THE CITY OF DEL RIO WILL PROVIDE DEMAND RESPONSE CURB-TO-CURB SERVICE IN VAL VERDE COUNTY. TRANSIT PROVIDER SHALL COMPLY WITH ARTICLE 12: PROJECT RECORDS AND REPORTS AND ARTICLE 13 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT REQUIRING PROCUREMENT AND PROJECT MILESTONES / QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS. WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME PERIOD SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) SETS A FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL EVERY THREE YEARS FOR FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THE PROPOSED OVERALL GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.

column55: This application is to request Section 5311 funds apportioned to the State of Kansas (UZA: 200000) in the amount of $16803066. Purpose: This application is to request FFY2020-2022 Section 5311 funds apportioned to the State of Kansas in the amount of $16802066.Budget Funding:2020.25.18.81 $122951842021.25.18.81 $ 42569492022.2J.18.R7 $ 249933Total Federal Amount: $16802066 Local/State Funding: $13548754Total Grant Amount: $30350820The State will be providing 20 of the local match with State Highway Funds. The remaining 20% match will be provided by the agencies general funds mill levy or other local funds. No federal funding is being used as match. All agencies and CTDs are verified in SAM before any payments are made to them. Activities to be performed: Operating Intercity Bus - provide continued transportation for their passengers. Project Admin - Provide administrative support to the transit agencies in the state. RTAP - Provide training and technical assistance to transit agencies in the state. State Admin - Will be used to cover expenses incurred to administer FTA programs. Expected outcomes: The funding for all of these projects will provide a needed boost to the transit agencies and their passengers. The RTAP project will centralize information and streamline processes that can be used by all the agencies and their passengers. Intended beneficiaries: It is expected that all of the projects will benefit anyone that uses transportation services in Kansas. Subrecipient Activities: Operating Intercity - Continue day to day services and utilize the additional funding to assist with additional expenses. RTAP - The University of Kansas Center for Research will provide assistance to transit agencies to better serve their customers.*Pre-award authority was selected because KDOT will enter into agreements with the CTDS the Intercity Bus Providers and KU for the period starting 7-1-22 in the amount of $15843067. The first two months of expenses are anticipated prior to execution of the award.

column55: Texas Department of Transportation 5339 BBF formula apportionments FY 2021 and FY 2022. These funds were distributed to the 36 subrecipients that represent Texas rural transit districts.RURAL TOTAL $7500000 TDC 1279516 July 6 2022 TDC letter awarding 1400000 TDCs attached.FY21 $3500000FY22 $4000000 The funds will be used by 5339 eligible subrecipients to support capital projects such as the purchase of new and replacement fleet new and replacement support vehicles shop equipment computer hardware and software vehicle overhauls facility rehab/renovations and other miscellaneous equipment eligible under the 5339 BBF formula program. Purpose of Award: 5339 BBF funding will enable the Texas rural transit providers to keep their equipment facilities and fleet in a state of good repair for use in rural portions of Texas. Activities to be performed: Fleet replacement facility design MISC equipment purchases fleet expansions and other eligible 5339 program activities. Vehicles being replaced have or will meet useful life prior to disposition.Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to keep their capital items in a state of good repair by rehabilitating and replacing older equipment fleet and facilities.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit Texans living in rural areas rural communities transit riders and providers.Subrecipient Activities: The rural transit districts that receive these funds will use the funds to benefit the general public by ensuring the capital items they interact with are in a good state of repair and in condition to serve their purpose.STIP pages: Pages 1289 and 1292

column55: This application is for 2022 formula funds to the Rural Areas of Texas: the Rural Transit Districts defined in the Texas Transportation Code Title 43 Chapter 458 and RTAP 5311(b) funds. The local match will be derived from local funds and TDCs.The Public Transportation Program managed by the Public Transportation Division (PTN) of Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT) was allocated 15000000 Transportation Development Credits (TDC) for distribution to eligible projects by the Texas Transportation Commission (commission) in Minute Order 116073 for state fiscal year 2022. The TDC letter dated 7/1/22 awards 800000 TDC to various agencies as match for capital projects funded with FY2022 federal Section 5311 Rural Area Grant Program funds. The funds will be used by transit agencies for general transportation services and capital purchases. Purpose of the Award: Funding for this 5311 Rural Areas grant will enable Texas transit districts to provide public transportation services in the rural areas of Texas. Funding will also allow transit providers to continue operating established transit routes and to add new services to aid communities.Activities to be performed: Operating assistance project administration vehicle preventive maintenance and repairs capital projects benefiting the rural area (e.g. vehicle procurement hardware and software solutions) state administration and training and technical assistance. Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to implement programs and services to create an environment of resilience for passengers employees and communities in rural areas of the state of Texas.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit and support mobility for rural areas communities transit riders and transit providers.Subrecipient Activities: Passenger transportation services to the general public using the most efficient combination of knowledge materials resources and technology. GENERAL FUNDS SUMMARYFY 2022 5311 Total Apportionment$60303948 Total 5311 funds:$50517853 Total 5311(b)(3) funds:$871180 Total 5311(f) funds:$8914915 State Administrative: $2100001 5311 funds applied for: $48417852 5311(b)(3) funds applied for: $871180 5311(f) funds applied for: $4872167Total funds applied for: $56261200Total 5311 amount to be applied for later: $0 Total 5311(b)(3) amount to be applied for later: $0 Total 5311(f) amount to be applied for later: $4042748 Total amount to be applied for later:$4042748

column24: OFFICE OF BUDGET AND POLICY(TBP)
column55: This application is for 2022 formula funds to the Rural Areas of Texas: the Rural Transit Districts defined in the Texas Transportation Code Title 43 Chapter 458 and RTAP 5311(b) funds. The local match will be derived from local funds and TDCs.The Public Transportation Program managed by the Public Transportation Division (PTN) of Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT) was allocated 15000000 Transportation Development Credits (TDC) for distribution to eligible projects by the Texas Transportation Commission (commission) in Minute Order 116073 for state fiscal year 2022. The TDC letter dated 7/1/22 awards 800000 TDC to various agencies as match for capital projects funded with FY2022 federal Section 5311 Rural Area Grant Program funds. The funds will be used by transit agencies for general transportation services and capital purchases. Purpose of the Award: Funding for this 5311 Rural Areas grant will enable Texas transit districts to provide public transportation services in the rural areas of Texas. Funding will also allow transit providers to continue operating established transit routes and to add new services to aid communities.Activities to be performed: Operating assistance project administration vehicle preventive maintenance and repairs capital projects benefiting the rural area (e.g. vehicle procurement hardware and software solutions) state administration and training and technical assistance. Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to implement programs and services to create an environment of resilience for passengers employees and communities in rural areas of the state of Texas.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit and support mobility for rural areas communities transit riders and transit providers.Subrecipient Activities: Passenger transportation services to the general public using the most efficient combination of knowledge materials resources and technology. GENERAL FUNDS SUMMARYFY 2022 5311 Total Apportionment$60303948 Total 5311 funds:$50517853 Total 5311(b)(3) funds:$871180 Total 5311(f) funds:$8914915 State Administrative: $2100001 5311 funds applied for: $48417852 5311(b)(3) funds applied for: $871180 5311(f) funds applied for: $4872167Total funds applied for: $56261200Total 5311 amount to be applied for later: $0 Total 5311(b)(3) amount to be applied for later: $0 Total 5311(f) amount to be applied for later: $4042748 Total amount to be applied for later:$4042748
column56: 20.509: FORMULA GRANTS FOR RURAL AREAS AND TRIBAL TRANSIT PROGRAM
column90: AS PRESENTED IN EAST TEXAS COUNCIL OF GOVERNMENTS' (ETCOG) FY22 GRANT APPLICATION, ETCOG WILL PROVIDE PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION THROUGHOUT THE RURAL TRANSIT DISTRICT SERVICE AREA. ETCOG WILL PROVIDE DEMAND RESPONSE SERVICE IN THE RURAL AREAS OF ANDERSON, CAMP, CHEROKEE, GREGG, HARRIS, HENDERSON, MARION, PANOLA, RAINS, RUSK, SMITH, UPSHUR, WOOD AND VAN ZANDT. TRANSIT PROVIDER SHALL COMPLY WITH ARTICLE 12: PROJECT RECORDS AND REPORTS AND ARTICLE 13 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT REQUIRING PROCUREMENT AND PROJECT MILESTONES / QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS. WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME PERIOD SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) SETS A FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL EVERY THREE YEARS FOR FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THE PROPOSED OVERALL GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.

column28: 0001: URBANIZED AREA PROGRAMS;0016: BUS AND BUS FACILITIES FORMULA GRANTS
column55: Texas Department of Transportation 5339 BBF formula apportionments FY 2021 and FY 2022. These funds were distributed to the 36 subrecipients that represent Texas rural transit districts.RURAL TOTAL $7500000 TDC 1279516 July 6 2022 TDC letter awarding 1400000 TDCs attached.FY21 $3500000FY22 $4000000 The funds will be used by 5339 eligible subrecipients to support capital projects such as the purchase of new and replacement fleet new and replacement support vehicles shop equipment computer hardware and software vehicle overhauls facility rehab/renovations and other miscellaneous equipment eligible under the 5339 BBF formula program. Purpose of Award: 5339 BBF funding will enable the Texas rural transit providers to keep their equipment facilities and fleet in a state of good repair for use in rural portions of Texas. Activities to be performed: Fleet replacement facility design MISC equipment purchases fleet expansions and other eligible 5339 program activities. Vehicles being replaced have or will meet useful life prior to disposition.Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to keep their capital items in a state of good repair by rehabilitating and replacing older equipment fleet and facilities.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit Texans living in rural areas rural communities transit riders and providers.Subrecipient Activities: The rural transit districts that receive these funds will use the funds to benefit the general public by ensuring the capital items they interact with are in a good state of repair and in condition to serve their purpose.STIP pages: Pages 1289 and 1292

column28: 0001: URBANIZED AREA PROGRAMS;0010: SENIORS AND PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES;0017: IIJA ACT, 2021
column55: This application is for 2022 formula funds for the 5310 demographics statewide: as defined in the Texas Transportation Code Title 43 Chapter 461. These funds will be recommended for award statewide to 39 small urban and rural transit districts private non-profit agencies governmental entities and local public agencies to the Texas Transportation Commission on July 12 2022. TDC letter dated 6/24/2022 attached.The funds will be used by 5310 providers for transportation services and capital purchases that serve Seniors and Individuals with disabilities to overcome transportation barriers.Purpose of the Award: Funding for section 5310 grant will enable Texas transit districts to provide public transportation services in both the rural and small urban areas of Texas. Funding will allow transit providers to continue operating established transit services and add new or expanded service to aid the growing 5310 population. Activities to be performed: Operating assistance project administration vehicle preventive maintenance and repairs capital projects benefiting the rural and small urban area (e.g. vehicle procurement hardware and software solutions state administration and mobility management 3rd Party contract services and technical assistance.) Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to implement 5310 programs and services to create an environment of resilience for passengers employees and communities in both rural and small urban areas of the state of Texas Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit seniors and individuals with disabilities by supporting mobility for rural and small urban areas communities transit riders and transit providers. Texas has the largest number of individuals with disabilities of all the states and 17% of the senior population lives in the 177 rural counties in Texas. Over half of seniors in Texas have one or more disabilities. Subrecipient Activities: 5310 Passenger transportation services to the public using the most efficient combination of knowledge materials resources and technology. FY2022 Full Apportionment: $11507861Funds Available: $11507861Non-Traditional State Administrative: $1150786 The amount of FY2022 non-traditional funds awarded does not exceed the 45% maximum. Total available for projects: $10357075 FY22 Total Small Urban apportionment: $5828383 Total State Admin applied for: $69412Traditional Small Urban projects applied for: $624707 Total Small Urban funds applied for: $694119 (SU projects +10% admin) Total obligated Small Urban traditional funds are 82% vs non traditional representing 18%Total Small Urban remaining funds to apply for later: $5134264 FY22 Total Rural apportionment: $5679478State Administrative Rural: $341988 Total Rural projects applied for: $3419883 Total rural funds applied for: $3761871 (Rural projects + 10% admin) Total obligated Rural traditional funds are 88% vs non traditional representing 12%FY22 Total Remaining Funds to be Applied for Later: $1917607 Total FY22 Rural/Small Urban funds to apply for later: $7051871 The Texas Department of Transportation is a Designated Recipient. The minimum of 55 percent of funding for traditional 5310 program type projects has been met. TxDOT certifies that the funds were awarded to subrecipients were awarded on a fair and equitable basis and the projects have been derived from a regionally coordinated public transit-human services transportation plan. To the extent feasible services are coordinated with transportation services provided by other federal agencies.
column56: 20.513: ENHANCED MOBILITY OF SENIORS AND INDIVIDUALS WITH DISABILITIES
column90: REAL 5310 PROJECT WILL PROVIDE CONTINUITY OF SERVICE AND ENHANCE EXISTING SERVICES TO SUPPORT A MORE ROBUST AND INNOVATIVE TRANSPORTATION SYSTEM IN THE NINE (9) RURAL COUNTIES OF THE COASTAL BEND INCLUDING ARANSAS COUNTY, BEE COUNTY, BROOKS COUNTY, DUVAL COUNTY, JIM HOGG COUNTY, JIM WELLS COUNTY, LIVE OAK COUNTY, REFUGIO COUNTY AND SAN PATRICIO COUNTY. PROJECT INCLUDES ROLLING STOCK EXPANSION OF ONE (1) LOW FLOOR ENTRY ADA ACCESSIBLE UNIT IN YEAR ONE. Â  TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) SETS A FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL EVERY THREE YEARS FOR FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THE OVERALL GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. column55: This application is for 2022 formula funds to the Rural Areas of Texas: the Rural Transit Districts defined in the Texas Transportation Code Title 43 Chapter 458 and RTAP 5311(b) funds. The local match will be derived from local funds and TDCs.The Public Transportation Program managed by the Public Transportation Division (PTN) of Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT) was allocated 15000000 Transportation Development Credits (TDC) for distribution to eligible projects by the Texas Transportation Commission (commission) in Minute Order 116073 for state fiscal year 2022. The TDC letter dated 7/1/22 awards 800000 TDC to various agencies as match for capital projects funded with FY2022 federal Section 5311 Rural Area Grant Program funds. The funds will be used by transit agencies for general transportation services and capital purchases. Purpose of the Award: Funding for this 5311 Rural Areas grant will enable Texas transit districts to provide public transportation services in the rural areas of Texas. Funding will also allow transit providers to continue operating established transit routes and to add new services to aid communities.Activities to be performed: Operating assistance project administration vehicle preventive maintenance and repairs capital projects benefiting the rural area (e.g. vehicle procurement hardware and software solutions) state administration and training and technical assistance. Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to implement programs and services to create an environment of resilience for passengers employees and communities in rural areas of the state of Texas.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit and support mobility for rural areas communities transit riders and transit providers.Subrecipient Activities: Passenger transportation services to the general public using the most efficient combination of knowledge materials resources and technology. REAL WILL PROVIDE DEMAND RESPONSE SERVICE IN THE RURAL AREAS OF ARANSAS, BEE, BROOKS, DUVAL, JIM HOGG, JIM WELLS, LIVE OAK, REFUGIO AND SAN PATRICIO COUNTIES. RANSIT PROVIDER SHALL COMPLY WITH ARTICLE 12: PROJECT RECORDS AND REPORTS AND ARTICLE 13 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT REQUIRING PROCUREMENT AND PROJECT MILESTONES / QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS. WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME PERIOD SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) SETS A FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL EVERY THREE YEARS FOR FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THE PROPOSED OVERALL GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.

column55: Funding for all projects included in this grant application is provided by the following apportionment years and Urbanized areas (UZAs).Section 5307 FFY 2022 Thousand Oaks (UZA #61440): $1459217Section 5307 FFY 2022 Oxnard (UZA #60860): $3626823Section 5307 FFY 2021 Camarillo (UZA #063680): $701522Section 5307 FFY 2022 Camarillo (UZA #063680): $759185Section 5307 FFY 2022 Simi Valley (#062710): $272551Overall grant fundingTotal Federal Funds: $6819298Total Local Match: $3834747 (Transportation Development Act [state sales tax for transportation] city general funds)Total Project Cost: $10654045A portion of the local share is provided by Transportation Development Credits. Because Transportation Development Credits do not allocate actual money toward project expenses an increased federal share is reflected where the credits are applied.VCTC is hereby submitting this grant application in support of the following projects for capital planning and operations:1) Capital Projects for VCTC and Subrecipients FY 2022 FundsThe grant applies $1940325 in FY 22 Section 5307 funds for preventive maintenance ADA service capital contracting cost capital infrastructure mobility management and Jobs Access and Reverse Commute with further details provided in the Project Description.2) Planning Projects for VCTC and CamarilloThe grant applies $1199000 in FY 22 Section 5307 funds for planning with further details provided in the Project Description.3) Operating Assistance for VCTC and Subrecipients FY 2022 FundsThe grant applies $2858451 in FY 22 Section 5307 funds for operating assistance with further details provided in the Project Description.4) Camarillo Preventive Maintenance FY 2021 FundsThe grant applies $604800 in FY 21 Section 5307 funds for preventive maintenance with further details provided in the Project Description.5) Camarillo Operating Assistance FY 2021 FundsThe grant applies $96722 in FY 21 Section 5307 funds for operating assistance with further details provided in the Project Description.Purpose: The purpose of this award is to provide $2545125 to VCTC and subrecipients for for preventive maintenance ADA service capital contracting cost mobility management capital infrastructure and Jobs Access Reverse Commute (JARC); $1199000 to VCTC and Camarillo for planning; and $2955173 to VCTC and Subrecipients for operating assistance.Activities to be performed: Funds will be used to cover eligible operating expenses such as driver salaries fuel maintenance on-demand rideshare transit vehicle leases etc. to continue transit operations.Expected outcomes: Funding will permit VCTC to continue to provide operations that would otherwise have to be cut due to lack of funding.Intended beneficiaries: VCTC and the riders that rely on its services will benefit from continued service permitting workers to get to work and riders to get to essential services.Subrecipients: The following are providers of transit service operators: MV Transportation First Transit and RATP-DEV.Suballocation Letter:Recipient organization is the Designated Recipient and can apply for and receive these apportioned funds. This Application is consistent with the suballocation identified in the Split Letter dated April 11 2022 and attached to this application. In keeping with the IIJA set aside for safety for areas over 200000 this grant will spend a minimum of $38145.30 representing 0.0075% of the Oxnard and Thousand Oaks funds for keeping vehicles safe and safety maintenance as part of ALI 11.7A.00 VCTC Intercity Preventive Maintenance.

column55: EARP
column90:
THE FEDERAL HIGHWAY ADMINISTRATION (FHWA) AND THE NATIONAL ASPHALT PAVEMENT ASSOCIATION (NAPA) SHARE A GOAL TO SUPPORT AND PROMOTE SUSTAINABLE PRACTICES, INCLUDING THE USE OF RECYCLED MATERIALS AND WARM-MIX ASPHALT (WMA). THE USE OF RECYCLED MATERIALS, SUCH AS RECLAIMED ASPHALT PAVEMENT (RAP) AND RECLAIMED ASPHALT SHINGLES (RAS), IN NEW ASPHALT PAVEMENTS CONSERVES NATURAL RESOURCES, REDUCES ASPHALT MIXTURE COST, REDUCES THE AMOUNT OF MATERIAL GOING INTO LANDFILLS, AND REDUCES ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS OF PRODUCTION AND CONSTRUCTION. THE USE OF WMA ALSO REDUCES THE ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS OF ASPHALT MIXTURE PRODUCTION, WHILE AT THE SAME TIME IMPROVES WORKABILITY.    
 THE FHWA AND NAPA HAVE COLLABORATED ON THE PUBLICATION OF NAPA IS-138, ASPHALT INDUSTRY SURVEY ON RECYCLED MATERIALS AND WARM-MIX ASPHALT USAGE, THAT QUANTIFIES THE CURRENT STATE-OF-THE-PRACTICE OF RAP, RAS, WMA AND OTHER RECYCLING TECHNIQUES (CIR, CCPR, FDR, AND HIR) USAGE IN THE U.S ON AN ANNUAL BASIS. 
 OBJECTIVE
 THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS STATEMENT OF WORK IS TO SUPPORT PUBLICATION AND COMMUNICATION OF THE 2021 EDITION OF NAPA IS-138.
 TASKS
 1.ESTABLISH AN AGREEMENT WITH NAPA TO:
 A.CONDUCT A REVIEW AND UPDATE OF THE QUESTION SET HISTORICALLY USED TO PERFORM THE SURVEY IN THE FOURTH QUARTER OF 2021 WORKING WITH FHWA. 
 B.PERFORM A SURVEY OF THE ASPHALT INDUSTRY USING THE METHODS HISTORICALLY EMPLOYED TO CAPTURE, RAP, RAS, WMA AND IN-PLACE RECYCLE DATA IN FIRST AND SECOND QUARTER OF 2022.
 C.COMPILE AND ANALYZE THE SURVEY FINDING INTO A SUMMARY REPORT THAT WILL BE 508 COMPLIANT AND TITLED, NAPA IS-138, ASPHALT INDUSTRY SURVEY ON RECYCLED MATERIALS AND WARM-MIX ASPHALT USAGE, 2021. IN ADDITION TO UPDATING THE SECTION SUMMARIZING THE TRENDS OVER THE PERIOD 2010 TO 2021, THE REPORT WILL CONTINUE TO INCLUDE ADDENDUM C AND THE SECTION OF THE REPORT FOCUSED ON CARBON FOOTPRINT REDUCTION (GHG EMISSION AND ENERGY REDUCTION) FROM USE OF WMA AND RAP/RAS. THE REPORT SHALL BE 508 COMPLIANT. UNR WILL COMPLETE 508 COMPLIANCE EFFORTS FOR THE ANNUAL REPORT. 
 D.PREPARE AN APPROXIMATELY 30-MINUTE POWERPOINT PRESENTATION THAT WILL BE USED TO ASSIST WITH PROMOTING UNDERSTANDING AND USE OF THE POSITIVE OBSERVATIONS IN THE FINDINGS.
 E.HOST AND RECORD A WEBINAR FREE TO ASPHALT INDUSTRY STAKEHOLDERS WITH REQUIRED REGISTRATION SO PARTICIPATION CAN BE REPORTED IN THE FIRST QUARTER OF 2023.
 F.POST THE RECORDED WEBINAR SO IT MAY BE VIEWED ONLINE AT NO COST AND CAPTURE ANALYTICS ON THE VIEWERSHIP OF RECORDED WEBINAR FOR 1 YEAR IN THE FIRST QUARTER OF 2023.
 G.ALLOW FREE DOWNLOAD OF THE REPORT FROM THE NAPA STORE AND REPORT THE NUMBER OF DOWNLOADS DURING 2023.  
 H.INCLUDE AN ARTICLE ON THE REPORT IN ASPHALT PAVEMENT MAGAZINE IN 2023. 
 I.INCLUDE NOTIFICATION OF THE REPORT AND A LINK TO IT, THE WEBINAR AND THE WEBINAR RECORDING IN ACTION NEWS DURING 2023 AS WELL AS A PRESS RELEASE.  
 2.UNR WILL COMPLETE 508 COMPLIANCE EFFORTS FOR THE REPORT.
 INTENDED OUTCOMES: NAPA IS-138, ASPHALT INDUSTRY SURVEY ON RECYCLED MATERIALS AND WARM-MIX ASPHALT USAGE 2021, A RELATED POWERPOINT PRESENTATION SUMMARIZING THE FINDS, HOSTING AND RECORDING OF AN INDUSTRY STAKEHOLDER WEBINAR PRESENTING THE FINDS, AND MULTIPLE COMMUNICATIONS OF THE REPORT AND WEBINAR INCLUDING AN ARTICLE IN ASPHALT PAVEMENT MAGAZINE, ACTION NEWS UPDATES AND A PRESS RELEASE. 
 PERFORMANCE MEASURE: NUMBER OF PARTICIPANTS IN THE STAKEHOLDER WEBINAR, NUMBER OF TIMES IS-138, 2021 IS DOWNLOADED, NUMBER OF TIMES IS-138, 2021 IS REFERENCED AND ANALYTICS FROM THE NAPA WEBSITE.

column55: The purpose of the Weatherization Assistance Program is to increase the energy efficiency of dwellings owned and occupied by low-income persons, reduce their total residential expenditures, and improve their health and safety. The priority population for the Weatherization Assistance Program is persons who are particularly vulnerable such as the elderly, persons with disabilities, families with children, high residential energy users, and households with high-energy burden.

column31: RAIL AND PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION, VIRGINIA DEPARTMENT OF
column55: The Virginia Department of Rail and Public Transportation (VDRPT) is applying for FFY 2022 Section 5303 Metropolitan Planning Program (MPP) funds in the amount of $3408991 to support the funding of 14 Metropolitan Planning Organization (MPO) Unified Planning Work Programs (UPWPs) throughout the state.VDRPT is also applying for FFY 2022 Section 5304 funds in the amount of $765356 for statewide transportation planning. The Statewide Planning and Research (SPR) Work Program is attached in TrAMS and includes a description and funding amount for each of the plans and studies listed in the ALIs.The non-Federal share will be provided by the respective metropolitan areas across the Commonwealth and the Commonwealth of Virginia. The FTA has approved the Unified Planning Work Program (UPWP) for MWCOG on June 1 2022 the only large urbanized area and air quality non-attainment or maintenance area remaining in the Commonwealth of Virginia. Funding in this application reflects what has been approved in the MPOs UPWPs. Approval letters and UPWPs are attached in TrAMS under Application Documents.Purpose: The purpose of this award is to support the funding of 14 Metropolitan Planning Organizations (MPO) so that they can carry out the activities in their FY2023 Unified Planning Work Programs (UPWP). It is also to support the planning activities of the Commonwealth of Virginia.Activities to be performed: Funds will be used to cover the activities in the approved UPWPs of our 14 MPOs which include general planning and programming short and long-term planning TIP development transit studies human service transportation coordination and addressing safety and security issues. The Commonwealth will also help transit agencies develop Transit Development Programs (TDPs) and Transit Strategic Plans (TSPs). Studies and surveys to help improve transportation services in the Commonwealth will also be funded.Expected outcome: Funding ensures the MPOs and the Commonwealth are carrying out transportation planning activities to comply with Federal transportation planning regulations.Intended beneficiaries: All citizens of the Commonwealth of Virginia that rely on efficient safe and effective transportation services and facilities to get them where they need to go.Subrecipient activities: Funds will be given to the following MPOs to cover the activities in their approved UPWPs: Roanoke Valley MPO Hampton Roads TPO Richmond Regional TPO Tri-Cities MPO Washington D.C. MPO (Metropolitan Washington Council of Governments or MWCOG) Fredericksburg MPO Harrisonburg-Rockingham MPO Staunton-Augusta-Waynesboro MPO Charlottesville MPO Bristol MPO Kingsport MPO Winchester MPO Lynchburg MPO and New River Valley MPO. Funds will also be given to the Thomas Jefferson PDC to conduct a study their regional transit and the Roanoke Valley-Alleghany Regional Commission to conduct a survey to better understand the transportation usage in their region.

column55: Texas Department of Transportation 5339 BBF formula apportionments FY 2021 and FY 2022. These funds were distributed to the 36 subrecipients that represent Texas rural transit districts.RURAL TOTAL $7500000 TDC 1279516 July 6 2022 TDC letter awarding 1400000 TDCs attached.FY21 $3500000FY22 $4000000 The funds will be used by 5339 eligible subrecipients to support capital projects such as the purchase of new and replacement fleet new and replacement support vehicles shop equipment computer hardware and software vehicle overhauls facility rehab/renovations and other miscellaneous equipment eligible under the 5339 BBF formula program. Purpose of Award: 5339 BBF funding will enable the Texas rural transit providers to keep their equipment facilities and fleet in a state of good repair for use in rural portions of Texas. Activities to be performed: Fleet replacement facility design MISC equipment purchases fleet expansions and other eligible 5339 program activities. Vehicles being replaced have or will meet useful life prior to disposition.Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to keep their capital items in a state of good repair by rehabilitating and replacing older equipment fleet and facilities.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit Texans living in rural areas rural communities transit riders and providers.Subrecipient Activities: The rural transit districts that receive these funds will use the funds to benefit the general public by ensuring the capital items they interact with are in a good state of repair and in condition to serve their purpose.STIP pages: Pages 1289 and 1292
column56: 20.526: BUSES AND BUS FACILITIES FORMULA, COMPETITIVE, AND LOW OR NO EMISSIONS PROGRAMS
column90: THE FUNDS SHALL BE USED FOR RURAL AREA TRANSIT CAPITAL PROJECTS IN THE SUBRECIPIENT'S SERVICE AREA THAT MAY REPLACE, REHABILITATE AND PURCHASE BUSES AND RELATED EQUIPMENT AND TO CONSTRUCT BUS-RELATED FACILITIES INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO TECHNOLOGICAL CHANGES OR INNOVATIONS TO MODIFY LOW OR NO EMISSION VEHICLES OR FACILITIES. TRANSIT PROVIDER SHALL COMPLY WITH ARTICLE 12: PROJECT RECORDS AND REPORTS AND ARTICLE 13 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT REQUIRING PROCUREMENT AND PROJECT MILESTONES / QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS. WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME PERIOD SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT OF FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.

column55: This application is for 2022 formula funds to the Rural Areas of Texas: the Rural Transit Districts defined in the Texas Transportation Code Title 43 Chapter 458 and RTAP 5311(b) funds. The local match will be derived from local funds and TDCs.The Public Transportation Program managed by the Public Transportation Division (PTN) of Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT) was allocated 15000000 Transportation Development Credits (TDC) for distribution to eligible projects by the Texas Transportation Commission (commission) in Minute Order 116073 for state fiscal year 2022. The TDC letter dated 7/1/22 awards 800000 TDC to various agencies as match for capital projects funded with FY2022 federal Section 5311 Rural Area Grant Program funds. The funds will be used by transit agencies for general transportation services and capital purchases. Purpose of the Award: Funding for this 5311 Rural Areas grant will enable Texas transit districts to provide public transportation services in the rural areas of Texas. Funding will also allow transit providers to continue operating established transit routes and to add new services to aid communities.Activities to be performed: Operating assistance project administration vehicle preventive maintenance and repairs capital projects benefiting the rural area (e.g. vehicle procurement hardware and software solutions) state administration and training and technical assistance. Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to implement programs and services to create an environment of resilience for passengers employees and communities in rural areas of the state of Texas.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit and support mobility for rural areas communities transit riders and transit providers.Subrecipient Activities: Passenger transportation services to the general public using the most efficient combination of knowledge materials resources and technology. GENERAL FUNDS SUMMARYFY 2022 5311 Total Apportionment$60303948 Total 5311 funds:$50517853 Total 5311(b)(3) funds:$871180 Total 5311(f) funds:$8914915 State Administrative: $2100001 5311 funds applied for: $48417852 5311(b)(3) funds applied for: $871180 5311(f) funds applied for: $4872167Total funds applied for: $56261200Total 5311 amount to be applied for later: $0 Total 5311(b)(3) amount to be applied for later: $0 Total 5311(f) amount to be applied for later: $4042748 Total amount to be applied for later:$4042748

column55: Project Title: Chester Valley Trail Ext :::: Project Description: Chester Valley Trail Extension Upper Merion Township & Bridgeport, Norristown Boroughs from approximately South Gulph Road to approximately DeKalb Street at Washington Ave. The Chester Valley Trail Extension is intended principally for transportation purposes, including trips to work, school, retail, and services.  The Extension will link to the Chester Valley Trail, connecting residential communities with major employment, school, retail, and service centers in King of Prussia, Bridgeport, and Norristown Boroughs as well as major employments, schools, retail, and service centers in Great Valley and Exton.  The Extension will also unite with the Schuylkill River Trail in Norristown and through this, link two trails into and through Philadelphia with eventual connections to the East Coast Greenway to provide an extensive trail network through the DVRPC region. This is a multiuse trail project to construct 3.9 miles of trail that has work on two structures to allow bike/ pedestrian traffic and 2 new structures along with 6 retaining walls that are part of the two new structures. Design-Build activities are limited to the 2 new structures and 6 new retaining walls design and the ADA curb ramps design.

column55: The purpose of the Weatherization Assistance Program is to increase the energy efficiency of dwellings owned and occupied by low-income persons, reduce their total residential expenditures, and improve their health and safety. The priority population for the Weatherization Assistance Program is persons who are particularly vulnerable such as the elderly, persons with disabilities, families with children, high residential energy users, and households with high-energy burden.

column55: Application Executive SummaryOVERVIEW The Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT) is responsible for oversight and administration of the Federal Transit Administrations (FTA) State Planning and Research Program (SPRP) authorized at 49 United States Code (U.S.C.) 5305 for the State of Texas. This application is for FY 2022 funds totaling $2597003. The department requests TDC match of 519402 in the attached letter. This work program covers the period of September 1 2022 to December 31 2027. It defines the various planning research and oversight activities programmed by TxDOTs Public Transportation Division (PTN). SUMMARY The work program is divided into two program areas other activities are not currently funded in this grant application and may be amended or added under a budget revision. (1) Short Range Transit Planning and (2) Other Activities. TxDOT will develop plans and programs to implement the Surface Transportation Act and continue implementation of state statutes which call for a coordinated public transit-human services transportation network. Individual tasks in the two program areas include: Program Area 1: Short Range Transit Planning -Public transportation service coordination -Data collection performance measures and statistical reporting -Public Transportation Management System General planning and development assistance Program Area 2: Other Activities -Public transportation training -Public transportation news and information -Public Transportation Advisory Committee supportPurpose of the Award: Funding for this 5304 grant will enable Texas lead agencies transit districts and the state to improve short range planning efforts.Activities to be performed: Coordination planning activities pilot projects research and other efforts that support short range planning in Texas. Expected Outcomes: Improved coordination innovation knowledge of current conditions and research on how to improve mobility by creating safe clean and reliable public transportation in Texas. Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit and support mobility for rural and urban transit users transit providers and their communities. Subrecipient Activities: Short range planning research pilot projects and other activities using the most efficient combination of knowledge materials resources and technology.
column56: 20.505: METROPOLITAN TRANSPORTATION PLANNING AND STATE AND NON-METROPOLITAN PLANNING AND RESEARCH
column90: THIS PROJECT COVERS PLAN PRELIMINARY ENGINEERING, INITIAL DESIGN, AND ENVIRONMENTAL WORK FOR THE ADMINISTRATIVE/MAINTENANCE FACILITY, DOWNTOWN TRANSFER FACILITY, AND MOBILITY HUBS. THE PENDING FACILITY FEASIBILITY STUDY WILL IDENTIFY A PRIMARY AND SECONDARY LOCATION FOR EACH OF THE ADMINISTRATION/MAINTENANCE FACILITY, DOWNTOWN TRANSFER FACILITY, AND MULTIPLE LOCATIONS FOR POTENTIAL MOBILITY HUBS. THE PRELIMINARY ENGINEERING, INITIAL DESIGN, AND ENVIRONMENTAL WORK WILL BE CONDUCTED BY A CONSULTANT THAT WILL BE HIRED THROUGH A COMPETITIVE PROCUREMENT PROCESS. THE CONSULTANT WILL USE THE DATA FROM THE FACILITY FEASIBILITY STUDY AND THE COMPREHENSIVE OPERATIONAL ANALYSIS (COA) TO DETERMINE WHAT IS SUITABLE FOR THE PROPOSED LOCATIONS OF EACH FACILITY. SUBRECIPIENT SHALL COMPLY WITH ARTICLE 12: PROJECT RECORDS AND REPORTS AND ARTICLE 13 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT REQUIRING PROCUREMENT AND PROJECT MILESTONES / QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS. WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME PERIOD SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE GRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) SETS A FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL EVERY THREE YEARS FOR FUNDS EXPENDED BY SUBRECIPIENTS. THE PROPOSED OVERALL GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN SUBRECIPIENTS SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.

HOTCOG WILL PROVIDE DEMAND RESPONSE SERVICE IN THE COUNTIES OF BOSQUE, FALLS, FREESTONE, HILL AND LIMESTONE. TRANSIT PROVIDER SHALL COMPLY WITH ARTICLE 12: PROJECT RECORDS AND REPORTS AND ARTICLE 13 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT REQUIRING PROCUREMENT AND PROJECT MILESTONES / QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS. WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME PERIOD SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) SETS A FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL EVERY THREE YEARS FOR FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THE PROPOSED OVERALL GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.

column55: Project Title: Citywide ADA Ramps 2 :::: Project Description: Philadelphia The design and construction of ADA ramps that were transitioned from other Federal Aid projects, including, but not limited to, Center City SE Quad Signals (MPMS #17655), Passyunk Ave Signals (MPMS #16987), 52nd St. Streetscape (MPMS #17829), Citywide Resurfacing 103 (MPMS #91837), and various streetscape projects; and as well as ramps located on Center City Philadelphia Federal Aid routes that were repaved with local funding. The ramps would have typically been included as design build items in the project contracts, however, in some instances, the urban context of the ADA ramp locations warrants further coordination or study.  To allow the original construction projects to proceed in a timely fashion, these ramps were pulled from the original construction contracts, and will now be addressed as part of this transition project.  This will allow the City to design and construct the ramps to current ADA requirements while providing for stairs, cellar doors, unique paving materials, adjacent historic properties and other considerations as necessary.
column90: AMERICANS WITH DISABILITIES ACT RAMPS - PHILADELPHIA CO

The project will also change the typical section of the roadway from being two lanes in each direction to one lane of traffic in each direction with a bicycle lane. column31: RAIL AND PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION, VIRGINIA DEPARTMENT OF
column55: The Virginia Department of Rail and Public Transportation (VDRPT) is applying for FFY 2022 Section 5303 Metropolitan Planning Program (MPP) funds in the amount of $3408991 to support the funding of 14 Metropolitan Planning Organization (MPO) Unified Planning Work Programs (UPWPs) throughout the state.VDRPT is also applying for FFY 2022 Section 5304 funds in the amount of $765356 for statewide transportation planning. The Statewide Planning and Research (SPR) Work Program is attached in TrAMS and includes a description and funding amount for each of the plans and studies listed in the ALIs.The non-Federal share will be provided by the respective metropolitan areas across the Commonwealth and the Commonwealth of Virginia. The FTA has approved the Unified Planning Work Program (UPWP) for MWCOG on June 1 2022 the only large urbanized area and air quality non-attainment or maintenance area remaining in the Commonwealth of Virginia. Funding in this application reflects what has been approved in the MPOs UPWPs. Approval letters and UPWPs are attached in TrAMS under Application Documents.Purpose: The purpose of this award is to support the funding of 14 Metropolitan Planning Organizations (MPO) so that they can carry out the activities in their FY2023 Unified Planning Work Programs (UPWP). It is also to support the planning activities of the Commonwealth of Virginia.Activities to be performed: Funds will be used to cover the activities in the approved UPWPs of our 14 MPOs which include general planning and programming short and long-term planning TIP development transit studies human service transportation coordination and addressing safety and security issues. The Commonwealth will also help transit agencies develop Transit Development Programs (TDPs) and Transit Strategic Plans (TSPs). Studies and surveys to help improve transportation services in the Commonwealth will also be funded.Expected outcome: Funding ensures the MPOs and the Commonwealth are carrying out transportation planning activities to comply with Federal transportation planning regulations.Intended beneficiaries: All citizens of the Commonwealth of Virginia that rely on efficient safe and effective transportation services and facilities to get them where they need to go.Subrecipient activities: Funds will be given to the following MPOs to cover the activities in their approved UPWPs: Roanoke Valley MPO Hampton Roads TPO Richmond Regional TPO Tri-Cities MPO Washington D.C. MPO (Metropolitan Washington Council of Governments or MWCOG) Fredericksburg MPO Harrisonburg-Rockingham MPO Staunton-Augusta-Waynesboro MPO Charlottesville MPO Bristol MPO Kingsport MPO Winchester MPO Lynchburg MPO and New River Valley MPO. Funds will also be given to the Thomas Jefferson PDC to conduct a study their regional transit and the Roanoke Valley-Alleghany Regional Commission to conduct a survey to better understand the transportation usage in their region.

column28: 0001: URBANIZED AREA PROGRAMS;0016: BUS AND BUS FACILITIES FORMULA GRANTS
column55: This application is to request Section 5339 Bus and Bus Facilities Formula funds apportioned to the State of Maine in the amount of $3085679. The request includes:FFY 2021 Section 5339 in the amount of $3040120FFY 2022 Section 5339 In the amount of $45559PURPOSE: The purpose of this award is to provide the state of Maine and its subrecipients with 80% federal share to replace buses trolleys and vans beyond their useful life as well as to purchase buses and vans to expand current fleet size for applicable transit providers. In addition two facilities will be upgraded and renovated.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: Funds will be used to purchase buses cutaways trolleys and vans for subrecipients as well as to upgrade and renovate two facilities.EXPECTED OUTCOMES: Improve the average age of the fleets to improve the State of Good Repair of the applicable Maine transit providers as well as improve the efficiency of the facilities and its equipment.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: Eight subrecipients and the populations of their service areas throughout the State of Maine.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: All applicable subrecipients will receive funds for capital assistance as outlined in the attached program of projects. The following transit providers will receive funding as part of this award.Aroostook Regional Transportation System (ARTS) for 3 accessible vans and 1 accessible cutaway to replace two buses and purchase 2 accessible vans to expand their fleet as well as facility renovations and upgrades. Downeast Community Partners (DCP) for 1 accessible cutaway to replace 1 cutaway.Downeast Transportation Inc. (DTI) for 5 accessible cutaways to replace 5 buses.Kennebec Valley Community Action Program (KVCAP) for 1 accessible cutaway and 2 accessible vans to replace two non-accessible vans and purchase 1 cutaway to expand their fleet.Penquis CAP (Penquis) for 3 accessible vans to replace 3 vans.Regional Transportation Program (RTP) for 8 accessible cutaways to replace 4 cutaways and purchase 4 cutaways to expand their fleet.Western Maine Transportation Services (WMTS) for facility upgrades and renovations.York County Community Action Corp. (YCCAC) for 5 trolleys to replace 5 trolleys.BENEFITS OF THE ABOVE ACTIVITIES: Many of MaineDOTs transit providers are using rolling stock that is beyond its useful life in years and/or miles. In addition to improving the average age of the fleet the maintenance costs of our transit providers should decrease with new vehicles. Buses trolleys and vans are being acquired to comply with or maintain compliance with ADA. MaineDOT is applying for these vehicles at 80% federal share. These vehicles are replacing vehicles which have met or exceeded their useful life and are for 7 nonprofit organizations. Refer to attached document with information on vehicles being replaced which includes subrecipient useful life mileage year/make/model and VIN. The non-profits will hold title and receive the vehicles as subrecipients. MaineDOT will ensure that the subrecipients will maintain satisfactory continuing control of the vehicles funded. These organizations aid the special transportation needs of seniors and individuals with disabilities in the State of Maine.Local match sources include county and municipal contributions capital reserve accounts contracted services unrestricted funds and local businesses/corporations.All vehicles are competitively bid and awarded or added on to an existing contract. Vehicles are purchased through the State of Maine Bureau of Purchases and titled to the respective transit providers named in this application.Attachments: (1) Provider Description; (2) Program of Projects; (3) Local Share Match Letters; (4) MaineDOT letter accepting 5339 funds for FFY2021 dated April 7 2021; and (5) MaineDOT letter accept 5339 funds for FFY 2022. MaineDOT executed the FY2022 Certifications and Assurances in TrAMS on February 7 2022. All activities are programmed in the FY22 element of the current ME STIP. MaineDOT is current with all Civil Rights Requirements and FTA annual certifications. All administrative and statutory requirements have been met in accordance with the Section 5339 Bus and Bus Facilities Program as articulated in FTA Circular 5100.1.All statutory requirements have been met.

column28: 0001: URBANIZED AREA PROGRAMS;0010: SENIORS AND PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES;0017: IIJA ACT, 2021
column55: This application is for 2022 formula funds for the 5310 demographics statewide: as defined in the Texas Transportation Code Title 43 Chapter 461. These funds will be recommended for award statewide to 39 small urban and rural transit districts private non-profit agencies governmental entities and local public agencies to the Texas Transportation Commission on July 12 2022. TDC letter dated 6/24/2022 attached.The funds will be used by 5310 providers for transportation services and capital purchases that serve Seniors and Individuals with disabilities to overcome transportation barriers.Purpose of the Award: Funding for section 5310 grant will enable Texas transit districts to provide public transportation services in both the rural and small urban areas of Texas. Funding will allow transit providers to continue operating established transit services and add new or expanded service to aid the growing 5310 population. Activities to be performed: Operating assistance project administration vehicle preventive maintenance and repairs capital projects benefiting the rural and small urban area (e.g. vehicle procurement hardware and software solutions state administration and mobility management 3rd Party contract services and technical assistance.) Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to implement 5310 programs and services to create an environment of resilience for passengers employees and communities in both rural and small urban areas of the state of Texas Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit seniors and individuals with disabilities by supporting mobility for rural and small urban areas communities transit riders and transit providers. Texas has the largest number of individuals with disabilities of all the states and 17% of the senior population lives in the 177 rural counties in Texas. Over half of seniors in Texas have one or more disabilities. Subrecipient Activities: 5310 Passenger transportation services to the public using the most efficient combination of knowledge materials resources and technology. FY2022 Full Apportionment: $11507861Funds Available: $11507861Non-Traditional State Administrative: $1150786 The amount of FY2022 non-traditional funds awarded does not exceed the 45% maximum. Total available for projects: $10357075 FY22 Total Small Urban apportionment: $5828383 Total State Admin applied for: $69412Traditional Small Urban projects applied for: $624707 Total Small Urban funds applied for: $694119 (SU projects +10% admin) Total obligated Small Urban traditional funds are 82% vs non traditional representing 18%Total Small Urban remaining funds to apply for later: $5134264 FY22 Total Rural apportionment: $5679478State Administrative Rural: $341988 Total Rural projects applied for: $3419883 Total rural funds applied for: $3761871 (Rural projects + 10% admin) Total obligated Rural traditional funds are 88% vs non traditional representing 12%FY22 Total Remaining Funds to be Applied for Later: $1917607 Total FY22 Rural/Small Urban funds to apply for later: $7051871 The Texas Department of Transportation is a Designated Recipient. The minimum of 55 percent of funding for traditional 5310 program type projects has been met. TxDOT certifies that the funds were awarded to subrecipients were awarded on a fair and equitable basis and the projects have been derived from a regionally coordinated public transit-human services transportation plan. To the extent feasible services are coordinated with transportation services provided by other federal agencies.
column56: 20.513: ENHANCED MOBILITY OF SENIORS AND INDIVIDUALS WITH DISABILITIES
column90: SUMMARY OF PROJECTS IS AS FOLLOWS: [ODESSA DISTRICT] PURCHASE OF SERVICE & PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE. [LUBBOCK DISTRICT] PURCHASE OF SERVICE. [EL PASO DISTRICT] PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE THE PROPOSED PURCHASE OF SERVICE AGREEMENTS ARE ONGOING PARTNERSHIPS WITH TERRELL COUNTY SENIOR TRANSPORTATION PROGRAM FOR $10,000 ANNUALLY; MISSION CENTER ADULT DAY SERVICE FOR $15,000 ANNUALLY; AND DAWSON COUNTY SENIOR CENTER FOR $6000 ANNUALLY. PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE FUNDS ARE REQUESTED FROM THE ODESSA DISTRICT FOR $50,205 ANNUALLY AND FROM THE EL PASO DISTRICT FOR $55,320 ANNUALLY. THE SERVICE AREA TO BE COVERED INCLUDES THE FOLLOWING 22 COUNTIES: ANDREWS, BORDEN, BREWSTER, CRANE, CULBERSON, DAWSON, RURAL ECTOR, GAINES, GLASSCOCK, HOWARD, HUDSPETH, JEFF DAVIS, LOVING, MARTIN, RURAL MIDLAND, PECOS, PRESIDIO, REEVES, TERRELL, UPTON, WARD AND WINKLER. SOCIAL SERVICE PARTNERS TERRELL COUNTY SENIORS, DAWSON COUNTY SENIORS AND MISSION CENTER ADULT DAY SERVICE PROVIDE VEHICLES, DRIVERS, FUEL AND MAINTENANCE, INSURANCE, ADMINISTRATIVE SUPPORT AND HAVE INCLUDED LETTERS OF COMMITMENT. TRANSIT PROVIDER SHALL COMPLY WITH ARTICLE 12: PROJECT RECORDS AND REPORTS AND ARTICLE 13 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT REQUIRING PROCUREMENT AND PROJECT MILESTONES / QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS. WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. Â  PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). Â  TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) SETS A FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL EVERY THREE YEARS FOR FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THE OVERALL GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.

column55: This application is for 2022 formula funds to the Rural Areas of Texas: the Rural Transit Districts defined in the Texas Transportation Code Title 43 Chapter 458 and RTAP 5311(b) funds. The local match will be derived from local funds and TDCs.The Public Transportation Program managed by the Public Transportation Division (PTN) of Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT) was allocated 15000000 Transportation Development Credits (TDC) for distribution to eligible projects by the Texas Transportation Commission (commission) in Minute Order 116073 for state fiscal year 2022. The TDC letter dated 7/1/22 awards 800000 TDC to various agencies as match for capital projects funded with FY2022 federal Section 5311 Rural Area Grant Program funds. The funds will be used by transit agencies for general transportation services and capital purchases. Purpose of the Award: Funding for this 5311 Rural Areas grant will enable Texas transit districts to provide public transportation services in the rural areas of Texas. Funding will also allow transit providers to continue operating established transit routes and to add new services to aid communities.Activities to be performed: Operating assistance project administration vehicle preventive maintenance and repairs capital projects benefiting the rural area (e.g. vehicle procurement hardware and software solutions) state administration and training and technical assistance. Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to implement programs and services to create an environment of resilience for passengers employees and communities in rural areas of the state of Texas.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit and support mobility for rural areas communities transit riders and transit providers.Subrecipient Activities: Passenger transportation services to the general public using the most efficient combination of knowledge materials resources and technology. GENERAL FUNDS SUMMARYFY 2022 5311 Total Apportionment$60303948 Total 5311 funds:$50517853 Total 5311(b)(3) funds:$871180 Total 5311(f) funds:$8914915 State Administrative: $2100001 5311 funds applied for: $48417852 5311(b)(3) funds applied for: $871180 5311(f) funds applied for: $4872167Total funds applied for: $56261200Total 5311 amount to be applied for later: $0 Total 5311(b)(3) amount to be applied for later: $0 Total 5311(f) amount to be applied for later: $4042748 Total amount to be applied for later:$4042748
column56: 20.509: FORMULA GRANTS FOR RURAL AREAS AND TRIBAL TRANSIT PROGRAM
column90: AS PRESENTED IN WEST TEXAS OPPORTUNITIES, INC.'S (WTO) FY22 GRANT APPLICATION, WTO WILL PROVIDE PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION THROUGHOUT THE RURAL TRANSIT DISTRICT SERVICE AREA. WTO WILL PROVIDE DEMAND RESPONSE SERVICE IN THE RURAL AREAS OF ANDREWS, BORDEN, BREWSTER, CRANE, CULBERSON, DAWSON, ECTOR, GAINES, GLASSCOCK, HOWARD, HUDSPETH, JEFF DAVIS, LOVING, MARTIN, MIDLAND, PECOS, PRESIDIO, REEVES, TERRELL, UPTON, WARD AND WINKLER COUNTIES. TRANSIT PROVIDER SHALL COMPLY WITH ARTICLE 12: PROJECT RECORDS AND REPORTS AND ARTICLE 13 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT REQUIRING PROCUREMENT AND PROJECT MILESTONES / QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS. WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME PERIOD SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) SETS A FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL EVERY THREE YEARS FOR FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THE PROPOSED OVERALL GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.
