column28: 0001: URBANIZED AREA PROGRAMS;0016: BUS AND BUS FACILITIES FORMULA GRANTS
column55: Texas Department of Transportation 5339 BBF formula apportionments FY 2021 and FY 2022. These funds were distributed to the 36 subrecipients that represent Texas rural transit districts.RURAL TOTAL $7500000 TDC 1279516 July 6 2022 TDC letter awarding 1400000 TDCs attached.FY21 $3500000FY22 $4000000 The funds will be used by 5339 eligible subrecipients to support capital projects such as the purchase of new and replacement fleet new and replacement support vehicles shop equipment computer hardware and software vehicle overhauls facility rehab/renovations and other miscellaneous equipment eligible under the 5339 BBF formula program. Purpose of Award: 5339 BBF funding will enable the Texas rural transit providers to keep their equipment facilities and fleet in a state of good repair for use in rural portions of Texas. Activities to be performed: Fleet replacement facility design MISC equipment purchases fleet expansions and other eligible 5339 program activities. Vehicles being replaced have or will meet useful life prior to disposition.Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to keep their capital items in a state of good repair by rehabilitating and replacing older equipment fleet and facilities.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit Texans living in rural areas rural communities transit riders and providers.Subrecipient Activities: The rural transit districts that receive these funds will use the funds to benefit the general public by ensuring the capital items they interact with are in a good state of repair and in condition to serve their purpose.STIP pages: Pages 1289 and 1292
column56: 20.526: BUSES AND BUS FACILITIES FORMULA, COMPETITIVE, AND LOW OR NO EMISSIONS PROGRAMS
column90: THE FUNDS SHALL BE USED FOR RURAL AREA TRANSIT CAPITAL PROJECTS IN THE SUBRECIPIENT'S SERVICE AREA THAT MAY REPLACE, REHABILITATE AND PURCHASE BUSES AND RELATED EQUIPMENT AND TO CONSTRUCT BUS-RELATED FACILITIES INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO TECHNOLOGICAL CHANGES OR INNOVATIONS TO MODIFY LOW OR NO EMISSION VEHICLES OR FACILITIES. TRANSIT PROVIDER SHALL COMPLY WITH ARTICLE 12: PROJECT RECORDS AND REPORTS AND ARTICLE 13 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT REQUIRING PROCUREMENT AND PROJECT MILESTONES / QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS. WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME PERIOD SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT OF FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT. THIS AMENDMENT REDUCES THE PROJECT GRANT AGREEMENT BY $68,042. THE MAXIMUM AMOUNT PAYABLE WITHOUT MODIFICATION IN ARTICLE 3. COMPENSATION OF THE GRANT AGREEMENT IS REVISED TO $310,869. ATTACHMENT B, HERETO ATTACHED, SHALL REPLACE THE PROJECT BUDGET PAGE IN SAID AGREEMENT. ALL OTHER PROVISIONS OF THE ORIGINAL PROJECT GRANT AGREEMENT NOT AMENDED ARE UNCHANGED AND REMAIN IN FULL FORCE AND EFFECT. THIS AMENDMENT BECOMES EFFECTIVE ON THE LATER DATE OF FULL EXECUTION BY BOTH PARTIES.

column55: This application is to request Section 5311 funds apportioned to the State of Kansas (UZA: 200000) in the amount of $16803066. Purpose: This application is to request FFY2020-2022 Section 5311 funds apportioned to the State of Kansas in the amount of $16802066.Budget Funding:2020.25.18.81 $122951842021.25.18.81 $ 42569492022.2J.18.R7 $ 249933Total Federal Amount: $16802066 Local/State Funding: $13548754Total Grant Amount: $30350820The State will be providing 20 of the local match with State Highway Funds. The remaining 20% match will be provided by the agencies general funds mill levy or other local funds. No federal funding is being used as match. All agencies and CTDs are verified in SAM before any payments are made to them. Activities to be performed: Operating Intercity Bus - provide continued transportation for their passengers. Project Admin - Provide administrative support to the transit agencies in the state. RTAP - Provide training and technical assistance to transit agencies in the state. State Admin - Will be used to cover expenses incurred to administer FTA programs. Expected outcomes: The funding for all of these projects will provide a needed boost to the transit agencies and their passengers. The RTAP project will centralize information and streamline processes that can be used by all the agencies and their passengers. Intended beneficiaries: It is expected that all of the projects will benefit anyone that uses transportation services in Kansas. Subrecipient Activities: Operating Intercity - Continue day to day services and utilize the additional funding to assist with additional expenses. RTAP - The University of Kansas Center for Research will provide assistance to transit agencies to better serve their customers.*Pre-award authority was selected because KDOT will enter into agreements with the CTDS the Intercity Bus Providers and KU for the period starting 7-1-22 in the amount of $15843067. The first two months of expenses are anticipated prior to execution of the award.

column28: 0001: URBANIZED AREA PROGRAMS;0010: SENIORS AND PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES;0017: IIJA ACT, 2021
column55: This application is for 2022 formula funds for the 5310 demographics statewide: as defined in the Texas Transportation Code Title 43 Chapter 461. These funds will be recommended for award statewide to 39 small urban and rural transit districts private non-profit agencies governmental entities and local public agencies to the Texas Transportation Commission on July 12 2022. TDC letter dated 6/24/2022 attached.The funds will be used by 5310 providers for transportation services and capital purchases that serve Seniors and Individuals with disabilities to overcome transportation barriers.Purpose of the Award: Funding for section 5310 grant will enable Texas transit districts to provide public transportation services in both the rural and small urban areas of Texas. Funding will allow transit providers to continue operating established transit services and add new or expanded service to aid the growing 5310 population. Activities to be performed: Operating assistance project administration vehicle preventive maintenance and repairs capital projects benefiting the rural and small urban area (e.g. vehicle procurement hardware and software solutions state administration and mobility management 3rd Party contract services and technical assistance.) Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to implement 5310 programs and services to create an environment of resilience for passengers employees and communities in both rural and small urban areas of the state of Texas Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit seniors and individuals with disabilities by supporting mobility for rural and small urban areas communities transit riders and transit providers. Texas has the largest number of individuals with disabilities of all the states and 17% of the senior population lives in the 177 rural counties in Texas. Over half of seniors in Texas have one or more disabilities. Subrecipient Activities: 5310 Passenger transportation services to the public using the most efficient combination of knowledge materials resources and technology. FY2022 Full Apportionment: $11507861Funds Available: $11507861Non-Traditional State Administrative: $1150786 The amount of FY2022 non-traditional funds awarded does not exceed the 45% maximum. Total available for projects: $10357075 FY22 Total Small Urban apportionment: $5828383 Total State Admin applied for: $69412Traditional Small Urban projects applied for: $624707 Total Small Urban funds applied for: $694119 (SU projects +10% admin) Total obligated Small Urban traditional funds are 82% vs non traditional representing 18%Total Small Urban remaining funds to apply for later: $5134264 FY22 Total Rural apportionment: $5679478State Administrative Rural: $341988 Total Rural projects applied for: $3419883 Total rural funds applied for: $3761871 (Rural projects + 10% admin) Total obligated Rural traditional funds are 88% vs non traditional representing 12%FY22 Total Remaining Funds to be Applied for Later: $1917607 Total FY22 Rural/Small Urban funds to apply for later: $7051871 The Texas Department of Transportation is a Designated Recipient. The minimum of 55 percent of funding for traditional 5310 program type projects has been met. TxDOT certifies that the funds were awarded to subrecipients were awarded on a fair and equitable basis and the projects have been derived from a regionally coordinated public transit-human services transportation plan. To the extent feasible services are coordinated with transportation services provided by other federal agencies.
column56: 20.513: ENHANCED MOBILITY OF SENIORS AND INDIVIDUALS WITH DISABILITIES
column81: U.S. LOCAL GOVERNMENT,U.S. STATE GOVERNMENT,TRANSIT AUTHORITY
column90: BRAZOS TRANSIT DISTRICT WILL PROVIDE PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION IN THE RURAL TRANSIT DISTRICT SERVICE AREA. BRAZOS TRANSIT DISTRICT WILL PROVIDE ONGOING FIXED ROUTE TRANSIT SERVICE AND COMPLEMENTARY ADA PARATRANSIT SERVICE IN THE CITIES OF LUFKIN, NACOGDOCHES, AND CLEVELAND. IN THE CITIES OF LIBERTY, DAYTON, AND AMES FUNDS WILL BE EXPENDED TO SUPPORT THE ONGOING CIRCULATOR ROUTE THAT SERVES THESE 3 CITIES. IN THE COUNTIES OF BRAZOS, BURLESON, GRIMES, HOUSTON, LEON, MADISON, MONTGOMERY, POLK, ROBERTSON, SAN JACINTO, TRINITY, WALKER, AND WASHINGTON SUPPORT WILL BE PROVIDE FOR ONGOING DEMAND RESPONSE SERVICES. TRANSIT PROVIDER SHALL COMPLY WITH ARTICLE 12: PROJECT RECORDS AND REPORTS AND ARTICLE 13 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT REQUIRING PROCUREMENT AND PROJECT MILESTONES / QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS. WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. Â  PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). Â  TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) SETS A FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL EVERY THREE YEARS FOR FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THE OVERALL GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.

column28: 0001: URBANIZED AREA PROGRAMS;0016: BUS AND BUS FACILITIES FORMULA GRANTS
column55: Texas Department of Transportation 5339 BBF formula apportionments FY 2021 and FY 2022. These funds were distributed to the 36 subrecipients that represent Texas rural transit districts.RURAL TOTAL $7500000 TDC 1279516 July 6 2022 TDC letter awarding 1400000 TDCs attached.FY21 $3500000FY22 $4000000 The funds will be used by 5339 eligible subrecipients to support capital projects such as the purchase of new and replacement fleet new and replacement support vehicles shop equipment computer hardware and software vehicle overhauls facility rehab/renovations and other miscellaneous equipment eligible under the 5339 BBF formula program. Purpose of Award: 5339 BBF funding will enable the Texas rural transit providers to keep their equipment facilities and fleet in a state of good repair for use in rural portions of Texas. Activities to be performed: Fleet replacement facility design MISC equipment purchases fleet expansions and other eligible 5339 program activities. Vehicles being replaced have or will meet useful life prior to disposition.Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to keep their capital items in a state of good repair by rehabilitating and replacing older equipment fleet and facilities.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit Texans living in rural areas rural communities transit riders and providers.Subrecipient Activities: The rural transit districts that receive these funds will use the funds to benefit the general public by ensuring the capital items they interact with are in a good state of repair and in condition to serve their purpose.STIP pages: Pages 1289 and 1292

WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME PERIOD SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT OF FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.

column55: This application is for 2022 formula funds to the Rural Areas of Texas: the Rural Transit Districts defined in the Texas Transportation Code Title 43 Chapter 458 and RTAP 5311(b) funds. The local match will be derived from local funds and TDCs.The Public Transportation Program managed by the Public Transportation Division (PTN) of Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT) was allocated 15000000 Transportation Development Credits (TDC) for distribution to eligible projects by the Texas Transportation Commission (commission) in Minute Order 116073 for state fiscal year 2022. The TDC letter dated 7/1/22 awards 800000 TDC to various agencies as match for capital projects funded with FY2022 federal Section 5311 Rural Area Grant Program funds. The funds will be used by transit agencies for general transportation services and capital purchases. Purpose of the Award: Funding for this 5311 Rural Areas grant will enable Texas transit districts to provide public transportation services in the rural areas of Texas. Funding will also allow transit providers to continue operating established transit routes and to add new services to aid communities.Activities to be performed: Operating assistance project administration vehicle preventive maintenance and repairs capital projects benefiting the rural area (e.g. vehicle procurement hardware and software solutions) state administration and training and technical assistance. Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to implement programs and services to create an environment of resilience for passengers employees and communities in rural areas of the state of Texas.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit and support mobility for rural areas communities transit riders and transit providers.Subrecipient Activities: Passenger transportation services to the general public using the most efficient combination of knowledge materials resources and technology. column90: AS PRESENTED IN BRAZOS TRANSIT DISTRICT'S FY22 GRANT APPLICATION, BRAZOS TRANSIT DISTRICT WILL PROVIDE PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION IN THE RURAL TRANSIT DISTRICT SERVICE AREA. BRAZOS TRANSIT DISTRICT WILL PROVIDE DEMAND RESPONSE SERVICE IN THE CITIES OF DIBOLL AND LUFKIN IN ANGELINA COUNTY, THE CITY OF NACOGDOCHES IN NACOGDOCHES COUNTY AND THE COUNTIES OF BRAZOS, BURLESON, GRIMES, HOUSTON, LEON, LIBERTY, MADISON, MONTGOMERY, POLK, ROBERTSON, SAN JACINTO, TRINITY, WALKER AND WASHINGTON. BRAZOS TRANSIT DISTRICT WILL ALSO PROVIDE FIXED ROUTE SERVICE IN THE CITIES OF LUFKIN, NACOGDOCHES AND CLEVELAND AND WILL PROVIDE AN EXPRESS ROUTE CONNECTING THE CITIES OF LUFKIN AND DIBOLL. COMPLEMENTARY ADA PARATRANSIT SERVICE IS AVAILABLE FOR THOSE WHO QUALIFY, REQUIRE WHEELCHAIR ACCESSIBLE SERVICES, OR ARE UNABLE TO RIDE THE FIXED ROUTE. BRAZOS TRANSIT DISTRICT WILL ALSO PROVIDE CIRCULATOR ROUTES IN THE CITIES OF LIBERTY, DAYTON, AND AMES. TRANSIT PROVIDER SHALL COMPLY WITH ARTICLE 12: PROJECT RECORDS AND REPORTS AND ARTICLE 13 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT REQUIRING PROCUREMENT AND PROJECT MILESTONES / QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS. WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME PERIOD SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) SETS A FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL EVERY THREE YEARS FOR FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THE PROPOSED OVERALL GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.

column55: Purpose of the Award: This application requests a total of $9779002 in Section 5311 funds to cover various transit operational activities throughout the state. The total of $9318868 in FFY2022 funds includes the full FFY2022 5311 statewide apportionment of $9179646 and the full RTAP amount of $139222. In addition this application re-obligates $460134 in FFY2020 LAPSING statewide funds being de-obligated from prior award #SD-2020-007-01.Activities to be performed: $4424171 Operating Assistance for rural providers$3567793 Project Administration for rural providers$1247812 Intercity Bus (91% of the 15% ICB requirement d $1376946 to fund feeder services across the State)$139222 RTAP (training)$ 400004 State/Program Administration for SDDOT (51% of maximum allowable as calculated by SDDOT)$9779002 Total FTA funds (Note: The FY 2020 funds have been separated into different Projects from the FY 2022 funds due to accounting requirements. Projects #1-#4 are funded with FY 2022 funds; Projects #5 and #6 are those funded with FY 2020 funds.)Expected outcomes: This grant will assist transit agencies statewide in funding administrative and operating costs during FY2023. SDDOT will award to 5311 eligible subrecipients for projects throughout the state. Intended beneficiaries: The transit patrons and employees of various transit agencies throughout the state of South Dakota.Subrecipient Activities: This grant will fund administrative and operating costs as well as provide training and fund ICB admin and operating for the following subrecipients:Aberdeen Ride Line Brookings Area Transit Authority City of Brandon Community Transit of Watertown/Sisseton East Dakota Transit Palace Transit Peoples Transit River Cities Public Transit Rural Office of Community Service Standing Rock Public Transit Vermillion Public Transit West River (Prairie Hills Transit) and Yankton Transit. Other Information:- Local funds sources for each subrecipient is documented in the POP.- Required documentation including the Program of Projects (POP) STIP documentation and Governors ICB letter are attached. The Governors letter stating that the intercity bus service needs in the state are being met without using 15% minimum of the 5311 funds. SDDOT will meet their ICB needs utilizing ARP and 5311 funds for FFY2022. In addition SDDOT is awarding ICB funds to subrecipients for feeder services. - SDDOT uses the sliding scale percentages for Project Administration at 82.82% federal match and Operating at 51.76% federal match as approved by FHWA in accordance with Circular 9040.1G . RTAP and State Administration are funded at 100% Federal.

column55: This application is for 2022 formula funds for the 5310 demographics statewide: as defined in the Texas Transportation Code Title 43 Chapter 461. These funds will be recommended for award statewide to 39 small urban and rural transit districts private non-profit agencies governmental entities and local public agencies to the Texas Transportation Commission on July 12 2022. TDC letter dated 6/24/2022 attached.The funds will be used by 5310 providers for transportation services and capital purchases that serve Seniors and Individuals with disabilities to overcome transportation barriers.Purpose of the Award: Funding for section 5310 grant will enable Texas transit districts to provide public transportation services in both the rural and small urban areas of Texas. Funding will allow transit providers to continue operating established transit services and add new or expanded service to aid the growing 5310 population. Activities to be performed: Operating assistance project administration vehicle preventive maintenance and repairs capital projects benefiting the rural and small urban area (e.g. vehicle procurement hardware and software solutions state administration and mobility management 3rd Party contract services and technical assistance.) Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to implement 5310 programs and services to create an environment of resilience for passengers employees and communities in both rural and small urban areas of the state of Texas Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit seniors and individuals with disabilities by supporting mobility for rural and small urban areas communities transit riders and transit providers. Texas has the largest number of individuals with disabilities of all the states and 17% of the senior population lives in the 177 rural counties in Texas. Over half of seniors in Texas have one or more disabilities. Subrecipient Activities: 5310 Passenger transportation services to the public using the most efficient combination of knowledge materials resources and technology. FY2022 Full Apportionment: $11507861Funds Available: $11507861Non-Traditional State Administrative: $1150786 The amount of FY2022 non-traditional funds awarded does not exceed the 45% maximum. Total available for projects: $10357075 FY22 Total Small Urban apportionment: $5828383 Total State Admin applied for: $69412Traditional Small Urban projects applied for: $624707 Total Small Urban funds applied for: $694119 (SU projects +10% admin) Total obligated Small Urban traditional funds are 82% vs non traditional representing 18%Total Small Urban remaining funds to apply for later: $5134264 FY22 Total Rural apportionment: $5679478State Administrative Rural: $341988 Total Rural projects applied for: $3419883 Total rural funds applied for: $3761871 (Rural projects + 10% admin) Total obligated Rural traditional funds are 88% vs non traditional representing 12%FY22 Total Remaining Funds to be Applied for Later: $1917607 Total FY22 Rural/Small Urban funds to apply for later: $7051871 The Texas Department of Transportation is a Designated Recipient. The minimum of 55 percent of funding for traditional 5310 program type projects has been met. TxDOT certifies that the funds were awarded to subrecipients were awarded on a fair and equitable basis and the projects have been derived from a regionally coordinated public transit-human services transportation plan. To the extent feasible services are coordinated with transportation services provided by other federal agencies.

PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME PERIOD SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) SETS A FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL EVERY THREE YEARS FOR FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THE PROPOSED OVERALL GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.

column55: This application is for 2022 formula funds to the Rural Areas of Texas: the Rural Transit Districts defined in the Texas Transportation Code Title 43 Chapter 458 and RTAP 5311(b) funds. The local match will be derived from local funds and TDCs.The Public Transportation Program managed by the Public Transportation Division (PTN) of Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT) was allocated 15000000 Transportation Development Credits (TDC) for distribution to eligible projects by the Texas Transportation Commission (commission) in Minute Order 116073 for state fiscal year 2022. The TDC letter dated 7/1/22 awards 800000 TDC to various agencies as match for capital projects funded with FY2022 federal Section 5311 Rural Area Grant Program funds. The funds will be used by transit agencies for general transportation services and capital purchases. Purpose of the Award: Funding for this 5311 Rural Areas grant will enable Texas transit districts to provide public transportation services in the rural areas of Texas. Funding will also allow transit providers to continue operating established transit routes and to add new services to aid communities.Activities to be performed: Operating assistance project administration vehicle preventive maintenance and repairs capital projects benefiting the rural area (e.g. vehicle procurement hardware and software solutions) state administration and training and technical assistance. Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to implement programs and services to create an environment of resilience for passengers employees and communities in rural areas of the state of Texas.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit and support mobility for rural areas communities transit riders and transit providers.Subrecipient Activities: Passenger transportation services to the general public using the most efficient combination of knowledge materials resources and technology. column55: Purpose of the Award: This application requests a total of $9779002 in Section 5311 funds to cover various transit operational activities throughout the state. The total of $9318868 in FFY2022 funds includes the full FFY2022 5311 statewide apportionment of $9179646 and the full RTAP amount of $139222. In addition this application re-obligates $460134 in FFY2020 LAPSING statewide funds being de-obligated from prior award #SD-2020-007-01.Activities to be performed: $4424171 Operating Assistance for rural providers$3567793 Project Administration for rural providers$1247812 Intercity Bus (91% of the 15% ICB requirement d $1376946 to fund feeder services across the State)$139222 RTAP (training)$ 400004 State/Program Administration for SDDOT (51% of maximum allowable as calculated by SDDOT)$9779002 Total FTA funds (Note: The FY 2020 funds have been separated into different Projects from the FY 2022 funds due to accounting requirements. Projects #1-#4 are funded with FY 2022 funds; Projects #5 and #6 are those funded with FY 2020 funds.)Expected outcomes: This grant will assist transit agencies statewide in funding administrative and operating costs during FY2023. SDDOT will award to 5311 eligible subrecipients for projects throughout the state. Intended beneficiaries: The transit patrons and employees of various transit agencies throughout the state of South Dakota.Subrecipient Activities: This grant will fund administrative and operating costs as well as provide training and fund ICB admin and operating for the following subrecipients:Aberdeen Ride Line Brookings Area Transit Authority City of Brandon Community Transit of Watertown/Sisseton East Dakota Transit Palace Transit Peoples Transit River Cities Public Transit Rural Office of Community Service Standing Rock Public Transit Vermillion Public Transit West River (Prairie Hills Transit) and Yankton Transit. Other Information:- Local funds sources for each subrecipient is documented in the POP.- Required documentation including the Program of Projects (POP) STIP documentation and Governors ICB letter are attached. The Governors letter stating that the intercity bus service needs in the state are being met without using 15% minimum of the 5311 funds. SDDOT will meet their ICB needs utilizing ARP and 5311 funds for FFY2022. In addition SDDOT is awarding ICB funds to subrecipients for feeder services. - SDDOT uses the sliding scale percentages for Project Administration at 82.82% federal match and Operating at 51.76% federal match as approved by FHWA in accordance with Circular 9040.1G . RTAP and State Administration are funded at 100% Federal.

column55: Description:This agreement is to fund the State of Texas' Water Quality Management Planning program to improve impaired water and protect unimpaired waters across the state by conducting planning that informs and supports implementation of Clean Water Act programs. In accordance with Clean Water Act section 205(j)(3), unless a waiver request is approved by EPA, the recipient will jointly develop workplans with and provide at least 40% of this award to regional or interstate watershed management planning agencies.   This agreement is supported by funding provided under the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act (IIJA) (PL 117-58).  Activities:The activities to be performed by the Coastal Bend and Bays Estuary Program (CBBEP) include the following water quality management planning activities: continuation of the Nueces Delta environmental monitoring, Baffin Bay watershed modeling, nutrient sampling in Petronila Creek, installation of Mission River water quality station, seagrass monitoring in Corpus Christi and Upper Laguna Madre, and a Coastal Bend Regional Wastewater feasibility study.  The following is more detail for the above projects: Nueces Delta Environmental Monitoring - CBBEP The purpose of this project is for the contractor to continue maintaining one current real-time salinity monitoring station on the Rincon Bayou. The salinity sensor will be used to trace freshwater inflows from freshwater pumping events via the Rincon Bayou Pipeline from the Nueces River and will report water temperature, conductivity, and salinity every 30 minutes. Data from this salinity station is being used to aid in the development of a management strategies for the Rincon Bayou Pipeline. The Center for Coastal Studies, the Harte Research Institute (HRI) at Texas AandM University Corpus Christi (TAMUCC) use the salinity data provided from the salinity stations to support various projects involving sampling in the Nueces Delta. Data from these salinity stations are also utilized by the University of Texas (UT) at Austin and the UT Marine Science Institute in Port Aransas to support various modeling projects which are investigating the interactions between water in sediment and tidal creeks in the Nueces Delta. The Nueces Delta Hydrodynamic Model being conducted by UT also utilized the tide gauge data in the western Nueces Bay. Several TWDB funded projects have and currently are utilizing the available data. The Nueces Delta Environmental Monitoring Project supports the Program Elements 11 a., 11 b., 11 g., 11 h., and 11 i. of the March 31, 1994 106/604(b) Guidance Memo issued by EPA Headquarters. This established monitoring effort supports the 1995 Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (then Texas Natural Resources Conservation Commission) Agreed Order which established the protocols for the required freshwater releases to the Nueces Estuary. By supporting ongoing operation of fixed salinity gauge and meteorological monitoring stations in the Nueces Delta as well as a sea level monitoring station in Nueces Bay, this project monitors the effectiveness of freshwater inflows to the Nueces Estuary and provides data necessary for adaptive management recommendations made by the Nueces Estuary Advisory Council (NEAC). The water level monitoring station also supports National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's (NOAA) Corpus Christi PORTSreg; monitoring network, a decision support tool that improves the safety and efficiency of maritime commerce and coastal resource management through the integration of real-time environmental observations. Data generated by this project is near real-time and is made publicly available via the NOAA Tides and Currents and the Texas AandM University - Conrad Blucher Institute websites and annual reports are published on the CBBEP website.   Baffin Bay Watershed Model - CBBEP The purpose of this project is to design and fabricate a 3'x7' custom plastic relief mode

column28: 0001: URBANIZED AREA PROGRAMS;0016: BUS AND BUS FACILITIES FORMULA GRANTS
column55: Texas Department of Transportation 5339 BBF formula apportionments FY 2021 and FY 2022. These funds were distributed to the 36 subrecipients that represent Texas rural transit districts.RURAL TOTAL $7500000 TDC 1279516 July 6 2022 TDC letter awarding 1400000 TDCs attached.FY21 $3500000FY22 $4000000 The funds will be used by 5339 eligible subrecipients to support capital projects such as the purchase of new and replacement fleet new and replacement support vehicles shop equipment computer hardware and software vehicle overhauls facility rehab/renovations and other miscellaneous equipment eligible under the 5339 BBF formula program. Purpose of Award: 5339 BBF funding will enable the Texas rural transit providers to keep their equipment facilities and fleet in a state of good repair for use in rural portions of Texas. Activities to be performed: Fleet replacement facility design MISC equipment purchases fleet expansions and other eligible 5339 program activities. Vehicles being replaced have or will meet useful life prior to disposition.Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to keep their capital items in a state of good repair by rehabilitating and replacing older equipment fleet and facilities.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit Texans living in rural areas rural communities transit riders and providers.Subrecipient Activities: The rural transit districts that receive these funds will use the funds to benefit the general public by ensuring the capital items they interact with are in a good state of repair and in condition to serve their purpose.STIP pages: Pages 1289 and 1292
column56: 20.526: BUSES AND BUS FACILITIES FORMULA, COMPETITIVE, AND LOW OR NO EMISSIONS PROGRAMS
column90: THE FUNDS SHALL BE USED FOR RURAL AREA TRANSIT CAPITAL PROJECTS IN THE SUBRECIPIENT'S SERVICE AREA THAT MAY REPLACE, REHABILITATE AND PURCHASE BUSES AND RELATED EQUIPMENT AND TO CONSTRUCT BUS-RELATED FACILITIES INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO TECHNOLOGICAL CHANGES OR INNOVATIONS TO MODIFY LOW OR NO EMISSION VEHICLES OR FACILITIES. TRANSIT PROVIDER SHALL COMPLY WITH ARTICLE 12: PROJECT RECORDS AND REPORTS AND ARTICLE 13 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT REQUIRING PROCUREMENT AND PROJECT MILESTONES / QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS. WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME PERIOD SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT OF FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.

column24: OFFICE OF BUDGET AND POLICY(TBP)
column55: This application is for 2022 formula funds to the Rural Areas of Texas: the Rural Transit Districts defined in the Texas Transportation Code Title 43 Chapter 458 and RTAP 5311(b) funds. The local match will be derived from local funds and TDCs.The Public Transportation Program managed by the Public Transportation Division (PTN) of Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT) was allocated 15000000 Transportation Development Credits (TDC) for distribution to eligible projects by the Texas Transportation Commission (commission) in Minute Order 116073 for state fiscal year 2022. The TDC letter dated 7/1/22 awards 800000 TDC to various agencies as match for capital projects funded with FY2022 federal Section 5311 Rural Area Grant Program funds. The funds will be used by transit agencies for general transportation services and capital purchases. Purpose of the Award: Funding for this 5311 Rural Areas grant will enable Texas transit districts to provide public transportation services in the rural areas of Texas. Funding will also allow transit providers to continue operating established transit routes and to add new services to aid communities.Activities to be performed: Operating assistance project administration vehicle preventive maintenance and repairs capital projects benefiting the rural area (e.g. vehicle procurement hardware and software solutions) state administration and training and technical assistance. Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to implement programs and services to create an environment of resilience for passengers employees and communities in rural areas of the state of Texas.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit and support mobility for rural areas communities transit riders and transit providers.Subrecipient Activities: Passenger transportation services to the general public using the most efficient combination of knowledge materials resources and technology. GENERAL FUNDS SUMMARYFY 2022 5311 Total Apportionment$60303948 Total 5311 funds:$50517853 Total 5311(b)(3) funds:$871180 Total 5311(f) funds:$8914915 State Administrative: $2100001 5311 funds applied for: $48417852 5311(b)(3) funds applied for: $871180 5311(f) funds applied for: $4872167Total funds applied for: $56261200Total 5311 amount to be applied for later: $0 Total 5311(b)(3) amount to be applied for later: $0 Total 5311(f) amount to be applied for later: $4042748 Total amount to be applied for later:$4042748
column56: 20.509: FORMULA GRANTS FOR RURAL AREAS AND TRIBAL TRANSIT PROGRAM
column90: AS PRESENTED IN STAR TRANSIT'S FY22 GRANT APPLICATION, STAR TRANSIT WILL PROVIDE PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION THROUGHOUT THE RURAL TRANSIT DISTRICT SERVICE AREA. STAR TRANSIT WILL PROVIDE DEMAND RESPONSE CURB-TO-CURB SERVICE IN THE RURAL AREAS OF KAUFMAN AND ROCKWALL COUNTIES. TRANSIT PROVIDER SHALL COMPLY WITH ARTICLE 12: PROJECT RECORDS AND REPORTS AND ARTICLE 13 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT REQUIRING PROCUREMENT AND PROJECT MILESTONES / QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS. WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME PERIOD SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) SETS A FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL EVERY THREE YEARS FOR FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THE PROPOSED OVERALL GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.

column55: Amendment #1 Purpose: WYDOT is adding the full FFY2022 5305(e)/5304 apportionment total of $160098 to two existing projects already in the award: - Project P2 - WYDOT Performance Based Planning Project - additional $29149 of federal funding to fully fund this project. The new FY22 funds were added as a new project (P5) to track the required separate accounting codes for FY22 funds.- Project P3 - Teton County - additional $130949 of federal funding to fully fund this project. The new FY22 funds were added as a new project (P4) to track the required separate accounting codes for FY22 funds.Activities to be Performed: remain the same as the original grant award. Projects P4 and P5 were added to separately track the new FY22 accounting codes.Expected Outcomes: remain the same as the original award.Intended Beneficiaries: remain the same as the original award.Subrecipient Activities: remain the same as the original award._____________________________________________________________OriginalPurpose:WYDOT is applying for a total of $284715 in Section 5304 planning formula funds for completing transit planning studies and related activities. The total FTA amount (provided at an 80/20 matching ratio) is composed of the following amounts:$ 31660- remaining apportionment of FFY2019 funds (Lapsing)$122106 - the full apportionment of FFY2020 funds$130949 - the full apportionment of FFY2021 funds$284715- Total Federal funding Activities to be Performed:The grant scope of work is organized into three projects for three separate agencies as described in more detail below.Project #1. Southern Teton Area Rapid Transit (START) - An amount of $120000 in FTA funds to review possible transportation alternatives for service to the Jackson Hole Airport based on results of surveys and statistical analysis that this project will fund. Project #2. WYDOT Transit Program Grants Management Performance Based Planning Project - An amount of $39840 in FTA funds to continue to fund WYDOTs ongoing project funded each year with planning funds to utilize Blackcat to assist with performance based planning currently being used for the WYDOT transit program. Project #3. Teton County - An amount of $124875 in initial FTA funds for planning and conceptual design for the Stilson Transit Center project. The project includes planning conceptual design outreach activities and evaluation for the proposed project to be constructed with BUILD funds in a future FTA application.(Note: the total cost for this effort exceeds $300000; it is anticipated that a portion of FY 2022 planning funds may be added as a future amendment after the funds are apportioned.) Expected Outcomes:The two planning projects for START and Teton County will help to further the transportation needs in both the Town of Jackson and Teton County. The grants management project for WYDOT is an ongoing project to better the transit program for all agencies with the BlackCat platform.Intended Beneficiaries:Transit agencies agency staff and transit passengersSubrecipient Activities:This grant will fund planning projects for Southern Teton Area Rapid Transit (START) and Teton County.Other Information:All required documentation is attached to this application including relevant pages from both the active STIP and the Annual Work Program.Local match is documented under the Activities to be Performed section and is coming from the Town of Jackson WYDOT and Teton County.Pre-award Statement: WYDOT is requesting pre-award authority for the performance based planning project of $39840 starting October 1 2021.

column18: REGION 3 DOT FTA
column24: OFFICE OF BUDGET AND POLICY(TBP)
column31: RAIL AND PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION, VIRGINIA DEPARTMENT OF
column55: The Virginia Department of Rail and Public Transportation (VDRPT) is applying for FFY 2022 Section 5303 Metropolitan Planning Program (MPP) funds in the amount of $3408991 to support the funding of 14 Metropolitan Planning Organization (MPO) Unified Planning Work Programs (UPWPs) throughout the state.VDRPT is also applying for FFY 2022 Section 5304 funds in the amount of $765356 for statewide transportation planning. The Statewide Planning and Research (SPR) Work Program is attached in TrAMS and includes a description and funding amount for each of the plans and studies listed in the ALIs.The non-Federal share will be provided by the respective metropolitan areas across the Commonwealth and the Commonwealth of Virginia. The FTA has approved the Unified Planning Work Program (UPWP) for MWCOG on June 1 2022 the only large urbanized area and air quality non-attainment or maintenance area remaining in the Commonwealth of Virginia. Funding in this application reflects what has been approved in the MPOs UPWPs. Approval letters and UPWPs are attached in TrAMS under Application Documents.Purpose: The purpose of this award is to support the funding of 14 Metropolitan Planning Organizations (MPO) so that they can carry out the activities in their FY2023 Unified Planning Work Programs (UPWP). It is also to support the planning activities of the Commonwealth of Virginia.Activities to be performed: Funds will be used to cover the activities in the approved UPWPs of our 14 MPOs which include general planning and programming short and long-term planning TIP development transit studies human service transportation coordination and addressing safety and security issues. The Commonwealth will also help transit agencies develop Transit Development Programs (TDPs) and Transit Strategic Plans (TSPs). Studies and surveys to help improve transportation services in the Commonwealth will also be funded.Expected outcome: Funding ensures the MPOs and the Commonwealth are carrying out transportation planning activities to comply with Federal transportation planning regulations.Intended beneficiaries: All citizens of the Commonwealth of Virginia that rely on efficient safe and effective transportation services and facilities to get them where they need to go.Subrecipient activities: Funds will be given to the following MPOs to cover the activities in their approved UPWPs: Roanoke Valley MPO Hampton Roads TPO Richmond Regional TPO Tri-Cities MPO Washington D.C. MPO (Metropolitan Washington Council of Governments or MWCOG) Fredericksburg MPO Harrisonburg-Rockingham MPO Staunton-Augusta-Waynesboro MPO Charlottesville MPO Bristol MPO Kingsport MPO Winchester MPO Lynchburg MPO and New River Valley MPO. Funds will also be given to the Thomas Jefferson PDC to conduct a study their regional transit and the Roanoke Valley-Alleghany Regional Commission to conduct a survey to better understand the transportation usage in their region.

column55: 06/06/22 (Original Grant):This application is to request Section 5304 funds apportioned to Michigan in the amount $671025 for eight new planning projects. The total FY22 grant is $838783. The funding breakdown is as follows:FY21 Section 5304 Federal funding of $443349 FY22 Section 5304 Federal funding of $227676State CTF match of $124454Local match (MPTA membership fee dues and/or registration fees) of $43304Purpose: Provide Section 5304 funds to assist rural and urban transit agencies cities municipalities and counties for research training/education planning and coordination and operational and technical projects that preserve or enhance public transportation.Activities to be performed: Transportation Needs Study and Service Plan Facility Construction Feasibility Study; Planning and Architectural/Engineering Services; Dynamic Air Purification Treatment; Transportation Service Feasibility Study Facility Feasibility Study; Drug Alcohol Consortium and Training; Midland County Connection/City of Midland Transit StudyExpected Outcomes: Projects will increase the support the economic vitality of the metropolitan area especially by enabling global competitiveness productivity and efficiency safety and security of the transportation system for motorized and nonmotorized users accessibility and mobility protect and enhance the environment enhance integration and connectivity of systems promote efficient and effective system management emphasize the preservation of the existing transportation system improve the resiliency and reliability of the transportation system and provide assistance to the transit agencies in the state of Michigan.Intended Beneficiaries: Rural and Urban Transit Agencies cities and municipalities counties and the publicSubrecipient Activities: Transportation Needs Study and Service Plan Facility Construction Feasibility Study; Planning and Architectural/Engineering Services; Dynamic Air Purification Treatment; Transportation Service Feasibility Study Facility Feasibility Study; Drug Alcohol Consortium and Training; Midland County Connection/City of Midland Transit StudyPOP Statewide UWP FTA Approval Letter BCATS UWP and MATS UWP are attached.
column56: 20.505: METROPOLITAN TRANSPORTATION PLANNING AND STATE AND NON-METROPOLITAN PLANNING AND RESEARCH
column90: PLANNING AND ARCHITECTURAL/ENGINEERING SERVICES: THE CITY OF BATTLE CREEK/BATTLE CREEK TRANSIT (BCT) FACILITY IS OVER 30 YEARS OLD AND THE ADMINISTRATIVE BUILDING ITSELF SITS ON A FOUNDATION THAT IS OVER 100 YEARS OLD. BCT WILL SECURE A FIRM TO PROVIDE PLANNING, ARCHITECTURAL/ENGINEERING SERVICES FOCUSED ON THE CITYÂ  S NEED FOR A NEW TRANSIT OPERATIONS, MAINTENANCE, AND STORAGE FACILITIES. SERVICES WILL INCLUDE GENERAL CONSULTING AND ASSISTANCE WITH THE CONCEPT DESIGN SITE IDENTIFICATION OF A COST-EFFECTIVE, FUNCTIONAL, AND LARGER FACILITY ACCEPTABLE TO MEET BOTH CURRENT OPERATIONS AND REFLECT CONSIDERATION FOR FUTURE GROWTH FOR THE NEXT 30 YEARS AS INDICATED BY THE CURRENTLY AVAILABLE TRANSIT DEVELOPMENT PLAN AND CURRENT MOVEMENT TOWARD A COUNTYWIDE AUTHORITY. PRELIMINARY ARCHITECTURAL CONCEPT DESIGNS/ENGINEERING TASKS WILL BE INCLUDED. A TECHNICAL MEMO OF THE FINDINGS SHALL BE PREPARED INCLUDING A HIGH-LEVEL CONCEPT BLOCK RENDERING THAT INCLUDES ADEQUATE UPDATED PROGRAMMING AND CONCEPTIONAL DESIGN WORK AS REQUIRED FOR SUBSEQUENT DEVELOPMENT OF THE PROJECT. A FINAL PACKET (POWER-POINT OR EQUIVALENT) WILL BE PREPARED AND PRESENTED TO ELECTED OFFICIALS TO APPROVE THE PRELIMINARY STUDY AS THE BASIS FOR DEVELOPMENT OF FUTURE DETAILED DESIGN FOR THE PROJECT. THE DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE A FINAL CONCEPT DESIGN AND AGGREGATE SQUARE FOOTAGES, CONFIRMED BUILDING PROGRAM AND FLOOR PLAN, CONFIRMED BUILDING SYSTEM OUTLINE AND OPERATIONAL FLOW DIAGRAMS, TEST FIT OF PROJECT ON SITE, SUPPORTING GRAPHICS SUFFICIENT TO DEPICT A RECOMMENDED OPTION AND STATE OF PROBABLE COST BASED ON INDUSTRY STANDARDS.

column28: 0001: URBANIZED AREA PROGRAMS;0010: SENIORS AND PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES;0017: IIJA ACT, 2021
column55: This application is for 2022 formula funds for the 5310 demographics statewide: as defined in the Texas Transportation Code Title 43 Chapter 461. These funds will be recommended for award statewide to 39 small urban and rural transit districts private non-profit agencies governmental entities and local public agencies to the Texas Transportation Commission on July 12 2022. TDC letter dated 6/24/2022 attached.The funds will be used by 5310 providers for transportation services and capital purchases that serve Seniors and Individuals with disabilities to overcome transportation barriers.Purpose of the Award: Funding for section 5310 grant will enable Texas transit districts to provide public transportation services in both the rural and small urban areas of Texas. Funding will allow transit providers to continue operating established transit services and add new or expanded service to aid the growing 5310 population. Activities to be performed: Operating assistance project administration vehicle preventive maintenance and repairs capital projects benefiting the rural and small urban area (e.g. vehicle procurement hardware and software solutions state administration and mobility management 3rd Party contract services and technical assistance.) Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to implement 5310 programs and services to create an environment of resilience for passengers employees and communities in both rural and small urban areas of the state of Texas Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit seniors and individuals with disabilities by supporting mobility for rural and small urban areas communities transit riders and transit providers. Texas has the largest number of individuals with disabilities of all the states and 17% of the senior population lives in the 177 rural counties in Texas. Over half of seniors in Texas have one or more disabilities. Subrecipient Activities: 5310 Passenger transportation services to the public using the most efficient combination of knowledge materials resources and technology. FY2022 Full Apportionment: $11507861Funds Available: $11507861Non-Traditional State Administrative: $1150786 The amount of FY2022 non-traditional funds awarded does not exceed the 45% maximum. Total available for projects: $10357075 FY22 Total Small Urban apportionment: $5828383 Total State Admin applied for: $69412Traditional Small Urban projects applied for: $624707 Total Small Urban funds applied for: $694119 (SU projects +10% admin) Total obligated Small Urban traditional funds are 82% vs non traditional representing 18%Total Small Urban remaining funds to apply for later: $5134264 FY22 Total Rural apportionment: $5679478State Administrative Rural: $341988 Total Rural projects applied for: $3419883 Total rural funds applied for: $3761871 (Rural projects + 10% admin) Total obligated Rural traditional funds are 88% vs non traditional representing 12%FY22 Total Remaining Funds to be Applied for Later: $1917607 Total FY22 Rural/Small Urban funds to apply for later: $7051871 The Texas Department of Transportation is a Designated Recipient. The minimum of 55 percent of funding for traditional 5310 program type projects has been met. TxDOT certifies that the funds were awarded to subrecipients were awarded on a fair and equitable basis and the projects have been derived from a regionally coordinated public transit-human services transportation plan. To the extent feasible services are coordinated with transportation services provided by other federal agencies.

column81: U.S. LOCAL GOVERNMENT,MUNICIPALITY,CITY,PLANNING COMMISSION,AIRPORT AUTHORITY,TRANSIT AUTHORITY
column90: WACO TRANSIT SYSTEM (WTS) PROVIDES TRANSPORTATION SERVICES FOR CITIZENS IN THE WACO URBANIZED AREA. WACO TRANSIT WILL PROVIDE NON EMERGENCY MEDICAL TRANSPORTATION SERVICES (I.E. MEDICAID) TO THE SIX COUNTY REGION. UTILIZING THE 5310 FUNDS TO PURCHASE OF SERVICE FROM THE ORGANIZATION CENTRAL TEXAS SENIOR MINISTRIES INCORPORATED, (CTSM), ALSO KNOWN AS MEALS ON WHEELS. CTSM WILL PERFORM AUTHORIZED TRIPS FOR THE ELDERLY AND DISABLED CLIENTS REQUESTING PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION. WTS TO EXPAND PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE ELDERLY & DISABLED CLIENTS WITHIN THE NEWLY DEVELOPED AND PREVIOUSLY DETERMINED URBANIZED AREAS OF WACO AND THE SURROUNDING COMMUNITIES THAT WERE IDENTIFIED AS OF THE 2010 CENSUS. TRANSIT PROVIDER SHALL COMPLY WITH ARTICLE 12: PROJECT RECORDS AND REPORTS AND ARTICLE 13 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT REQUIRING PROCUREMENT AND PROJECT MILESTONES / QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS. WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. Â  PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). Â  TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) SETS A FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL EVERY THREE YEARS FOR FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THE OVERALL GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.

column55: This cooperative agreement provides $1560507.00 (One Million and Five Hundred and Sixty Thousand and Five Hundred and Seven Dollars) funded through Sect. 5314 - Technical Assist Standards HR Training (2018 and forward) Technical Assistance and Workforce Development funding to support the ninth year of operations for the National Center for Mobility Management (NCMM). The award date is the same as the date of award. The period of performance will be from March 1 2022 to February 28 2023. This application includes funds for research and development activities. The cognizant agency the Department of Health and Human Services approved the Community Transportation Association of Americas (CTAAs) indirect cost rate on April 26 2021 and a copy of the organizations approved rate is on file with FTA. The approved rate of 34.0% will be applied to the applicable activity line descriptions. The NCMM was created pursuant to a Request for Proposals published on August 6 2018 and subsequently awarded through a cooperative agreement to CTAA. CTAA is the recipient of the Master Agreement with the FTA that supports a collaborative composed of CTAA Easterseals and the American Public Transportation Association (APTA). The mission of the NCMM is to facilitate communities in adopting customer-centered mobility strategies that empower people to live independently and advance health economic vitality self-sufficiency and community. The NCMM supports the development of coordinated transportation systems that are responsive to the needs of disadvantaged populations and all travelers. The objectives outlined in this cooperative agreement support technical assistance and training activities that build mobility management capacity strengthen the mobility management field and encourage the adoption of mobility management strategies in the transportation employment housing medical veteran human service education health and other industries. The Center will continue to play a key role in supporting FTAs work around mobility management activities and its leadership of the Coordinating Council on Access and Mobility (CCAM). Federal Role: FTAs Office of Program Management through the Division of Rural and Targeted Programs will be involved in all major decision-making activities. FTA will collaborate review evaluate and comment upon project activities key materials and technical reports. FTA will also maintain frequent contact with the project directors hold quarterly project review meetings require appropriate and timely submission of milestone and Federal Financial Review reports review and approval of invoices and if needed FTA participate in any decision to re-direct project activities. Recipient Role: CTAA will be responsible for collaboration with FTA day-to-day management and implementation of all project activities as outlined in the grant application and Statement of Work including meetings preparing technical status and financial reports and submitting the final project report. CTAA will also submit invoices for reimbursements and an in-depth report on major activities.

column31: RAIL AND PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION, VIRGINIA DEPARTMENT OF
column55: The Virginia Department of Rail and Public Transportation (VDRPT) is applying for FFY 2022 Section 5303 Metropolitan Planning Program (MPP) funds in the amount of $3408991 to support the funding of 14 Metropolitan Planning Organization (MPO) Unified Planning Work Programs (UPWPs) throughout the state.VDRPT is also applying for FFY 2022 Section 5304 funds in the amount of $765356 for statewide transportation planning. The Statewide Planning and Research (SPR) Work Program is attached in TrAMS and includes a description and funding amount for each of the plans and studies listed in the ALIs.The non-Federal share will be provided by the respective metropolitan areas across the Commonwealth and the Commonwealth of Virginia. The FTA has approved the Unified Planning Work Program (UPWP) for MWCOG on June 1 2022 the only large urbanized area and air quality non-attainment or maintenance area remaining in the Commonwealth of Virginia. Funding in this application reflects what has been approved in the MPOs UPWPs. Approval letters and UPWPs are attached in TrAMS under Application Documents.Purpose: The purpose of this award is to support the funding of 14 Metropolitan Planning Organizations (MPO) so that they can carry out the activities in their FY2023 Unified Planning Work Programs (UPWP). It is also to support the planning activities of the Commonwealth of Virginia.Activities to be performed: Funds will be used to cover the activities in the approved UPWPs of our 14 MPOs which include general planning and programming short and long-term planning TIP development transit studies human service transportation coordination and addressing safety and security issues. The Commonwealth will also help transit agencies develop Transit Development Programs (TDPs) and Transit Strategic Plans (TSPs). Studies and surveys to help improve transportation services in the Commonwealth will also be funded.Expected outcome: Funding ensures the MPOs and the Commonwealth are carrying out transportation planning activities to comply with Federal transportation planning regulations.Intended beneficiaries: All citizens of the Commonwealth of Virginia that rely on efficient safe and effective transportation services and facilities to get them where they need to go.Subrecipient activities: Funds will be given to the following MPOs to cover the activities in their approved UPWPs: Roanoke Valley MPO Hampton Roads TPO Richmond Regional TPO Tri-Cities MPO Washington D.C. MPO (Metropolitan Washington Council of Governments or MWCOG) Fredericksburg MPO Harrisonburg-Rockingham MPO Staunton-Augusta-Waynesboro MPO Charlottesville MPO Bristol MPO Kingsport MPO Winchester MPO Lynchburg MPO and New River Valley MPO. Funds will also be given to the Thomas Jefferson PDC to conduct a study their regional transit and the Roanoke Valley-Alleghany Regional Commission to conduct a survey to better understand the transportation usage in their region.

The priority population for the Weatherization Assistance Program is persons who are particularly vulnerable such as the elderly, persons with disabilities, families with children, high residential energy users, and households with high-energy burden.

column28: 0001: URBANIZED AREA PROGRAMS;0016: BUS AND BUS FACILITIES FORMULA GRANTS
column55: This application is to request Section 5339 Bus and Bus Facilities Formula funds apportioned to the State of Maine in the amount of $3085679. The request includes:FFY 2021 Section 5339 in the amount of $3040120FFY 2022 Section 5339 In the amount of $45559PURPOSE: The purpose of this award is to provide the state of Maine and its subrecipients with 80% federal share to replace buses trolleys and vans beyond their useful life as well as to purchase buses and vans to expand current fleet size for applicable transit providers. In addition two facilities will be upgraded and renovated.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: Funds will be used to purchase buses cutaways trolleys and vans for subrecipients as well as to upgrade and renovate two facilities.EXPECTED OUTCOMES: Improve the average age of the fleets to improve the State of Good Repair of the applicable Maine transit providers as well as improve the efficiency of the facilities and its equipment.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: Eight subrecipients and the populations of their service areas throughout the State of Maine.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: All applicable subrecipients will receive funds for capital assistance as outlined in the attached program of projects. The following transit providers will receive funding as part of this award.Aroostook Regional Transportation System (ARTS) for 3 accessible vans and 1 accessible cutaway to replace two buses and purchase 2 accessible vans to expand their fleet as well as facility renovations and upgrades. Downeast Community Partners (DCP) for 1 accessible cutaway to replace 1 cutaway.Downeast Transportation Inc. (DTI) for 5 accessible cutaways to replace 5 buses.Kennebec Valley Community Action Program (KVCAP) for 1 accessible cutaway and 2 accessible vans to replace two non-accessible vans and purchase 1 cutaway to expand their fleet.Penquis CAP (Penquis) for 3 accessible vans to replace 3 vans.Regional Transportation Program (RTP) for 8 accessible cutaways to replace 4 cutaways and purchase 4 cutaways to expand their fleet.Western Maine Transportation Services (WMTS) for facility upgrades and renovations.York County Community Action Corp. (YCCAC) for 5 trolleys to replace 5 trolleys.BENEFITS OF THE ABOVE ACTIVITIES: Many of MaineDOTs transit providers are using rolling stock that is beyond its useful life in years and/or miles. In addition to improving the average age of the fleet the maintenance costs of our transit providers should decrease with new vehicles. Buses trolleys and vans are being acquired to comply with or maintain compliance with ADA. MaineDOT is applying for these vehicles at 80% federal share. These vehicles are replacing vehicles which have met or exceeded their useful life and are for 7 nonprofit organizations. Refer to attached document with information on vehicles being replaced which includes subrecipient useful life mileage year/make/model and VIN. The non-profits will hold title and receive the vehicles as subrecipients. MaineDOT will ensure that the subrecipients will maintain satisfactory continuing control of the vehicles funded. These organizations aid the special transportation needs of seniors and individuals with disabilities in the State of Maine.Local match sources include county and municipal contributions capital reserve accounts contracted services unrestricted funds and local businesses/corporations.All vehicles are competitively bid and awarded or added on to an existing contract. Vehicles are purchased through the State of Maine Bureau of Purchases and titled to the respective transit providers named in this application.Attachments: (1) Provider Description; (2) Program of Projects; (3) Local Share Match Letters; (4) MaineDOT letter accepting 5339 funds for FFY2021 dated April 7 2021; and (5) MaineDOT letter accept 5339 funds for FFY 2022. MaineDOT executed the FY2022 Certifications and Assurances in TrAMS on February 7 2022. All activities are programmed in the FY22 element of the current ME STIP. MaineDOT is current with all Civil Rights Requirements and FTA annual certifications. All administrative and statutory requirements have been met in accordance with the Section 5339 Bus and Bus Facilities Program as articulated in FTA Circular 5100.1.All statutory requirements have been met.

column55: Purpose of the Award: This application with Lapsing funds obligates a total of $234226 in Section 5305(e)/Sec 5304 Statewide Planning funds. The total is composed of the following amounts: $ 47976 in remaining FFY 2019 LAPSING funds (de-obligated from prior award #SD-2018-002);$ 55301 in FFY2020 funds (the total amount remaining);$130949 in FFY2021 funds (the full apportionment);$234226 Total(Note: FY 2022 funds will be added in future amendment. They will be applied in a new separate project(s) and not co-mingled with older funds.)Activities to be Performed: The grant includes funding planning assistance for subrecipients throughout the state. The planning assistance will allow subrecipients to hire technical expertise (such as architect and engineering consultants) to assist with completing final design for progressing their capital projects into construction. (This application provides additional funds for the CTWSI facility planning funded by existing award #SD-2021-017.) In addition this application will fund planning assistance on the Statewide Human Services Coordinated Plan and an intercity bus needs study.Expected Outcomes: The planning activities will assist SDDOT to assist its subrecipients throughout the state with planning activities and will enable CTWSI to prepare their new expansion and remodel projects into construction.Intended Beneficiaries: Communities throughout the state including Milbank Webster Britton Faulkton Lennox and statewide. Subrecipient Activities: One subrecipient will be funded directly by this application: Community Transit of Watertown/Sisseton Inc. (CTWSI). CTWSI will be conducting planning-related activities for their future construction projects at five sites.Other: Associated documentation is attached to this application.

column28: 0001: URBANIZED AREA PROGRAMS;0016: BUS AND BUS FACILITIES FORMULA GRANTS
column55: Texas Department of Transportation 5339 BBF formula apportionments FY 2021 and FY 2022. These funds were distributed to the 36 subrecipients that represent Texas rural transit districts.RURAL TOTAL $7500000 TDC 1279516 July 6 2022 TDC letter awarding 1400000 TDCs attached.FY21 $3500000FY22 $4000000 The funds will be used by 5339 eligible subrecipients to support capital projects such as the purchase of new and replacement fleet new and replacement support vehicles shop equipment computer hardware and software vehicle overhauls facility rehab/renovations and other miscellaneous equipment eligible under the 5339 BBF formula program. Purpose of Award: 5339 BBF funding will enable the Texas rural transit providers to keep their equipment facilities and fleet in a state of good repair for use in rural portions of Texas. Activities to be performed: Fleet replacement facility design MISC equipment purchases fleet expansions and other eligible 5339 program activities. Vehicles being replaced have or will meet useful life prior to disposition.Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to keep their capital items in a state of good repair by rehabilitating and replacing older equipment fleet and facilities.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit Texans living in rural areas rural communities transit riders and providers.Subrecipient Activities: The rural transit districts that receive these funds will use the funds to benefit the general public by ensuring the capital items they interact with are in a good state of repair and in condition to serve their purpose.STIP pages: Pages 1289 and 1292
column56: 20.526: BUSES AND BUS FACILITIES FORMULA, COMPETITIVE, AND LOW OR NO EMISSIONS PROGRAMS
column90: THE FUNDS SHALL BE USED FOR RURAL AREA TRANSIT CAPITAL PROJECTS IN THE SUBRECIPIENT'S SERVICE AREA THAT MAY REPLACE, REHABILITATE AND PURCHASE BUSES AND RELATED EQUIPMENT AND TO CONSTRUCT BUS-RELATED FACILITIES INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO TECHNOLOGICAL CHANGES OR INNOVATIONS TO MODIFY LOW OR NO EMISSION VEHICLES OR FACILITIES. TRANSIT PROVIDER SHALL COMPLY WITH ARTICLE 12: PROJECT RECORDS AND REPORTS AND ARTICLE 13 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT REQUIRING PROCUREMENT AND PROJECT MILESTONES / QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS. WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME PERIOD SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT OF FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.

column55: Purpose of the Award: This application requests a total of $9779002 in Section 5311 funds to cover various transit operational activities throughout the state. The total of $9318868 in FFY2022 funds includes the full FFY2022 5311 statewide apportionment of $9179646 and the full RTAP amount of $139222. In addition this application re-obligates $460134 in FFY2020 LAPSING statewide funds being de-obligated from prior award #SD-2020-007-01.Activities to be performed: $4424171 Operating Assistance for rural providers$3567793 Project Administration for rural providers$1247812 Intercity Bus (91% of the 15% ICB requirement d $1376946 to fund feeder services across the State)$139222 RTAP (training)$ 400004 State/Program Administration for SDDOT (51% of maximum allowable as calculated by SDDOT)$9779002 Total FTA funds (Note: The FY 2020 funds have been separated into different Projects from the FY 2022 funds due to accounting requirements. Projects #1-#4 are funded with FY 2022 funds; Projects #5 and #6 are those funded with FY 2020 funds.)Expected outcomes: This grant will assist transit agencies statewide in funding administrative and operating costs during FY2023. SDDOT will award to 5311 eligible subrecipients for projects throughout the state. Intended beneficiaries: The transit patrons and employees of various transit agencies throughout the state of South Dakota.Subrecipient Activities: This grant will fund administrative and operating costs as well as provide training and fund ICB admin and operating for the following subrecipients:Aberdeen Ride Line Brookings Area Transit Authority City of Brandon Community Transit of Watertown/Sisseton East Dakota Transit Palace Transit Peoples Transit River Cities Public Transit Rural Office of Community Service Standing Rock Public Transit Vermillion Public Transit West River (Prairie Hills Transit) and Yankton Transit. Other Information:- Local funds sources for each subrecipient is documented in the POP.- Required documentation including the Program of Projects (POP) STIP documentation and Governors ICB letter are attached. The Governors letter stating that the intercity bus service needs in the state are being met without using 15% minimum of the 5311 funds. SDDOT will meet their ICB needs utilizing ARP and 5311 funds for FFY2022. In addition SDDOT is awarding ICB funds to subrecipients for feeder services. - SDDOT uses the sliding scale percentages for Project Administration at 82.82% federal match and Operating at 51.76% federal match as approved by FHWA in accordance with Circular 9040.1G . RTAP and State Administration are funded at 100% Federal.
