column18: REGION 6 DOT FTA
column24: OFFICE OF BUDGET AND POLICY(TBP)
column55: This application is for 2022 formula funds to the Rural Areas of Texas: the Rural Transit Districts defined in the Texas Transportation Code Title 43 Chapter 458 and RTAP 5311(b) funds. The local match will be derived from local funds and TDCs.The Public Transportation Program managed by the Public Transportation Division (PTN) of Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT) was allocated 15000000 Transportation Development Credits (TDC) for distribution to eligible projects by the Texas Transportation Commission (commission) in Minute Order 116073 for state fiscal year 2022. The TDC letter dated 7/1/22 awards 800000 TDC to various agencies as match for capital projects funded with FY2022 federal Section 5311 Rural Area Grant Program funds. The funds will be used by transit agencies for general transportation services and capital purchases. Purpose of the Award: Funding for this 5311 Rural Areas grant will enable Texas transit districts to provide public transportation services in the rural areas of Texas. Funding will also allow transit providers to continue operating established transit routes and to add new services to aid communities.Activities to be performed: Operating assistance project administration vehicle preventive maintenance and repairs capital projects benefiting the rural area (e.g. vehicle procurement hardware and software solutions) state administration and training and technical assistance. Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to implement programs and services to create an environment of resilience for passengers employees and communities in rural areas of the state of Texas.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit and support mobility for rural areas communities transit riders and transit providers.Subrecipient Activities: Passenger transportation services to the general public using the most efficient combination of knowledge materials resources and technology. GENERAL FUNDS SUMMARYFY 2022 5311 Total Apportionment$60303948 Total 5311 funds:$50517853 Total 5311(b)(3) funds:$871180 Total 5311(f) funds:$8914915 State Administrative: $2100001 5311 funds applied for: $48417852 5311(b)(3) funds applied for: $871180 5311(f) funds applied for: $4872167Total funds applied for: $56261200Total 5311 amount to be applied for later: $0 Total 5311(b)(3) amount to be applied for later: $0 Total 5311(f) amount to be applied for later: $4042748 Total amount to be applied for later:$4042748
column56: 20.509: FORMULA GRANTS FOR RURAL AREAS AND TRIBAL TRANSIT PROGRAM
column90: AS PRESENTED IN EAST TEXAS COUNCIL OF GOVERNMENTS' (ETCOG) FY22 GRANT APPLICATION, ETCOG WILL PROVIDE PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION THROUGHOUT THE RURAL TRANSIT DISTRICT SERVICE AREA. ETCOG WILL PROVIDE DEMAND RESPONSE SERVICE IN THE RURAL AREAS OF ANDERSON, CAMP, CHEROKEE, GREGG, HARRIS, HENDERSON, MARION, PANOLA, RAINS, RUSK, SMITH, UPSHUR, WOOD AND VAN ZANDT. TRANSIT PROVIDER SHALL COMPLY WITH ARTICLE 12: PROJECT RECORDS AND REPORTS AND ARTICLE 13 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT REQUIRING PROCUREMENT AND PROJECT MILESTONES / QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS. WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME PERIOD SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) SETS A FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL EVERY THREE YEARS FOR FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THE PROPOSED OVERALL GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.

column55: The West Virginia Department of Transportation Division of Public Transit (WVDOT) Section is applying for FFY 2022 Section 5310 Enhanced Mobility of Seniors and Individuals with Disabilities Program funds in the amount of $2830061 ($1307284 for Rural Apportionment and $1522777 for Small Urban Apportionment) to support the State DOTs FFY 2022 Program of Projects (POP). The WVDOT is applying for funding for both rural and small urban areas for the following projects:Rural projects include the following:Purchase of Eight (8) replacement vansPurchase of Four (4) expansion vans3rd party contracted servicesSmall Urban projects include the following:State Program Administration funds3rd party contracted servicesPurchase of One (1) replacement SUVPurchase of Eight (8) replacement vansPurchase of One (1) expansion vanAll projects in the current POP are in Category A status and are for traditional Section 5310 projects and thus meet the requirement to spend 55% of the apportionment toward traditional capital projects.The States FY 2022 Section 5310 POP is attached to this grant under Application Documents. The total number of recipients funded in the POP is twelve (12) private non-profits in the small urbans areas and twenty (20) private non-profits in the rural areas. The projects included in this application were derived from updated coordinated public transit - human services transportation plans developed by various West Virginia Planning and Development Councils located throughout the State. In addition each plan has been approved by the West Virginia Division of Public Transit.The State Management Plan for the State FY 2022 Section 5310 Program was approved by FTA on March 7 2019.Purpose: The purpose of this award is to provide funding to eligible recipients to meet the transportation needs of seniors and individuals with disabilities throughout West Virginia.Activities to be Performed: This application will fund the purchase of replacement and expansion vans as well as state program admin funds and funding for third party contracting.Expected Outcomes: Continued safe and effective operation of transit services for rural areas of West Virginia. Intended Beneficiaries: WVDOT transit agencies and citizens in the rural and non-urbanized areas of the state. Subrecipient Activities: The following twelve (12) private non-profits in the small urbans areas and twenty (20) private non-profits in the rural areas of West Virginia.Small UrbanEastern Panhandle TransitBerkeley Senior Services Hansford Senior ServicesHancock County Sr. ServicesKanawha Valley Senior Services Northwood Health SystemsPutnam Aging ProgramRaleigh County Community Action Association Family Service Upper Ohio ValleyGood Shepherd InterfaithMonongalia County UrbanWood County Senior Citizens AssociationRural Braxton County Senior Citizens CenterChristian Help Inc. of Mingo CountyCommunity Action of South Eastern West VirginiaCouncil of Senior Citizens of Gilmer CountyCouncil on Aging (Wyoming)Harrison County Senior Citizens Center Inc.Lewis County Senior Citizens CenterMcDowell County Commission on AgingPocahontas County Senior CitizensRitchie County Integrated Family ServicesSenior Life Services of Morgan CountySummers County Council on AgingWirt County Committee on AgingCentral WV Community Action Integrated Resources Inc. Logan-Mingo Area Mental HealthMarion CountyTaylor County Senior Citizens IncWebster County Senior CitizensYouth Health Services

column24: OFFICE OF BUDGET AND POLICY(TBP)
column28: 0001: URBANIZED AREA PROGRAMS;0016: BUS AND BUS FACILITIES FORMULA GRANTS
column55: Texas Department of Transportation 5339 BBF formula apportionments FY 2021 and FY 2022. These funds were distributed to the 36 subrecipients that represent Texas rural transit districts.RURAL TOTAL $7500000 TDC 1279516 July 6 2022 TDC letter awarding 1400000 TDCs attached.FY21 $3500000FY22 $4000000 The funds will be used by 5339 eligible subrecipients to support capital projects such as the purchase of new and replacement fleet new and replacement support vehicles shop equipment computer hardware and software vehicle overhauls facility rehab/renovations and other miscellaneous equipment eligible under the 5339 BBF formula program. Purpose of Award: 5339 BBF funding will enable the Texas rural transit providers to keep their equipment facilities and fleet in a state of good repair for use in rural portions of Texas. Activities to be performed: Fleet replacement facility design MISC equipment purchases fleet expansions and other eligible 5339 program activities. Vehicles being replaced have or will meet useful life prior to disposition.Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to keep their capital items in a state of good repair by rehabilitating and replacing older equipment fleet and facilities.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit Texans living in rural areas rural communities transit riders and providers.Subrecipient Activities: The rural transit districts that receive these funds will use the funds to benefit the general public by ensuring the capital items they interact with are in a good state of repair and in condition to serve their purpose.STIP pages: Pages 1289 and 1292
column56: 20.526: BUSES AND BUS FACILITIES FORMULA, COMPETITIVE, AND LOW OR NO EMISSIONS PROGRAMS
column90: THE FUNDS SHALL BE USED FOR RURAL AREA TRANSIT CAPITAL PROJECTS IN THE SUBRECIPIENT'S SERVICE AREA THAT MAY REPLACE, REHABILITATE AND PURCHASE BUSES AND RELATED EQUIPMENT AND TO CONSTRUCT BUS-RELATED FACILITIES INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO TECHNOLOGICAL CHANGES OR INNOVATIONS TO MODIFY LOW OR NO EMISSION VEHICLES OR FACILITIES. TRANSIT PROVIDER SHALL COMPLY WITH ARTICLE 12: PROJECT RECORDS AND REPORTS AND ARTICLE 13 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT REQUIRING PROCUREMENT AND PROJECT MILESTONES / QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS. WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME PERIOD SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT OF FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.

column28: 0001: URBANIZED AREA PROGRAMS;0010: SENIORS AND PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES;0017: IIJA ACT, 2021
column55: This application is for 2022 formula funds for the 5310 demographics statewide: as defined in the Texas Transportation Code Title 43 Chapter 461. These funds will be recommended for award statewide to 39 small urban and rural transit districts private non-profit agencies governmental entities and local public agencies to the Texas Transportation Commission on July 12 2022. TDC letter dated 6/24/2022 attached.The funds will be used by 5310 providers for transportation services and capital purchases that serve Seniors and Individuals with disabilities to overcome transportation barriers.Purpose of the Award: Funding for section 5310 grant will enable Texas transit districts to provide public transportation services in both the rural and small urban areas of Texas. Funding will allow transit providers to continue operating established transit services and add new or expanded service to aid the growing 5310 population. Activities to be performed: Operating assistance project administration vehicle preventive maintenance and repairs capital projects benefiting the rural and small urban area (e.g. vehicle procurement hardware and software solutions state administration and mobility management 3rd Party contract services and technical assistance.) Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to implement 5310 programs and services to create an environment of resilience for passengers employees and communities in both rural and small urban areas of the state of Texas Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit seniors and individuals with disabilities by supporting mobility for rural and small urban areas communities transit riders and transit providers. Texas has the largest number of individuals with disabilities of all the states and 17% of the senior population lives in the 177 rural counties in Texas. Over half of seniors in Texas have one or more disabilities. Subrecipient Activities: 5310 Passenger transportation services to the public using the most efficient combination of knowledge materials resources and technology. FY2022 Full Apportionment: $11507861Funds Available: $11507861Non-Traditional State Administrative: $1150786 The amount of FY2022 non-traditional funds awarded does not exceed the 45% maximum. Total available for projects: $10357075 FY22 Total Small Urban apportionment: $5828383 Total State Admin applied for: $69412Traditional Small Urban projects applied for: $624707 Total Small Urban funds applied for: $694119 (SU projects +10% admin) Total obligated Small Urban traditional funds are 82% vs non traditional representing 18%Total Small Urban remaining funds to apply for later: $5134264 FY22 Total Rural apportionment: $5679478State Administrative Rural: $341988 Total Rural projects applied for: $3419883 Total rural funds applied for: $3761871 (Rural projects + 10% admin) Total obligated Rural traditional funds are 88% vs non traditional representing 12%FY22 Total Remaining Funds to be Applied for Later: $1917607 Total FY22 Rural/Small Urban funds to apply for later: $7051871 The Texas Department of Transportation is a Designated Recipient. The minimum of 55 percent of funding for traditional 5310 program type projects has been met. TxDOT certifies that the funds were awarded to subrecipients were awarded on a fair and equitable basis and the projects have been derived from a regionally coordinated public transit-human services transportation plan. To the extent feasible services are coordinated with transportation services provided by other federal agencies.
column56: 20.513: ENHANCED MOBILITY OF SENIORS AND INDIVIDUALS WITH DISABILITIES
column90: PAISANO TRANSIT ENHANCEMENT SERVICES WILL PROVIDE 5310 TRANSPORTATION SERVICES BY EXTENDING HOURS OF SERVICE FROM 4 PM TO 7 PM MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY TO OUR ELDERLY AND DISABLED CITIZENS AND SATURDAY AND SUNDAY 9 AM TO 2 PM. THE WEEKEND SERVICE WOULD BE PROVIDED THROUGH KLEBERG COUNTY HUMAN SERVICES PAISANO TRANSIT TO THE ELDERLY AND DISABLED CITIZENS AS WELL. column56: 20.513: ENHANCED MOBILITY OF SENIORS AND INDIVIDUALS WITH DISABILITIES
column90: MOUNTING HORIZONS (MHI) PROJECTS HAS THREE MAIN ELEMENTS; MOBILITY MANAGEMENT, COORDINATION OF SERVICES, AND PURCHASE OF SERVICES. OVERALL, THE PROJECT OBJECTIVES ARE: 1) INCREASE DEMAND RESPONSE SERVICES IN AREAS WHERE PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION IS NOT ADEQUATE. 2) IMPROVE COORDINATION BETWEEN EXISTING TRANSPORTATION PROVIDERS THROUGH MOBILITY MANAGEMENT. 3) ENHANCE INDEPENDENCE OF INDIVIDUALS BY COORDINATING SERVICES WITH OTHER AGENCIES THAT SERVE THE SAME POPULATIONS. 4) INCREASE THE NUMBER OF NEW TRANSPORTATION PROVIDERS TO AREAS WITH LIMITED OR NO TRANSIT SERVICES. TRANSIT PROVIDER SHALL COMPLY WITH ARTICLE 12: PROJECT RECORDS AND REPORTS AND ARTICLE 13 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT REQUIRING PROCUREMENT AND PROJECT MILESTONES / QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS. WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. Â  PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). Â  TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) SETS A FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL EVERY THREE YEARS FOR FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THE OVERALL GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.

column55: This application is for 2022 formula funds to the Rural Areas of Texas: the Rural Transit Districts defined in the Texas Transportation Code Title 43 Chapter 458 and RTAP 5311(b) funds. The local match will be derived from local funds and TDCs.The Public Transportation Program managed by the Public Transportation Division (PTN) of Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT) was allocated 15000000 Transportation Development Credits (TDC) for distribution to eligible projects by the Texas Transportation Commission (commission) in Minute Order 116073 for state fiscal year 2022. The TDC letter dated 7/1/22 awards 800000 TDC to various agencies as match for capital projects funded with FY2022 federal Section 5311 Rural Area Grant Program funds. The funds will be used by transit agencies for general transportation services and capital purchases. Purpose of the Award: Funding for this 5311 Rural Areas grant will enable Texas transit districts to provide public transportation services in the rural areas of Texas. column56: 20.509: FORMULA GRANTS FOR RURAL AREAS AND TRIBAL TRANSIT PROGRAM
column90: AS PRESENTED IN HILL COUNTRY TRANSIT DISTRICT'S (HCTD) FY22 GRANT APPLICATION, HCTD WILL PROVIDE PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION THROUGHOUT THE RURAL TRANSIT DISTRICT SERVICE AREA. HCTD WILL PROVIDE DOOR-TO-DOOR DEMAND RESPONSE SERVICE IN THE RURAL AREAS OF BELL, CORYELL, HAMILTON, LAMPASAS, LLANO, MASON, MILAM, MILLS, AND SAN SABA COUNTIES. TRANSIT PROVIDER SHALL COMPLY WITH ARTICLE 12: PROJECT RECORDS AND REPORTS AND ARTICLE 13 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT REQUIRING PROCUREMENT AND PROJECT MILESTONES / QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS. WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME PERIOD SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) SETS A FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL EVERY THREE YEARS FOR FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THE PROPOSED OVERALL GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.

column55: This application is for 2022 formula funds to the Rural Areas of Texas: the Rural Transit Districts defined in the Texas Transportation Code Title 43 Chapter 458 and RTAP 5311(b) funds. The local match will be derived from local funds and TDCs.The Public Transportation Program managed by the Public Transportation Division (PTN) of Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT) was allocated 15000000 Transportation Development Credits (TDC) for distribution to eligible projects by the Texas Transportation Commission (commission) in Minute Order 116073 for state fiscal year 2022. The TDC letter dated 7/1/22 awards 800000 TDC to various agencies as match for capital projects funded with FY2022 federal Section 5311 Rural Area Grant Program funds. The funds will be used by transit agencies for general transportation services and capital purchases. Purpose of the Award: Funding for this 5311 Rural Areas grant will enable Texas transit districts to provide public transportation services in the rural areas of Texas. Funding will also allow transit providers to continue operating established transit routes and to add new services to aid communities.Activities to be performed: Operating assistance project administration vehicle preventive maintenance and repairs capital projects benefiting the rural area (e.g. vehicle procurement hardware and software solutions) state administration and training and technical assistance. Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to implement programs and services to create an environment of resilience for passengers employees and communities in rural areas of the state of Texas.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit and support mobility for rural areas communities transit riders and transit providers.Subrecipient Activities: Passenger transportation services to the general public using the most efficient combination of knowledge materials resources and technology. column28: 0001: URBANIZED AREA PROGRAMS;0010: SENIORS AND PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES;0017: IIJA ACT, 2021
column55: This application is for 2022 formula funds for the 5310 demographics statewide: as defined in the Texas Transportation Code Title 43 Chapter 461. These funds will be recommended for award statewide to 39 small urban and rural transit districts private non-profit agencies governmental entities and local public agencies to the Texas Transportation Commission on July 12 2022. TDC letter dated 6/24/2022 attached.The funds will be used by 5310 providers for transportation services and capital purchases that serve Seniors and Individuals with disabilities to overcome transportation barriers.Purpose of the Award: Funding for section 5310 grant will enable Texas transit districts to provide public transportation services in both the rural and small urban areas of Texas. Funding will allow transit providers to continue operating established transit services and add new or expanded service to aid the growing 5310 population. Activities to be performed: Operating assistance project administration vehicle preventive maintenance and repairs capital projects benefiting the rural and small urban area (e.g. vehicle procurement hardware and software solutions state administration and mobility management 3rd Party contract services and technical assistance.) Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to implement 5310 programs and services to create an environment of resilience for passengers employees and communities in both rural and small urban areas of the state of Texas Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit seniors and individuals with disabilities by supporting mobility for rural and small urban areas communities transit riders and transit providers. Texas has the largest number of individuals with disabilities of all the states and 17% of the senior population lives in the 177 rural counties in Texas. Over half of seniors in Texas have one or more disabilities. Subrecipient Activities: 5310 Passenger transportation services to the public using the most efficient combination of knowledge materials resources and technology. FY2022 Full Apportionment: $11507861Funds Available: $11507861Non-Traditional State Administrative: $1150786 The amount of FY2022 non-traditional funds awarded does not exceed the 45% maximum. Total available for projects: $10357075 FY22 Total Small Urban apportionment: $5828383 Total State Admin applied for: $69412Traditional Small Urban projects applied for: $624707 Total Small Urban funds applied for: $694119 (SU projects +10% admin) Total obligated Small Urban traditional funds are 82% vs non traditional representing 18%Total Small Urban remaining funds to apply for later: $5134264 FY22 Total Rural apportionment: $5679478State Administrative Rural: $341988 Total Rural projects applied for: $3419883 Total rural funds applied for: $3761871 (Rural projects + 10% admin) Total obligated Rural traditional funds are 88% vs non traditional representing 12%FY22 Total Remaining Funds to be Applied for Later: $1917607 Total FY22 Rural/Small Urban funds to apply for later: $7051871 The Texas Department of Transportation is a Designated Recipient. The minimum of 55 percent of funding for traditional 5310 program type projects has been met. TxDOT certifies that the funds were awarded to subrecipients were awarded on a fair and equitable basis and the projects have been derived from a regionally coordinated public transit-human services transportation plan. To the extent feasible services are coordinated with transportation services provided by other federal agencies.

WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME PERIOD SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT OF FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.

column31: RECREATION AND CONSERVATION OFFICE, WASHINGTON STATE
column55: Together with state matching funds, Washington's PCSRF and IIJA award will fund projects and actions identified in NOAA-approved recovery plans and that uphold treaty rights. The 120 high-priority, site-based projects will address limiting factors and protect or restore habitat statewide. Hatchery and harvest reform actions will complement the habitat projects by improving fitness of wild fish and addressing hatchery operations that limit the productivity of listed populations and non-listed populations essential for exercise of tribal treaty rights. Washington's established multi-tiered monitoring program will continue to evaluate the effectiveness of salmon habitat projects and measure progress toward recovery. Monitoring outcomes include data and findings that help determine if funds are well-invested, produce desired results, and support Washington's adaptive management approach.
column56: 11.438: PACIFIC COAST SALMON RECOVERY PACIFIC SALMON TREATY PROGRAM
column90: HCSEG IS PROPOSING TO CONTINUE TO PROVIDE RESEARCH ON SUMMER CHUM SALMON PRODUCTIVITY FROM THE UNION RIVER FISH IN/FISH OUT PROGRAM. THIS IS A MONITORING PROJECT TO ASSESS THE PRODUCTIVITY AND ABUNDANCE OF THE UNION RIVER SUMMER CHUM SALMON STOCK. THE PROJECT IS LOCATED APPROXIMATELY 0.1 MILES FROM THE MOUTH OF THE UNION RIVER IN THE TOWN OF BELFAIR, MASON COUNTY, WA. THE OVERALL GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ESTIMATE FRESHWATER PRODUCTIVITY, ABUNDANCE, SURVIVAL RATES, AND IMMIGRATION AND EMIGRATION TIMING OF NATURALLY-PRODUCED UNION RIVER SUMMER CHUM SALMON FROM DECEMBER 2022 TO DECEMBER 2024.Â  THIS PROGRAM HAS BEEN COLLECTING THIS DATA SINCE 2018.SIMILAR FISH IN/FISH OUT PROGRAMS ARE CURRENTLY BEING CONDUCTED BY THE WDFW ON SALMON CREEK, FOR THE SJDFUCA SUMMER CHUM SALMON POPULATION, AND ON THE DUCKABUSH RIVER ON THE WEST SIDE OF THE HOOD CANAL ESU. RESULTS FROM THIS PROJECT WILL HELP INFORM EFFORTS TO IMPLEMENT BETTER REGULATORY AND RECOVERY METRICS OF HOOD CANAL SUMMER CHUM SALMON WITHIN THE SUB REGION OF SOUTHEAST HOOD CANAL. WHEN COUPLED WITH DATA FROM THE WEST SIDE STUDY ON THE DUCKABUSH, CO-MANAGERS COULD PROVIDE A STRONGER MEASURE OF SUMMER CHUM SALMON RECOVERY THROUGHOUT THE HOOD CANAL ESU. THE END RESULT OF THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO PROVIDE A MEANS OF EVALUATING THE EFFECTS OF HABITAT RESTORATION, POTENTIAL IMPACTS DUE TO CLIMATE CHANGE, AND OTHER LONG-TERM FACTORS INFLUENCING RECOVERY OF HOOD CANAL SUMMER CHUM SALMON.

column55: Texas Department of Transportation 5339 BBF formula apportionments FY 2021 and FY 2022. These funds were distributed to the 36 subrecipients that represent Texas rural transit districts.RURAL TOTAL $7500000 TDC 1279516 July 6 2022 TDC letter awarding 1400000 TDCs attached.FY21 $3500000FY22 $4000000 The funds will be used by 5339 eligible subrecipients to support capital projects such as the purchase of new and replacement fleet new and replacement support vehicles shop equipment computer hardware and software vehicle overhauls facility rehab/renovations and other miscellaneous equipment eligible under the 5339 BBF formula program. Purpose of Award: 5339 BBF funding will enable the Texas rural transit providers to keep their equipment facilities and fleet in a state of good repair for use in rural portions of Texas. Activities to be performed: Fleet replacement facility design MISC equipment purchases fleet expansions and other eligible 5339 program activities. Vehicles being replaced have or will meet useful life prior to disposition.Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to keep their capital items in a state of good repair by rehabilitating and replacing older equipment fleet and facilities.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit Texans living in rural areas rural communities transit riders and providers.Subrecipient Activities: The rural transit districts that receive these funds will use the funds to benefit the general public by ensuring the capital items they interact with are in a good state of repair and in condition to serve their purpose.STIP pages: Pages 1289 and 1292

column55: The primary objective of this partnership would be to work together to better facilitate aquatic management projects with partners, in areas of mutual interest  The focus of the work would be varied, and would include design and implementation of instream restoration projects that increase habitat complexity and resiliency, as well as the removal of barriers to fish and other aquatic organism passage  Inventory, assessment and monitoring are key components that inform aquatic restoration  Data collected from monitoring and assessments provide information on baseline ecological condition, are used to design restoration projects and determine the effectiveness of the projects  Engaging with the public and stakeholders through environmental education and outreach programs promotes knowledge and skills needed to address complex environmental issues and ensures the public is informed about conservation and restoration of natural resources

column18: OREGON STATE OFFICE

column28: 0004: WESTERN OREGON RESOURCE MANAGEMENT;0011: LAND RESOURCES;0012: 2022 DISASTER SUPPLEMENTAL (P.L. 117-43);0019: 2022 BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW (P.L. 117-58);0021: AQUATIC RESOURCES MANAGEMENT
column55: The primary objective of this partnership would be to work together to better facilitate aquatic management projects with partners, in areas of mutual interest. The focus of the work would be varied, and would include design and implementation of instream restoration projects that increase habitat complexity and resiliency, as well as the removal of barriers to fish and other aquatic organism passage. Inventory, assessment and monitoring are key components that inform aquatic restoration. Data collected from monitoring and assessments provide information on baseline ecological condition, are used to design restoration projects and determine the effectiveness of the projects. Engaging with the public and stakeholders through environmental education and outreach programs promotes knowledge and skills needed to address complex environmental issues and ensures the public is informed about conservation and restoration of natural resources.

column55: This application is for 2022 formula funds to the Rural Areas of Texas: the Rural Transit Districts defined in the Texas Transportation Code Title 43 Chapter 458 and RTAP 5311(b) funds. The local match will be derived from local funds and TDCs.The Public Transportation Program managed by the Public Transportation Division (PTN) of Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT) was allocated 15000000 Transportation Development Credits (TDC) for distribution to eligible projects by the Texas Transportation Commission (commission) in Minute Order 116073 for state fiscal year 2022. The TDC letter dated 7/1/22 awards 800000 TDC to various agencies as match for capital projects funded with FY2022 federal Section 5311 Rural Area Grant Program funds. The funds will be used by transit agencies for general transportation services and capital purchases. Purpose of the Award: Funding for this 5311 Rural Areas grant will enable Texas transit districts to provide public transportation services in the rural areas of Texas. Funding will also allow transit providers to continue operating established transit routes and to add new services to aid communities.Activities to be performed: Operating assistance project administration vehicle preventive maintenance and repairs capital projects benefiting the rural area (e.g. vehicle procurement hardware and software solutions) state administration and training and technical assistance. Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to implement programs and services to create an environment of resilience for passengers employees and communities in rural areas of the state of Texas.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit and support mobility for rural areas communities transit riders and transit providers.Subrecipient Activities: Passenger transportation services to the general public using the most efficient combination of knowledge materials resources and technology. GENERAL FUNDS SUMMARYFY 2022 5311 Total Apportionment$60303948 Total 5311 funds:$50517853 Total 5311(b)(3) funds:$871180 Total 5311(f) funds:$8914915 State Administrative: $2100001 5311 funds applied for: $48417852 5311(b)(3) funds applied for: $871180 5311(f) funds applied for: $4872167Total funds applied for: $56261200Total 5311 amount to be applied for later: $0 Total 5311(b)(3) amount to be applied for later: $0 Total 5311(f) amount to be applied for later: $4042748 Total amount to be applied for later:$4042748
column56: 20.509: FORMULA GRANTS FOR RURAL AREAS AND TRIBAL TRANSIT PROGRAM
column90: AS PRESENTED IN KLEBERG COUNTY HUMAN SERVICES' FY22 GRANT APPLICATION, KLEBERG COUNTY HUMAN SERVICES WILL PROVIDE PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION IN THE RURAL TRANSIT DISTRICT SERVICE AREA. KLEBERG COUNTY HUMAN SERVICE WILL PROVIDE DEMAND RESPONSE SERVICE IN KLEBERG AND KENEDY COUNTIES. TRANSIT PROVIDER SHALL COMPLY WITH ARTICLE 12: PROJECT RECORDS AND REPORTS AND ARTICLE 13 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT REQUIRING PROCUREMENT AND PROJECT MILESTONES / QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS. WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME PERIOD SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) SETS A FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL EVERY THREE YEARS FOR FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THE PROPOSED OVERALL GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.

column55: This application is to request Section 5311 funds apportioned to the State of Kansas (UZA: 200000) in the amount of $16803066. Purpose: This application is to request FFY2020-2022 Section 5311 funds apportioned to the State of Kansas in the amount of $16802066.Budget Funding:2020.25.18.81 $122951842021.25.18.81 $ 42569492022.2J.18.R7 $ 249933Total Federal Amount: $16802066 Local/State Funding: $13548754Total Grant Amount: $30350820The State will be providing 20 of the local match with State Highway Funds. The remaining 20% match will be provided by the agencies general funds mill levy or other local funds. No federal funding is being used as match. All agencies and CTDs are verified in SAM before any payments are made to them. Activities to be performed: Operating Intercity Bus - provide continued transportation for their passengers. Project Admin - Provide administrative support to the transit agencies in the state. RTAP - Provide training and technical assistance to transit agencies in the state. State Admin - Will be used to cover expenses incurred to administer FTA programs. Expected outcomes: The funding for all of these projects will provide a needed boost to the transit agencies and their passengers. The RTAP project will centralize information and streamline processes that can be used by all the agencies and their passengers. Intended beneficiaries: It is expected that all of the projects will benefit anyone that uses transportation services in Kansas. Subrecipient Activities: Operating Intercity - Continue day to day services and utilize the additional funding to assist with additional expenses. RTAP - The University of Kansas Center for Research will provide assistance to transit agencies to better serve their customers.*Pre-award authority was selected because KDOT will enter into agreements with the CTDS the Intercity Bus Providers and KU for the period starting 7-1-22 in the amount of $15843067. The first two months of expenses are anticipated prior to execution of the award.

column28: 0015: CONGESTION MITIGATION AND AIR QUALITY IMPROVEMENT PROGRAM
column55: Project Title: CITY OF MISSION VIEJO - THE PROJECT IS LOCATED ON THE WESTERN EDGE OF MISSION VIEJO. THE MISSION VIEJO N/S CORRIDOR TRAIL IS BOUNDED BY LOS ALISOS BL :::: Project Description: CITY OF MISSION VIEJO - THE PROJECT IS LOCATED ON THE WESTERN EDGE OF MISSION VIEJO. THE MISSION VIEJO N/S CORRIDOR TRAIL IS BOUNDED BY LOS ALISOS BLVD TO THE NORTH AND THE LAGUNA NIGUEL/MISSION VIEJO METROLINK STATION TO THE SOUTH. THE JERONIMO/CHRISANTA TRAIL IS BOUNDED BY JERONIMO ROAD TO THE EAST AND CHRISANTA DRIVE AND THE MISSION VIEIO N/S CORRIDOR TRAIL TO THE WEST. BICYCLE FACILITY, CONNECTING THE CITY OF MISSION VIEJO TO AND FROM THE LAGUNA NIGUEL/MISSION VIEJO METROLINK STATION AT THE SOUTH END AND CONTINUING NORTH TO THE LAKE FOREST BOUNDARY LINE AND THE ALISO CREEK TRAIL. THIS TRAIL IS PRIMARILY ALONG THE OCTA RAILROAD CORRIDOR AND MAY POTENTIALLY CONTINUE NORTH TO THE IRVINE METROLINK TRAIN STATION. A SECOND TRAIL, THE JERONIMO/CHRISANTA TRAIL, IS AN EXISTING FLOOD CONTROL  CHANNEL OPEN SPACE, AND WILL SERVE TO CONNECT THE RESIDENTS OF CENTRAL MISSION VIEJO TO THE MISSION VIEJO N/S CORRIDOR TRAIL. THE PROJECT WILL IDENTIFY THE MOST APPROPRIATE DESIGN PARAMETERS FOR BOTH OF THE TRAILS. THIS WILL INCLUDE DEVELOPING A PRELIMINARY ENGINEERING STUDY TO DETERMINE TRAIL LAYOUT, ESTIMATING PROBABLE CONSTRUCTION COSTS, IDENTIFYING LIMITATIONS IN DESIGN AND ACCESS, AND SEEKING PUBLIC INPUT ON TRAIL DESIGN.
column90: CITY OF MISSION VIEJO - THE PROJECT IS LOCATED ON THE WESTERN EDGE OF MISSION VIEJO.

column55: The West Virginia Department of Transportation Division of Public Transit (WVDOT) Section is applying for FFY 2022 Section 5310 Enhanced Mobility of Seniors and Individuals with Disabilities Program funds in the amount of $2830061 ($1307284 for Rural Apportionment and $1522777 for Small Urban Apportionment) to support the State DOTs FFY 2022 Program of Projects (POP). The WVDOT is applying for funding for both rural and small urban areas for the following projects:Rural projects include the following:Purchase of Eight (8) replacement vansPurchase of Four (4) expansion vans3rd party contracted servicesSmall Urban projects include the following:State Program Administration funds3rd party contracted servicesPurchase of One (1) replacement SUVPurchase of Eight (8) replacement vansPurchase of One (1) expansion vanAll projects in the current POP are in Category A status and are for traditional Section 5310 projects and thus meet the requirement to spend 55% of the apportionment toward traditional capital projects.The States FY 2022 Section 5310 POP is attached to this grant under Application Documents. The total number of recipients funded in the POP is twelve (12) private non-profits in the small urbans areas and twenty (20) private non-profits in the rural areas. The projects included in this application were derived from updated coordinated public transit - human services transportation plans developed by various West Virginia Planning and Development Councils located throughout the State. In addition each plan has been approved by the West Virginia Division of Public Transit.The State Management Plan for the State FY 2022 Section 5310 Program was approved by FTA on March 7 2019.Purpose: The purpose of this award is to provide funding to eligible recipients to meet the transportation needs of seniors and individuals with disabilities throughout West Virginia.Activities to be Performed: This application will fund the purchase of replacement and expansion vans as well as state program admin funds and funding for third party contracting.Expected Outcomes: Continued safe and effective operation of transit services for rural areas of West Virginia. Intended Beneficiaries: WVDOT transit agencies and citizens in the rural and non-urbanized areas of the state. column28: 0001: URBANIZED AREA PROGRAMS;0016: BUS AND BUS FACILITIES FORMULA GRANTS
column55: Texas Department of Transportation 5339 BBF formula apportionments FY 2021 and FY 2022. These funds were distributed to the 36 subrecipients that represent Texas rural transit districts.RURAL TOTAL $7500000 TDC 1279516 July 6 2022 TDC letter awarding 1400000 TDCs attached.FY21 $3500000FY22 $4000000 The funds will be used by 5339 eligible subrecipients to support capital projects such as the purchase of new and replacement fleet new and replacement support vehicles shop equipment computer hardware and software vehicle overhauls facility rehab/renovations and other miscellaneous equipment eligible under the 5339 BBF formula program. Purpose of Award: 5339 BBF funding will enable the Texas rural transit providers to keep their equipment facilities and fleet in a state of good repair for use in rural portions of Texas. Activities to be performed: Fleet replacement facility design MISC equipment purchases fleet expansions and other eligible 5339 program activities. Vehicles being replaced have or will meet useful life prior to disposition.Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to keep their capital items in a state of good repair by rehabilitating and replacing older equipment fleet and facilities.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit Texans living in rural areas rural communities transit riders and providers.Subrecipient Activities: The rural transit districts that receive these funds will use the funds to benefit the general public by ensuring the capital items they interact with are in a good state of repair and in condition to serve their purpose.STIP pages: Pages 1289 and 1292
column56: 20.526: BUSES AND BUS FACILITIES FORMULA, COMPETITIVE, AND LOW OR NO EMISSIONS PROGRAMS
column90: THE FUNDS SHALL BE USED FOR RURAL AREA TRANSIT CAPITAL PROJECTS IN THE SUBRECIPIENT'S SERVICE AREA THAT MAY REPLACE, REHABILITATE AND PURCHASE BUSES AND RELATED EQUIPMENT AND TO CONSTRUCT BUS-RELATED FACILITIES INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO TECHNOLOGICAL CHANGES OR INNOVATIONS TO MODIFY LOW OR NO EMISSION VEHICLES OR FACILITIES. TRANSIT PROVIDER SHALL COMPLY WITH ARTICLE 12: PROJECT RECORDS AND REPORTS AND ARTICLE 13 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT REQUIRING PROCUREMENT AND PROJECT MILESTONES / QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS. WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME PERIOD SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT OF FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.

column18: REGION 6 DOT FTA
column24: OFFICE OF BUDGET AND POLICY(TBP)
column55: Application Executive SummaryOVERVIEW The Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT) is responsible for oversight and administration of the Federal Transit Administrations (FTA) State Planning and Research Program (SPRP) authorized at 49 United States Code (U.S.C.) 5305 for the State of Texas. This application is for FY 2022 funds totaling $2597003. The department requests TDC match of 519402 in the attached letter. This work program covers the period of September 1 2022 to December 31 2027. It defines the various planning research and oversight activities programmed by TxDOTs Public Transportation Division (PTN). SUMMARY The work program is divided into two program areas other activities are not currently funded in this grant application and may be amended or added under a budget revision. (1) Short Range Transit Planning and (2) Other Activities. TxDOT will develop plans and programs to implement the Surface Transportation Act and continue implementation of state statutes which call for a coordinated public transit-human services transportation network. Individual tasks in the two program areas include: Program Area 1: Short Range Transit Planning -Public transportation service coordination -Data collection performance measures and statistical reporting -Public Transportation Management System General planning and development assistance Program Area 2: Other Activities -Public transportation training -Public transportation news and information -Public Transportation Advisory Committee supportPurpose of the Award: Funding for this 5304 grant will enable Texas lead agencies transit districts and the state to improve short range planning efforts.Activities to be performed: Coordination planning activities pilot projects research and other efforts that support short range planning in Texas. Expected Outcomes: Improved coordination innovation knowledge of current conditions and research on how to improve mobility by creating safe clean and reliable public transportation in Texas. Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit and support mobility for rural and urban transit users transit providers and their communities. Subrecipient Activities: Short range planning research pilot projects and other activities using the most efficient combination of knowledge materials resources and technology.
column56: 20.505: METROPOLITAN TRANSPORTATION PLANNING AND STATE AND NON-METROPOLITAN PLANNING AND RESEARCH
column90: THIS PROJECT IS FOR THE IMPLEMENTATION PLAN FOR THE EL PASO COUNTY RURAL TRANSIT (EPCRT) SYSTEM BASED ON THE RESULTS OF THE EL PASO COUNTY REGIONAL TRANSIT INSTITUTIONAL OPTIONS FEASIBILITY STUDY. THE DELIVERABLES OF THIS PROJECT CONSIST THE FOLLOWING TECHNICAL MEMORANDA: 1. OVERALL PHASING PLAN: THE PHASING PLAN WILL SPEAK TO THE TIMING OF SERVICE DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION IN SPECIFIC CORRIDORS (STARTING WITH ROUTE 31) AND SPECIFIC SERVICE TYPES, WITH CONSIDERATION OF FACTORS SUCH AS LOCAL MUNICIPALITY SUPPORT, ADA COMPLIANCE, AND GEOGRAPHIC EQUITY. 2. TIMELINE FOR THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE RECOMMENDED ROUTES AND SERVICES: THE TIMELINE SHOULD ALLOW FOR REASSESSMENTS AFTER EACH PHASE OF IMPLEMENTATION; THESE REASSESSMENTS SHOULD INCLUDE A CHECK-IN WITH THE COMMUNITY TO GAUGE PUBLIC AND STAKEHOLDER RESPONSES TO THE ENHANCEMENTS. 3. SPECIFIC IMPLEMENTATION PLANS AND STRATEGIES: -NEW AND/OR REALIGNED FIXED-ROUTE BUS LINES. -THE INTRODUCTION OF FLEX-ROUTE BUS SERVICE IN SELECTED CORRIDORS -THE INTRODUCTION OF GENERAL PUBLIC DEMAND-RESPONSE (GPDR) SERVICE IN THE RURAL AREAS OF THE COUNTY. -SUBAREA-SPECIFIC AS WELL AS GENERAL STRATEGIES FOR IMPLEMENTATION OF THE RECOMMENDED GPDR SERVICE IN THE COUNTY. -STRATEGIES TO COVER CONCEPTS OF OPERATIONS AND STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURES (SOPS) SUCH AS -HANDLING SAME-DAY TRIP REQUESTS. -HOW DEVIATION REQUESTS ARE RECEIVED AND SCHEDULED 4. A DOCUMENT DESCRIBING RESPONSIBILITIES OF VARIOUS PARTNERS AND STAKEHOLDERS. 5. AN ASSESSMENT OF AVAILABLE RESOURCES (E.G., CONTRACTOR CAPACITY) AND ASSESSMENT OF RESOURCES NEEDED (E.G., SCHEDULING/DISPATCHING SOFTWARE). IN-DEPTH ANALYSIS AND DOCUMENTATION OF CURRENT TECHNOLOGY AVAILABLE WITHIN THE COUNTY TRANSIT SYSTEM. THE TEAM WILL IDENTIFY SPECIFIC NEEDS THAT TECHNOLOGY ENHANCEMENTS CAN ADDRESS (E.G., PROVIDING EASILY ACCESSIBLE AND ACCURATE TRANSIT INFORMATION TO CUSTOMERS) AND THE FEATURES THAT SUCH ENHANCEMENTS SHOULD INCORPORATE. THE TEAM WILL EVALUATE THE FEATURES AND COST-EFFECTIVENESS OF CANDIDATE TECHNOLOGY TOOLS AND DEVELOP IMPLEMENTATION STRATEGIES AND TIMELINES. 6. A MARKETING AND EDUCATION PLAN. 7. AN ADA COMPLIANCE PLAN. EPC WILL COLLATE THESE DOCUMENTS TO PRODUCE A COMPREHENSIVE IMPLEMENTATION PLAN DOCUMENT. SUBRECIPIENT SHALL COMPLY WITH ARTICLE 12: PROJECT RECORDS AND REPORTS AND ARTICLE 13 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT REQUIRING PROCUREMENT AND PROJECT MILESTONES / QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS. WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME PERIOD SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE GRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) SETS A FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL EVERY THREE YEARS FOR FUNDS EXPENDED BY SUBRECIPIENTS. THE PROPOSED OVERALL GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN SUBRECIPIENTS SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.

column18: REGION 6 DOT FTA
column24: OFFICE OF BUDGET AND POLICY(TBP)
column55: This application is for 2022 formula funds to the Rural Areas of Texas: the Rural Transit Districts defined in the Texas Transportation Code Title 43 Chapter 458 and RTAP 5311(b) funds. The local match will be derived from local funds and TDCs.The Public Transportation Program managed by the Public Transportation Division (PTN) of Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT) was allocated 15000000 Transportation Development Credits (TDC) for distribution to eligible projects by the Texas Transportation Commission (commission) in Minute Order 116073 for state fiscal year 2022. The TDC letter dated 7/1/22 awards 800000 TDC to various agencies as match for capital projects funded with FY2022 federal Section 5311 Rural Area Grant Program funds. The funds will be used by transit agencies for general transportation services and capital purchases. Purpose of the Award: Funding for this 5311 Rural Areas grant will enable Texas transit districts to provide public transportation services in the rural areas of Texas. Funding will also allow transit providers to continue operating established transit routes and to add new services to aid communities.Activities to be performed: Operating assistance project administration vehicle preventive maintenance and repairs capital projects benefiting the rural area (e.g. vehicle procurement hardware and software solutions) state administration and training and technical assistance. Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to implement programs and services to create an environment of resilience for passengers employees and communities in rural areas of the state of Texas.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit and support mobility for rural areas communities transit riders and transit providers.Subrecipient Activities: Passenger transportation services to the general public using the most efficient combination of knowledge materials resources and technology. GENERAL FUNDS SUMMARYFY 2022 5311 Total Apportionment$60303948 Total 5311 funds:$50517853 Total 5311(b)(3) funds:$871180 Total 5311(f) funds:$8914915 State Administrative: $2100001 5311 funds applied for: $48417852 5311(b)(3) funds applied for: $871180 5311(f) funds applied for: $4872167Total funds applied for: $56261200Total 5311 amount to be applied for later: $0 Total 5311(b)(3) amount to be applied for later: $0 Total 5311(f) amount to be applied for later: $4042748 Total amount to be applied for later:$4042748
column56: 20.509: FORMULA GRANTS FOR RURAL AREAS AND TRIBAL TRANSIT PROGRAM
column90: AS PRESENTED IN COMMUNITY SERVICES, INC. D.B.A. COMMUNITY TRANSIT SERVICE'S (CTS) FY22 GRANT APPLICATION, CTS WILL PROVIDE PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION THROUGHOUT THE RURAL TRANSIT DISTRICT SERVICE AREA. CTS WILL PROVIDE DEMAND RESPONSE CURB-TO-CURB SERVICE IN THE COUNTIES OF ELLIS AND NAVARRO. TRANSIT PROVIDER SHALL COMPLY WITH ARTICLE 12: PROJECT RECORDS AND REPORTS AND ARTICLE 13 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT REQUIRING PROCUREMENT AND PROJECT MILESTONES / QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS. WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME PERIOD SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) SETS A FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL EVERY THREE YEARS FOR FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THE PROPOSED OVERALL GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.

column55: The purpose of the Weatherization Assistance Program is to increase the energy efficiency of dwellings owned and occupied by low-income persons, reduce their total residential expenditures, and improve their health and safety. The priority population for the Weatherization Assistance Program is persons who are particularly vulnerable such as the elderly, persons with disabilities, families with children, high residential energy users, and households with high-energy burden.

ART WILL PROVIDE DEMAND RESPONSE CURB-TO-CURB SERVICE IN THE RURAL AREAS OF ATASCOSA, BANDERA, COMAL, FRIO, GILLESPIE, GUADALUPE, KARNES, KENDALL, KERR, MCMULLEN, MEDINA AND WILSON COUNTIES. SERVICE WILL ALSO BE PROVIDED FROM THE RURAL COUNTIES INTO SAN ANTONIO AND BEXAR COUNTY AND A DEVIATED FIXED ROUTE SERVICE WILL BE PROVIDED IN THE CITY OF SEGUIN. WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) SETS A FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL EVERY THREE YEARS FOR FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THE PROPOSED OVERALL GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.

column55: Funding for all projects included in this grant application is provided by the following apportionment years and Urbanized areas (UZAs).Section 5307 FFY 2022 Thousand Oaks (UZA #61440): $1459217Section 5307 FFY 2022 Oxnard (UZA #60860): $3626823Section 5307 FFY 2021 Camarillo (UZA #063680): $701522Section 5307 FFY 2022 Camarillo (UZA #063680): $759185Section 5307 FFY 2022 Simi Valley (#062710): $272551Overall grant fundingTotal Federal Funds: $6819298Total Local Match: $3834747 (Transportation Development Act [state sales tax for transportation] city general funds)Total Project Cost: $10654045A portion of the local share is provided by Transportation Development Credits. Because Transportation Development Credits do not allocate actual money toward project expenses an increased federal share is reflected where the credits are applied.VCTC is hereby submitting this grant application in support of the following projects for capital planning and operations:1) Capital Projects for VCTC and Subrecipients FY 2022 FundsThe grant applies $1940325 in FY 22 Section 5307 funds for preventive maintenance ADA service capital contracting cost capital infrastructure mobility management and Jobs Access and Reverse Commute with further details provided in the Project Description.2) Planning Projects for VCTC and CamarilloThe grant applies $1199000 in FY 22 Section 5307 funds for planning with further details provided in the Project Description.3) Operating Assistance for VCTC and Subrecipients FY 2022 FundsThe grant applies $2858451 in FY 22 Section 5307 funds for operating assistance with further details provided in the Project Description.4) Camarillo Preventive Maintenance FY 2021 FundsThe grant applies $604800 in FY 21 Section 5307 funds for preventive maintenance with further details provided in the Project Description.5) Camarillo Operating Assistance FY 2021 FundsThe grant applies $96722 in FY 21 Section 5307 funds for operating assistance with further details provided in the Project Description.Purpose: The purpose of this award is to provide $2545125 to VCTC and subrecipients for for preventive maintenance ADA service capital contracting cost mobility management capital infrastructure and Jobs Access Reverse Commute (JARC); $1199000 to VCTC and Camarillo for planning; and $2955173 to VCTC and Subrecipients for operating assistance.Activities to be performed: Funds will be used to cover eligible operating expenses such as driver salaries fuel maintenance on-demand rideshare transit vehicle leases etc. to continue transit operations.Expected outcomes: Funding will permit VCTC to continue to provide operations that would otherwise have to be cut due to lack of funding.Intended beneficiaries: VCTC and the riders that rely on its services will benefit from continued service permitting workers to get to work and riders to get to essential services.Subrecipients: The following are providers of transit service operators: MV Transportation First Transit and RATP-DEV.Suballocation Letter:Recipient organization is the Designated Recipient and can apply for and receive these apportioned funds. This Application is consistent with the suballocation identified in the Split Letter dated April 11 2022 and attached to this application. In keeping with the IIJA set aside for safety for areas over 200000 this grant will spend a minimum of $38145.30 representing 0.0075% of the Oxnard and Thousand Oaks funds for keeping vehicles safe and safety maintenance as part of ALI 11.7A.00 VCTC Intercity Preventive Maintenance.

column55: Amendment #1 Purpose: WYDOT is adding the full FFY2022 5305(e)/5304 apportionment total of $160098 to two existing projects already in the award: - Project P2 - WYDOT Performance Based Planning Project - additional $29149 of federal funding to fully fund this project. The new FY22 funds were added as a new project (P5) to track the required separate accounting codes for FY22 funds.- Project P3 - Teton County - additional $130949 of federal funding to fully fund this project. The new FY22 funds were added as a new project (P4) to track the required separate accounting codes for FY22 funds.Activities to be Performed: remain the same as the original grant award. Projects P4 and P5 were added to separately track the new FY22 accounting codes.Expected Outcomes: remain the same as the original award.Intended Beneficiaries: remain the same as the original award.Subrecipient Activities: remain the same as the original award._____________________________________________________________OriginalPurpose:WYDOT is applying for a total of $284715 in Section 5304 planning formula funds for completing transit planning studies and related activities. The total FTA amount (provided at an 80/20 matching ratio) is composed of the following amounts:$ 31660- remaining apportionment of FFY2019 funds (Lapsing)$122106 - the full apportionment of FFY2020 funds$130949 - the full apportionment of FFY2021 funds$284715- Total Federal funding Activities to be Performed:The grant scope of work is organized into three projects for three separate agencies as described in more detail below.Project #1. Southern Teton Area Rapid Transit (START) - An amount of $120000 in FTA funds to review possible transportation alternatives for service to the Jackson Hole Airport based on results of surveys and statistical analysis that this project will fund. Project #2. WYDOT Transit Program Grants Management Performance Based Planning Project - An amount of $39840 in FTA funds to continue to fund WYDOTs ongoing project funded each year with planning funds to utilize Blackcat to assist with performance based planning currently being used for the WYDOT transit program. Project #3. Teton County - An amount of $124875 in initial FTA funds for planning and conceptual design for the Stilson Transit Center project. The project includes planning conceptual design outreach activities and evaluation for the proposed project to be constructed with BUILD funds in a future FTA application.(Note: the total cost for this effort exceeds $300000; it is anticipated that a portion of FY 2022 planning funds may be added as a future amendment after the funds are apportioned.) Expected Outcomes:The two planning projects for START and Teton County will help to further the transportation needs in both the Town of Jackson and Teton County. The grants management project for WYDOT is an ongoing project to better the transit program for all agencies with the BlackCat platform.Intended Beneficiaries:Transit agencies agency staff and transit passengersSubrecipient Activities:This grant will fund planning projects for Southern Teton Area Rapid Transit (START) and Teton County.Other Information:All required documentation is attached to this application including relevant pages from both the active STIP and the Annual Work Program.Local match is documented under the Activities to be Performed section and is coming from the Town of Jackson WYDOT and Teton County.Pre-award Statement: WYDOT is requesting pre-award authority for the performance based planning project of $39840 starting October 1 2021.

column55: This application is to request Section 5311 funds apportioned to the State of Kansas (UZA: 200000) in the amount of $16803066. Purpose: This application is to request FFY2020-2022 Section 5311 funds apportioned to the State of Kansas in the amount of $16802066.Budget Funding:2020.25.18.81 $122951842021.25.18.81 $ 42569492022.2J.18.R7 $ 249933Total Federal Amount: $16802066 Local/State Funding: $13548754Total Grant Amount: $30350820The State will be providing 20 of the local match with State Highway Funds. The remaining 20% match will be provided by the agencies general funds mill levy or other local funds. No federal funding is being used as match. All agencies and CTDs are verified in SAM before any payments are made to them. Activities to be performed: Operating Intercity Bus - provide continued transportation for their passengers. Project Admin - Provide administrative support to the transit agencies in the state. RTAP - Provide training and technical assistance to transit agencies in the state. State Admin - Will be used to cover expenses incurred to administer FTA programs. Expected outcomes: The funding for all of these projects will provide a needed boost to the transit agencies and their passengers. The RTAP project will centralize information and streamline processes that can be used by all the agencies and their passengers. Intended beneficiaries: It is expected that all of the projects will benefit anyone that uses transportation services in Kansas. Subrecipient Activities: Operating Intercity - Continue day to day services and utilize the additional funding to assist with additional expenses. RTAP - The University of Kansas Center for Research will provide assistance to transit agencies to better serve their customers.*Pre-award authority was selected because KDOT will enter into agreements with the CTDS the Intercity Bus Providers and KU for the period starting 7-1-22 in the amount of $15843067. The first two months of expenses are anticipated prior to execution of the award.

column55: This application is for 2022 formula funds to the Rural Areas of Texas: the Rural Transit Districts defined in the Texas Transportation Code Title 43 Chapter 458 and RTAP 5311(b) funds. The local match will be derived from local funds and TDCs.The Public Transportation Program managed by the Public Transportation Division (PTN) of Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT) was allocated 15000000 Transportation Development Credits (TDC) for distribution to eligible projects by the Texas Transportation Commission (commission) in Minute Order 116073 for state fiscal year 2022. The TDC letter dated 7/1/22 awards 800000 TDC to various agencies as match for capital projects funded with FY2022 federal Section 5311 Rural Area Grant Program funds. The funds will be used by transit agencies for general transportation services and capital purchases. Purpose of the Award: Funding for this 5311 Rural Areas grant will enable Texas transit districts to provide public transportation services in the rural areas of Texas. Funding will also allow transit providers to continue operating established transit routes and to add new services to aid communities.Activities to be performed: Operating assistance project administration vehicle preventive maintenance and repairs capital projects benefiting the rural area (e.g. vehicle procurement hardware and software solutions) state administration and training and technical assistance. Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to implement programs and services to create an environment of resilience for passengers employees and communities in rural areas of the state of Texas.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit and support mobility for rural areas communities transit riders and transit providers.Subrecipient Activities: Passenger transportation services to the general public using the most efficient combination of knowledge materials resources and technology. GENERAL FUNDS SUMMARYFY 2022 5311 Total Apportionment$60303948 Total 5311 funds:$50517853 Total 5311(b)(3) funds:$871180 Total 5311(f) funds:$8914915 State Administrative: $2100001 5311 funds applied for: $48417852 5311(b)(3) funds applied for: $871180 5311(f) funds applied for: $4872167Total funds applied for: $56261200Total 5311 amount to be applied for later: $0 Total 5311(b)(3) amount to be applied for later: $0 Total 5311(f) amount to be applied for later: $4042748 Total amount to be applied for later:$4042748

column90: FUNDING FOR THIS PROJECT WILL CONSIST OF PRELIMINARY ENGINEERING, ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW AND DESIGN OF A NEW TRANSIT FACILITY THAT WILL ACCOMMODATE THE CONSTANT GROWTH OF THE COUNTY TRANSIT SERVICE. THE NEW FACILITY WILL INCLUDE OFFICE SPACE, A REPAIR SHOP, CNG (COMPRESS NATURAL GAS) FUELING SYSTEM, PARKING SPACE FOR TRANSIT FLEET, AND ADDITIONAL INFRASTRUCTURE REQUIRED FOR OPERATIONS. THE TRANSIT PROVIDER'S RESPONSE TO THE 2022 COORDINATED CALL FOR PROJECTS IS HEREBY INCORPORATED INTO THE PROJECT DESCRIPTION EXCEPT AS AMENDED IN THIS ATTACHMENT. TRANSIT PROVIDER SHALL COMPLY WITH ARTICLE 12: PROJECT RECORDS AND REPORTS AND ARTICLE 13 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT REQUIRING PROCUREMENT AND PROJECT MILESTONES / QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS. THE PROPOSED OVERALL GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. column55: Purpose of the Award: This application requests a total of $9779002 in Section 5311 funds to cover various transit operational activities throughout the state. The total of $9318868 in FFY2022 funds includes the full FFY2022 5311 statewide apportionment of $9179646 and the full RTAP amount of $139222. In addition this application re-obligates $460134 in FFY2020 LAPSING statewide funds being de-obligated from prior award #SD-2020-007-01.Activities to be performed: $4424171 Operating Assistance for rural providers$3567793 Project Administration for rural providers$1247812 Intercity Bus (91% of the 15% ICB requirement d $1376946 to fund feeder services across the State)$139222 RTAP (training)$ 400004 State/Program Administration for SDDOT (51% of maximum allowable as calculated by SDDOT)$9779002 Total FTA funds (Note: The FY 2020 funds have been separated into different Projects from the FY 2022 funds due to accounting requirements. Projects #1-#4 are funded with FY 2022 funds; Projects #5 and #6 are those funded with FY 2020 funds.)Expected outcomes: This grant will assist transit agencies statewide in funding administrative and operating costs during FY2023. SDDOT will award to 5311 eligible subrecipients for projects throughout the state. Intended beneficiaries: The transit patrons and employees of various transit agencies throughout the state of South Dakota.Subrecipient Activities: This grant will fund administrative and operating costs as well as provide training and fund ICB admin and operating for the following subrecipients:Aberdeen Ride Line Brookings Area Transit Authority City of Brandon Community Transit of Watertown/Sisseton East Dakota Transit Palace Transit Peoples Transit River Cities Public Transit Rural Office of Community Service Standing Rock Public Transit Vermillion Public Transit West River (Prairie Hills Transit) and Yankton Transit. Other Information:- Local funds sources for each subrecipient is documented in the POP.- Required documentation including the Program of Projects (POP) STIP documentation and Governors ICB letter are attached. The Governors letter stating that the intercity bus service needs in the state are being met without using 15% minimum of the 5311 funds. SDDOT will meet their ICB needs utilizing ARP and 5311 funds for FFY2022. In addition SDDOT is awarding ICB funds to subrecipients for feeder services. - SDDOT uses the sliding scale percentages for Project Administration at 82.82% federal match and Operating at 51.76% federal match as approved by FHWA in accordance with Circular 9040.1G . RTAP and State Administration are funded at 100% Federal.

column55: 06/06/22 (Original Grant):This application is to request Section 5304 funds apportioned to Michigan in the amount $671025 for eight new planning projects. The total FY22 grant is $838783. The funding breakdown is as follows:FY21 Section 5304 Federal funding of $443349 FY22 Section 5304 Federal funding of $227676State CTF match of $124454Local match (MPTA membership fee dues and/or registration fees) of $43304Purpose: Provide Section 5304 funds to assist rural and urban transit agencies cities municipalities and counties for research training/education planning and coordination and operational and technical projects that preserve or enhance public transportation.Activities to be performed: Transportation Needs Study and Service Plan Facility Construction Feasibility Study; Planning and Architectural/Engineering Services; Dynamic Air Purification Treatment; Transportation Service Feasibility Study Facility Feasibility Study; Drug Alcohol Consortium and Training; Midland County Connection/City of Midland Transit StudyExpected Outcomes: Projects will increase the support the economic vitality of the metropolitan area especially by enabling global competitiveness productivity and efficiency safety and security of the transportation system for motorized and nonmotorized users accessibility and mobility protect and enhance the environment enhance integration and connectivity of systems promote efficient and effective system management emphasize the preservation of the existing transportation system improve the resiliency and reliability of the transportation system and provide assistance to the transit agencies in the state of Michigan.Intended Beneficiaries: Rural and Urban Transit Agencies cities and municipalities counties and the publicSubrecipient Activities: Transportation Needs Study and Service Plan Facility Construction Feasibility Study; Planning and Architectural/Engineering Services; Dynamic Air Purification Treatment; Transportation Service Feasibility Study Facility Feasibility Study; Drug Alcohol Consortium and Training; Midland County Connection/City of Midland Transit StudyPOP Statewide UWP FTA Approval Letter BCATS UWP and MATS UWP are attached.
column56: 20.505: METROPOLITAN TRANSPORTATION PLANNING AND STATE AND NON-METROPOLITAN PLANNING AND RESEARCH
column90: MIDLAND COUNTY CONNECTION/CITY OF MIDLAND TRANSIT STUDY:  THE OBJECTIVE IS TO CONDUCT THE MIDLAND COUNTY CONNECTION/CITY OF MIDLAND TRANSIT STUDY OF THE TWO TRANSIT OPERATIONS WITHIN MIDLAND COUNTY TO DETERMINE IF COMBINING THE TRANSIT OPERATIONS INTO A COUNTY-WIDE TRANSIT AUTHORITY WOULD HELP MIDLAND RESIDENTS TO REALIZE COST EFFICIENCIES AND/OR PROVIDE IMPROVED/EXPANDED TRANSIT SERVICES. IN 2016, A COMMUNITY TRANSPORTATION STUDY WAS FACILITATED BY THE MIDLAND AREA TRANSPORTATION STUDY (MATS) TO EVALUATE AND BUILD ON THE REGIONÂ  S CURRENT TRANSPORTATION SERVICES, RESPOND TO CURRENT COMMUNITY NEEDS, AND PROMOTE CONNECTIVITY COLLABORATION. ONE OF THE RECOMMENDATIONS OF THE 2016 STUDY WAS TO COMBINE COUNTY CONNECTION AND CITY OF MIDLAND DIAL-A-RIDEÂ  S DISPATCH AND SCHEDULING SERVICES IN AN EFFORT TO ALLOW FOR GREATER FLEXIBILITY IN COMBINING TRIPS. SINCE THE 2016 TRANSPORTATION STUDY, THERE HAVE BEEN SEVERAL CHANGES WITHIN THE REGION THAT HAVE GENERATED RENEWED INTEREST IN THE CONCEPT OF COLLABORATION BETWEEN AGENCIES. AS MIDLAND LOOKS TO THE FUTURE, PART OF THE STRATEGIC PLAN IN THE REGION IS TO DEVELOP TRANSPORTATION OFFERINGS THAT CAN HELP ATTRACT ECONOMIC GROWTH TO THE AREA, STRENGTHEN THE SERVICE OFFERINGS AVAILABLE TO CURRENT RESIDENTS, KEEP COSTS TO RESIDENTS EFFECTIVE AND FURTHER REGIONAL TRANSIT RESPONSIVENESS AND CONNECTIVITY. RESIDENTS RESIDING WITHIN THE CITY LIMITS OF MIDLAND CURRENTLY PAY TWO DIFFERENT TAXES TO SUPPORT THE TWO (2) TRANSIT SERVICES. A PORTION OF THEIR PROPERTY TAXES SUPPORT THE CITY DIAL-A-RIDE SERVICE, AND THEY PAY A SEPARATE MILLAGE TO SUPPORT COUNTY CONNECTION. THIS PROJECT WILL IDENTIFY IF COST SAVINGS COULD BE ACHIEVED. ADDITIONALLY, THE STUDY WILL HELP TO DETERMINE IF REDUCTION OF DUPLICATIVE SERVICES COULD RESULT IN ADDITIONAL TRANSIT OFFERINGS FOR THE RESIDENTS IN MIDLAND COUNTY. IF A TRANSIT AUTHORITY PROVES TO BE TOO COST PROHIBITIVE THE STUDY COULD HELP TO IDENTIFY WAYS IN WHICH THE SEPARATE TRANSIT AGENCIES COULD COLLABORATE WITHIN THEIR EXISTING STRUCTURES.
