column24: REGION 6 (FUNDING OFFICE)
column55: Description:This agreement is to fund the State of Texas' Water Quality Management Planning program to improve impaired water and protect unimpaired waters across the state by conducting planning that informs and supports implementation of Clean Water Act programs. In accordance with Clean Water Act section 205(j)(3), unless a waiver request is approved by EPA, the recipient will jointly develop workplans with and provide at least 40% of this award to regional or interstate watershed management planning agencies.   This agreement is supported by funding provided under the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act (IIJA) (PL 117-58).  Activities:The activities to be performed by the Coastal Bend and Bays Estuary Program (CBBEP) include the following water quality management planning activities: continuation of the Nueces Delta environmental monitoring, Baffin Bay watershed modeling, nutrient sampling in Petronila Creek, installation of Mission River water quality station, seagrass monitoring in Corpus Christi and Upper Laguna Madre, and a Coastal Bend Regional Wastewater feasibility study.  The following is more detail for the above projects: Nueces Delta Environmental Monitoring - CBBEP The purpose of this project is for the contractor to continue maintaining one current real-time salinity monitoring station on the Rincon Bayou. The salinity sensor will be used to trace freshwater inflows from freshwater pumping events via the Rincon Bayou Pipeline from the Nueces River and will report water temperature, conductivity, and salinity every 30 minutes. Data from this salinity station is being used to aid in the development of a management strategies for the Rincon Bayou Pipeline. The Center for Coastal Studies, the Harte Research Institute (HRI) at Texas AandM University Corpus Christi (TAMUCC) use the salinity data provided from the salinity stations to support various projects involving sampling in the Nueces Delta. Data from these salinity stations are also utilized by the University of Texas (UT) at Austin and the UT Marine Science Institute in Port Aransas to support various modeling projects which are investigating the interactions between water in sediment and tidal creeks in the Nueces Delta. The Nueces Delta Hydrodynamic Model being conducted by UT also utilized the tide gauge data in the western Nueces Bay. Several TWDB funded projects have and currently are utilizing the available data. The Nueces Delta Environmental Monitoring Project supports the Program Elements 11 a., 11 b., 11 g., 11 h., and 11 i. of the March 31, 1994 106/604(b) Guidance Memo issued by EPA Headquarters. This established monitoring effort supports the 1995 Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (then Texas Natural Resources Conservation Commission) Agreed Order which established the protocols for the required freshwater releases to the Nueces Estuary. By supporting ongoing operation of fixed salinity gauge and meteorological monitoring stations in the Nueces Delta as well as a sea level monitoring station in Nueces Bay, this project monitors the effectiveness of freshwater inflows to the Nueces Estuary and provides data necessary for adaptive management recommendations made by the Nueces Estuary Advisory Council (NEAC). The water level monitoring station also supports National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's (NOAA) Corpus Christi PORTSreg; monitoring network, a decision support tool that improves the safety and efficiency of maritime commerce and coastal resource management through the integration of real-time environmental observations. Data generated by this project is near real-time and is made publicly available via the NOAA Tides and Currents and the Texas AandM University - Conrad Blucher Institute websites and annual reports are published on the CBBEP website.   Baffin Bay Watershed Model - CBBEP The purpose of this project is to design and fabricate a 3'x7' custom plastic relief mode

column55: Texas Department of Transportation 5339 BBF formula apportionments FY 2021 and FY 2022. These funds were distributed to the 36 subrecipients that represent Texas rural transit districts.RURAL TOTAL $7500000 TDC 1279516 July 6 2022 TDC letter awarding 1400000 TDCs attached.FY21 $3500000FY22 $4000000 The funds will be used by 5339 eligible subrecipients to support capital projects such as the purchase of new and replacement fleet new and replacement support vehicles shop equipment computer hardware and software vehicle overhauls facility rehab/renovations and other miscellaneous equipment eligible under the 5339 BBF formula program. Purpose of Award: 5339 BBF funding will enable the Texas rural transit providers to keep their equipment facilities and fleet in a state of good repair for use in rural portions of Texas. Activities to be performed: Fleet replacement facility design MISC equipment purchases fleet expansions and other eligible 5339 program activities. Vehicles being replaced have or will meet useful life prior to disposition.Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to keep their capital items in a state of good repair by rehabilitating and replacing older equipment fleet and facilities.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit Texans living in rural areas rural communities transit riders and providers.Subrecipient Activities: The rural transit districts that receive these funds will use the funds to benefit the general public by ensuring the capital items they interact with are in a good state of repair and in condition to serve their purpose.STIP pages: Pages 1289 and 1292

column90: THE FUNDS SHALL BE USED FOR RURAL AREA TRANSIT CAPITAL PROJECTS IN THE SUBRECIPIENT'S SERVICE AREA THAT MAY REPLACE, REHABILITATE AND PURCHASE BUSES AND RELATED EQUIPMENT AND TO CONSTRUCT BUS-RELATED FACILITIES INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO TECHNOLOGICAL CHANGES OR INNOVATIONS TO MODIFY LOW OR NO EMISSION VEHICLES OR FACILITIES. TRANSIT PROVIDER SHALL COMPLY WITH ARTICLE 12: PROJECT RECORDS AND REPORTS AND ARTICLE 13 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT REQUIRING PROCUREMENT AND PROJECT MILESTONES / QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS. WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME PERIOD SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT OF FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.

column55: Purpose of the Award: This application requests a total of $9779002 in Section 5311 funds to cover various transit operational activities throughout the state. The total of $9318868 in FFY2022 funds includes the full FFY2022 5311 statewide apportionment of $9179646 and the full RTAP amount of $139222. In addition this application re-obligates $460134 in FFY2020 LAPSING statewide funds being de-obligated from prior award #SD-2020-007-01.Activities to be performed: $4424171 Operating Assistance for rural providers$3567793 Project Administration for rural providers$1247812 Intercity Bus (91% of the 15% ICB requirement d $1376946 to fund feeder services across the State)$139222 RTAP (training)$ 400004 State/Program Administration for SDDOT (51% of maximum allowable as calculated by SDDOT)$9779002 Total FTA funds (Note: The FY 2020 funds have been separated into different Projects from the FY 2022 funds due to accounting requirements. Projects #1-#4 are funded with FY 2022 funds; Projects #5 and #6 are those funded with FY 2020 funds.)Expected outcomes: This grant will assist transit agencies statewide in funding administrative and operating costs during FY2023. SDDOT will award to 5311 eligible subrecipients for projects throughout the state. Intended beneficiaries: The transit patrons and employees of various transit agencies throughout the state of South Dakota.Subrecipient Activities: This grant will fund administrative and operating costs as well as provide training and fund ICB admin and operating for the following subrecipients:Aberdeen Ride Line Brookings Area Transit Authority City of Brandon Community Transit of Watertown/Sisseton East Dakota Transit Palace Transit Peoples Transit River Cities Public Transit Rural Office of Community Service Standing Rock Public Transit Vermillion Public Transit West River (Prairie Hills Transit) and Yankton Transit. Other Information:- Local funds sources for each subrecipient is documented in the POP.- Required documentation including the Program of Projects (POP) STIP documentation and Governors ICB letter are attached. The Governors letter stating that the intercity bus service needs in the state are being met without using 15% minimum of the 5311 funds. SDDOT will meet their ICB needs utilizing ARP and 5311 funds for FFY2022. In addition SDDOT is awarding ICB funds to subrecipients for feeder services. - SDDOT uses the sliding scale percentages for Project Administration at 82.82% federal match and Operating at 51.76% federal match as approved by FHWA in accordance with Circular 9040.1G . RTAP and State Administration are funded at 100% Federal.

column55: This application is for 2022 formula funds to the Rural Areas of Texas: the Rural Transit Districts defined in the Texas Transportation Code Title 43 Chapter 458 and RTAP 5311(b) funds. The local match will be derived from local funds and TDCs.The Public Transportation Program managed by the Public Transportation Division (PTN) of Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT) was allocated 15000000 Transportation Development Credits (TDC) for distribution to eligible projects by the Texas Transportation Commission (commission) in Minute Order 116073 for state fiscal year 2022. The TDC letter dated 7/1/22 awards 800000 TDC to various agencies as match for capital projects funded with FY2022 federal Section 5311 Rural Area Grant Program funds. The funds will be used by transit agencies for general transportation services and capital purchases. Purpose of the Award: Funding for this 5311 Rural Areas grant will enable Texas transit districts to provide public transportation services in the rural areas of Texas. Funding will also allow transit providers to continue operating established transit routes and to add new services to aid communities.Activities to be performed: Operating assistance project administration vehicle preventive maintenance and repairs capital projects benefiting the rural area (e.g. vehicle procurement hardware and software solutions) state administration and training and technical assistance. Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to implement programs and services to create an environment of resilience for passengers employees and communities in rural areas of the state of Texas.Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit and support mobility for rural areas communities transit riders and transit providers.Subrecipient Activities: Passenger transportation services to the general public using the most efficient combination of knowledge materials resources and technology. GENERAL FUNDS SUMMARYFY 2022 5311 Total Apportionment$60303948 Total 5311 funds:$50517853 Total 5311(b)(3) funds:$871180 Total 5311(f) funds:$8914915 State Administrative: $2100001 5311 funds applied for: $48417852 5311(b)(3) funds applied for: $871180 5311(f) funds applied for: $4872167Total funds applied for: $56261200Total 5311 amount to be applied for later: $0 Total 5311(b)(3) amount to be applied for later: $0 Total 5311(f) amount to be applied for later: $4042748 Total amount to be applied for later:$4042748

column90: AS PRESENTED IN ARK-TEX COUNCIL OF GOVERNMENTS' (ATCOG) FY22 GRANT APPLICATION, ATCOG WILL PROVIDE PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION THROUGHOUT THE RURAL TRANSIT DISTRICT SERVICE AREA. ATCOG WILL PROVIDE DEMAND RESPONSE SERVICE IN THE RURAL AREAS OF CASS, MORRIS, DELTA, HOPKINS, BOWIE, RED RIVER, FRANKLIN, LAMAR AND TITUS COUNTIES. ATCOG WILL ALSO PROVIDE DEVIATED FIXED ROUTE SERVICE IN THE CITY OF MT. PLEASANT. TRANSIT PROVIDER SHALL COMPLY WITH ARTICLE 12: PROJECT RECORDS AND REPORTS AND ARTICLE 13 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT REQUIRING PROCUREMENT AND PROJECT MILESTONES / QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS. WITHIN 30 DAYS OF PGA EXECUTION, THE SUBRECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE THE TXDOT PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION COORDINATOR WITH A PROJECT MILESTONE PLAN THAT DELINEATES FUND EXPENDITURES THROUGHOUT THE CONTRACT PERIOD. PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME PERIOD SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) SETS A FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL EVERY THREE YEARS FOR FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THE PROPOSED OVERALL GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.

PER TEXAS ADMINISTRATIVE CODE (TAC) 31.47, AUDIT AND PROJECT CLOSE-OUT STANDARDS: THE SUBRECIPIENT SHALL MAKE EVERY REASONABLE EFFORT TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND REQUEST APPROPRIATE REIMBURSEMENTS WITHIN THE TIME PERIOD SPECIFIED IN THE PROJECT AGREEMENT AND TAC 9.136, SUSPENSION OR TERMINATION FOR CAUSE: ON TERMINATION OF A SUBGRANT, THE UNEXPENDED AND UNOBLIGATED FUNDS AWARDED TO THE SUBGRANTEE IMMEDIATELY REVERT TO THE DEPARTMENT (TXDOT). TXDOT'S PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION DIVISION'S (PTN) FEDERAL TRANSIT ADMINISTRATION OVERALL DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISE (DBE) GOAL FOR FISCAL YEARS 2021 - 2023 IS 3.1 PERCENT OF FUNDS EXPENDED BY GRANTEES. THIS IS NOT A CONTRACT SPECIFIC GOAL BUT AN OVERALL GOAL FOR ANNUAL DBE PARTICIPATION. PTN GRANTEES SHOULD UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO INCLUDE DBE BUSINESSES IN PURCHASING AND CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES, AND ARE ENCOURAGED TO UTILIZE DBE BUSINESS WHENEVER PRACTICABLE. THE FULL DEFINITION OF DBE PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS IS FOUND IN ARTICLE 23 OF THE MASTER GRANT AGREEMENT.

column28: 0001: URBANIZED AREA PROGRAMS;0010: SENIORS AND PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES;0017: IIJA ACT, 2021
column55: This application is for 2022 formula funds for the 5310 demographics statewide: as defined in the Texas Transportation Code Title 43 Chapter 461. These funds will be recommended for award statewide to 39 small urban and rural transit districts private non-profit agencies governmental entities and local public agencies to the Texas Transportation Commission on July 12 2022. TDC letter dated 6/24/2022 attached.The funds will be used by 5310 providers for transportation services and capital purchases that serve Seniors and Individuals with disabilities to overcome transportation barriers.Purpose of the Award: Funding for section 5310 grant will enable Texas transit districts to provide public transportation services in both the rural and small urban areas of Texas. Funding will allow transit providers to continue operating established transit services and add new or expanded service to aid the growing 5310 population. Activities to be performed: Operating assistance project administration vehicle preventive maintenance and repairs capital projects benefiting the rural and small urban area (e.g. vehicle procurement hardware and software solutions state administration and mobility management 3rd Party contract services and technical assistance.) Expected Outcomes: Transit providers will be able to implement 5310 programs and services to create an environment of resilience for passengers employees and communities in both rural and small urban areas of the state of Texas Intended Beneficiaries: The proposed projects will benefit seniors and individuals with disabilities by supporting mobility for rural and small urban areas communities transit riders and transit providers. Texas has the largest number of individuals with disabilities of all the states and 17% of the senior population lives in the 177 rural counties in Texas. Over half of seniors in Texas have one or more disabilities. Subrecipient Activities: 5310 Passenger transportation services to the public using the most efficient combination of knowledge materials resources and technology. FY2022 Full Apportionment: $11507861Funds Available: $11507861Non-Traditional State Administrative: $1150786 The amount of FY2022 non-traditional funds awarded does not exceed the 45% maximum. Total available for projects: $10357075 FY22 Total Small Urban apportionment: $5828383 Total State Admin applied for: $69412Traditional Small Urban projects applied for: $624707 Total Small Urban funds applied for: $694119 (SU projects +10% admin) Total obligated Small Urban traditional funds are 82% vs non traditional representing 18%Total Small Urban remaining funds to apply for later: $5134264 FY22 Total Rural apportionment: $5679478State Administrative Rural: $341988 Total Rural projects applied for: $3419883 Total rural funds applied for: $3761871 (Rural projects + 10% admin) Total obligated Rural traditional funds are 88% vs non traditional representing 12%FY22 Total Remaining Funds to be Applied for Later: $1917607 Total FY22 Rural/Small Urban funds to apply for later: $7051871 The Texas Department of Transportation is a Designated Recipient. The minimum of 55 percent of funding for traditional 5310 program type projects has been met. TxDOT certifies that the funds were awarded to subrecipients were awarded on a fair and equitable basis and the projects have been derived from a regionally coordinated public transit-human services transportation plan. To the extent feasible services are coordinated with transportation services provided by other federal agencies.

column24: OFFICE OF BUDGET AND POLICY(TBP)
column55: This application is for FY 2022 Section 5310 Non-Urbanized Area apportionment for the PRHTA in the total amount $106457. The local share will be match with Transportation Development Credits (TDC). Federal share will be $106457; TDC will be $15969. PURPOSEThis project will provide transportation services for elderly persons and individuals with disabilities to meet the special transportation needs of these citizens in areas where the services are inappropriate insufficient or unavailable. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMEDEach of these projects are operated by a sub grantee and supervised by the Puerto Rico Highway and Transportation Authority distributed as follow:-Acquisition of Vehicles EXPECTED OUTCOMESAcquisition of Bus for Expansion to expand existing transportation services and to provide more options that can meet the transportation needs of the elderly or disabled population. The covered area for these municipalities increased the elderly population as a result it has become more important to expand these services.SUBRICIPIENT ACTIVITIES- Acquisition of VehiclesNTENDED BENEFICIARIESThe users will benefit from this performance especially older citizens and health patients that rely on public transportation services. The better performing route service will allow for more people including workers and visitors to rely on this serviceThe Office of the Ombudsman for the Elderly Persons and the Office of the Ombudsman for the Persons with Disabilities meet periodically with the PRHTA to exchange information about the areas that have special transportation needs. This information is beneficial in the establishment of applicants/ evaluation coordination plan. The Coordinated Public Transit-Human Services Transportation Plan (CPT-HSTP) was approved by PRMPO in February 26-27 2020.-The minimum of 55% of the 5310 apportionment is dedicated to the traditional 5310 activities. -All projects included on this application have been derived from locally coordinated human services transportation plan.-PRHTA will ensure that all vehicles purchased are accessible purchased from an FTA approved TVM and reported to FTA within 30 days after contract is signed.-PRHTA will check the current listing of Transit Vehicle Manufacturers (TVM) (https://www.transit.dot.gov/regulations-and-guidance/civil-rights-ada/eligible-tvms-list) to ensure each is listen as a certified TVM in compliance with FTA regulations.- PRHTA will follow all 3rd party procurement policies as defined in C4220.1F (Third Party Contracting Guidance).- PRHTA will ensure contractors procured will not be on the FTA Suspension and Debarment list.Projects Selection Criteria: The PRHTA utilizes the following criteria for the evaluation and selection of applicants: 1. Degree of coordination with other agencies for maximum utilization and operating efficiency any shortcoming of existing services. 2. Number of clienteles to receive the specialized transportation services. 3. Extent to which accessible transportation services are provided in the area to be served including the number of Section 5310 vehicles in the area days and hours of service frequency of trip etc. 4. Extent to which the following management factors are presented: a. Route to be Serve- The types of roads in the route to determine if the vehicles requested are the most appropriate to offer the transportation service. b. Management Capability: Extent of fiscal and managerial capability especially in the applicants ability to provide for the local share vehicle operation and maintenance drivers scheduling and dispatching storage of vehicle(s) when not in service and the ability to administer and monitoring the transportation program including compliance with reporting requirements. c. Driver(s) Training.: The PRHTA will review the kind of training the applicant has given (or will give) to the driver(s) a review of the driver(s) record. d. ADA and Section 504: Reviewing applicant compliance with ADA and Section 504 provisions including a visual inspection of the presence of ramps accessible facilities display of Civil Rights Policies and Equal Employment Etc. *CPT- HSTP included Strategies to properly address the identified gaps and needs key recommendations and guidelines were developed. See attached document Human Coordinated Plan_Rev_February 26 2020 pages 29 to 32) *See attached pages of the STIP for the activities included in this application.

column31: PUBLIC HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES, MONTANA DEPARTMENT OF
column55: The purpose of the Weatherization Assistance Program is to increase the energy efficiency of dwellings owned and occupied by low-income persons, reduce their total residential expenditures, and improve their health and safety. The priority population for the Weatherization Assistance Program is persons who are particularly vulnerable such as the elderly, persons with disabilities, families with children, high residential energy users, and households with high-energy burden.
